The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25433,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nba-finals-2020-lakers-heat-game-1-24-thoughts","date":"2020-10-01","title":"24 thoughts on Game 1 of The Finals","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014  The Lakers and Heat playing for the title of NBA bubble kings. I have to admit, I wasn\u2019t sure we\u2019d get here on March 11, when the season shut down due to the coronavirus pandemic. But here we are, four wins away from crowning a champion in the most tumultuous season of my lifetime. The calendar year opened with the somber news of longtime NBA Commissioner David Stern\u2019s passing. After the shocking news on Jan. 26 of the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant, his daughter, Giannia, and seven others, it felt like rock bottom. All-Star weekend in Chicago felt like a giant group hug, seeing all the usual faces in the NBA ecosystem doing their best to celebrate those who were lost as well as the best in the game this season. The season felt rejuvenated after that. But it didn\u2019t last. When Rudy Gobert\u2019s positive test for COVID-19 shut down that game in Oklahoma City, you had to know things would take a dramatic change. But a four-month hiatus and then the social-justice uproar in the wake of George Floyd\u2019s killing in Minneapolis, no one saw that twist coming and we don\u2019t know how many more twists and turns there will be in the future. The season restart wasn\u2019t guaranteed. But the league and the NBPA pulled it together, a collaborative effort that saved the season. There were turbulent times along the way. There was a moment \u2014 when the Milwaukee Bucks didn\u2019t take the floor for a playoff game against the Orlando Magic \u2014 when it seemed like forces beyond the control of anyone here were conspiring to bring an abrupt and crushing end to this season. And yet here we are, on the cusp of perhaps another title for LeBron James or another for the franchise \u2014 the Miami Heat \u2014 that helped him capture his first two. We\u2019re talking about a potentially dream finish to what on multiple occasions felt like a nightmare year for so many. It\u2019s good to be here, no \u2026 it\u2019s great to be here, to chronicle (with 24 Thoughts from each game) the finish to the longest season in NBA history. It\u2019s time to sit back and enjoy the games now, each and every frantic minute as these teams fight for the right to be NBA champions. * * * 24 \u2014  This is a giant step up for Butler, who has been the most confident man in the bubble from the start. Anxious to see if the Heat can rise to the moment with so little experience on their side compared to the Lakers. 23 \u2014  These two \u2026 SMH! 22 \u2014  Tyler Herro out here making those of us who have been around the league for a few years feel absolutely ancient. Ugh! 21 \u2014  Pretty good Game 1 seats for the MDE (Shaquille O\u2019Neal), President Barack Obama and \u201cBig Game James\u201d (Worthy). 20 \u2014  No jitters whatsoever for the \u201cunderdog\u201d Heat early as they open up an early 23-10 lead on the home team. 19 \u2014  Things come at you fast in The Finals. One minute you\u2019re rolling and the next, you\u2019re getting rolled over. 18 \u2014  Playoff Rondo is a real thing! 17 \u2014  Most likely the first of many milestones for him in this series. 16 \u2014  Let\u2019s not get ahead of ourselves. Too soon. 15 \u2014  Age ain\u2019t nothing but a number for Herro. Young fella showing up and showing out in his first taste of The Finals. But he\u2019s getting picked on defensively. Lakers have spotted the target. 14 \u2014  Lakers doing just fine without LeBron on the floor. So you know what\u2019s coming when he cranks up. Warning sign for the Heat down 57-47 with just over three minutes to play before halftime. 13 \u2014  The Heat dared the Lakers to beat them from deep in the first half \u2026 and that\u2019s exactly what they did. 12 \u2014  This is how you finish the first half when you flip it from a 13-point deficit early to a 65-48 lead. 11 \u2014  Just the facts! 10 \u2014  The Lakers shooting 13-for-20 from beyond the 3-point line and Goran Dragic out for the rest of the game with a foot injury has a way of shaking up a team, even one as confident as the Heat coming into this game. Lakers up 76-54 and showing no signs of slowing down. 9 \u2014 Its  93-67 Lakers at the end of the third and no Bam (shoulder) or Dragic for the Heat. This could get downright filthy before long if the Heat don\u2019t start knocking down some shots. 8 \u2014  Not the news you want to hear about the player who has led you in scoring in this postseason. Kendrick Nunn, second in the Kia Rookie of the Year race, is on in relief. But this could be a potentially devastating blow for the Heat. 7 \u2014  Pretty much sums up the night for Spoelstra and the Heat. Game 1 got off to that nice 23-10 start and rolled all the way downhill and into a gator-filled ditch down here at Walt Disney World. 6 \u2014  Tough night all around for Herro and the Heat. 5 \u2014  Can\u2019t do a Lakers\u2019 win without some instant analysis from Magic! 4 \u2014  The Lakers\u2019 116-98 Game 1 demolition of the suddenly wounded Heat puts this series in a completely different light as we get ready for Game 2 on Friday. The status of Bam and Dragic will determine how much longer the bubble stays open for basketball business. If the Heat are down two starters \u2026 don\u2019t want to get ahead of the news or anything. But it\u2019s fair to wonder if the Heat\u2019s bubble got busted tonight. 3 \u2014  AD looked super comfortable in his first Finals game, Finals MVP comfortable? 2 \u2014  I wondered how Bam would hold up against the pounding the Lakers would dish out via this future Hall of Famer. Didn\u2019t go too well for Bam. 1 \u2014  Not exactly the news you want to hear Heat fans. * * * Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25479,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/5-things-learned-2020-finals-game-1","date":"2020-10-01","title":"5 things we learned from Game 1 of 2020 Finals","content":" Five things we learned from the Los Angeles Lakers\u2019 116-98 victory against the Miami Heat in Game 1 of the 2020 Finals Wednesday on the NBA campus in Orlando. * * * No, there were no spinal injuries among the Heat\u2019s multiple mishaps in Game 1. But they could have felt a little whiplash after getting outscored 75-30 during a stretch of barely 22 minutes . It began with their own early run, opening a 23-10 lead deep into the first quarter. Then came the Lakers\u2019 19-3 rush to close out that quarter. The second quarter was a mismatch, won by L.A. when it outshot the Heat 63.2% to 36.4%. That was followed by the Lakers\u2019 22-7 start to the second half in slightly less than six minutes. It was 87-55 when the smoke cleared. That swing of 45 points rendered most of what followed irrelevant, except perhaps for Lakers coach Frank Vogel\u2019s film review before Game 2 to fend off any overconfidence in his crew. For Miami, the freefall from that early lead to donesville was like a magician pulling a silk table cloth off a magnificently set table, but sending the china, glassware, centerpiece and good silver flying across the dining room. The Lakers did it with unusual 3-point proficiency. They hit 11 of their first 17 in Game 1 and totaled 15-of-38. That\u2019s their third most 3-pointers made in the postseason and eighth most in all of 2019-20. L.A. had ranked 23rd in takes (31.6) and makes (11.0) during the regular season, 21st in accuracy (.349), so they outdid themselves across the board Wednesday. Miami\u2019s zone, so honed and effective in the East finals against Boston, ran and hid this time. As vexing as it is to spell, plantar fasciitis \u2013 trauma to the thick band of tissue that runs from one\u2019s heel bone toward the toes \u2013 is even worse to play on for an NBA player. That\u2019s what Miami faces with Goran Dragic suffering a reported tear in his left foot in the second quarter. \u201cPlantar fasciitis sucks,\u201d said Joakim Noah, one of the many who have been hobbled by it through the years. \u201cIt feels like you have needles underneath your feet while you\u2019re playing.\u201d Known among trainers as \u201cthe Achilles heel of NBA players,\u201d the injury has afflicted a multitude of players at varying degrees of severity, including Noah, Pau Gasol, Jason Kidd, Joe Johnson, Damian Lillard, Nene, Derrick Favors and Steve Francis. It particularly hampers running, cutting and jumping \u2014 three somewhat useful activities in basketball. It is best treated with orthotics, injections, immobilization and rest, two of which Miami has little time for. So as much as it stunk for the Heat that Bam Adebayo aggravated a shoulder injury and was done after 21 minutes, as much as Jimmy Butler twisting an ankle gouged into his effectiveness from that point, Dragic limping off was the worst. And could settle this Finals almost before it began. Dragic had been the Heat\u2019s leading scorer through the playoffs, averaging 19.9 points per game. His usage rate of 27.2 in 16 postseason games has been higher than in any of his 12 NBA regular seasons (it was 25.7 in his All-Star season of 2017-18, when he averaged 17.3 points). He is a creative, slippery offensive player, initiating trouble for any defense and often bailing out Miami deep into shot clocks. Kendrick Nunn, the All-Rookie first-teamer who logged only 23 minutes in the East finals and none at all in the last three games, scored 18 points mostly in garbage time of Game 1. He is Miami\u2019s best option, barring a miracle recovery by or remarkable treatment of Dragic\u2019s sore foot gets him back to at least 80 percent capability. That\u2019s the reason the Lakers started big, with both Anthony Davis and Dwight Howard in the lineup, only to subsequently go small. Trailing by double digits so early in the game will scuttle plans like that, pronto. That big lineup wasn\u2019t equipped to deal with the Heat\u2019s early 3-point proficiency (welcome back, Jae Crowder) or Miami\u2019s pick-and-roll forays. So no matter how much Vogel wanted to flex his team\u2019s size advantage at the other end, he had to find better matchups. Consider: On a night when Danny Green was plus-21 and the L.A. bench pack of Rajon Rondo, Kyle Kuzma and Alex Caruso all finished with double-digit plus ratings, Howard in his 15 minutes was minus-2. Miami is facing the more acute defensive problem now. It needs Tyler Herro as a scorer and Duncan Robinson as a shooter, but both were treated like raw meat by LeBron James and his teammates. James, as we\u2019ve seen in other playoffs when the pace slows to the half-court, all but points to the mismatch he wants as if he\u2019s at one of the finest steakhouses in the land, making his selection off the server\u2019s tray. The Lakers run a little action to isolate the lonely bone-in ribeye, and nature\u2019s food chain takes over. By the way, when it\u2019s LeBron licking his chops over Herro or Robinson, the physiques of those tender Heat defenders feel like more injuries waiting to happen. Herro was a minus-35 in Game 1. And even though Robinson was a good-enough-to-lose minus-8, he didn\u2019t make a shot, missing the mere three 3-pointers he launched in 27 minutes. What about Andre Iguodala? Certainly Iguodala has the resume defensively and great experience against James. But the difference between James\u2019 35 years on the planet and Iggy\u2019s 36 turned into 35 Wednesday, the gap between the Lakers\u2019 star\u2019s plus-10 and the Miami vet\u2019s minus-25. If he continues to play the way he did in Game 1 (34 points, nine rebounds, five assists and three blocked shots in 38 minutes). If that keeps him about five points and three boards, on average, ahead of James in the stats when this is over, while staying within an assist or two. And if James keeps talking up his younger teammate the way he did after this one (\u201cHe was, once again, a force in every facet the game\u201d). Otherwise, that award remains James\u2019 to lose. His results were sufficiently impressive \u2013 25 points, 13 rebounds, nine assists, a couple 3-pointers and a handful of highlights \u2013 to keep him as both the sentimental (he\u2019s old) and still-formidable favorite. Let\u2019s see how much the Heat and the media talk about Miami\u2019s vaunted culture when they\u2019ve got as many as three starters in the trainer\u2019s room in the hours between Games 1 and 2. One thing culture is not is a bunch of backups going against the LeBron James and the Anthony Davis, trying to win four out of six now. There will be no sympathy from James, at least not until it\u2019s over. Back in 2015, he had to play a Finals without Cleveland\u2019s Nos. 2 and 3, Kyrie Irving and Kevin Love. Against Golden State. Soldiering on with the likes of Tristan Thompson, Matthew Dellavedova and Timofey Mozgov. So in addition to plugging the leaks of his defense, Heat coach Erik Spoelstra has to be prepared to try that with replacement parts. Remember, thanks to the bubble format \u2014 and the fact we\u2019re watching Finals games in October \u2014 there are no extended breaks in this series, no travel days folded in. The only gap of one additional day comes between Game 4 Tuesday and Game 5 next Friday. Do the math. That might be too late. * * * Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25410,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/2020-nba-draft-combine-media-availability-sessions","date":"2020-10-01","title":"2020 NBA Draft Combine Media Availability Sessions","content":"The NBA will host several Zoom Media Availability sessions beginning Monday, Sept 28 with top participants from NBA Combine 2020 in advance of the 2020 NBA Draft Presented by State Farm. Links to the videos of these sessions will be posted when available. Monday, Sept. 28 Tuesday, Sept. 29 Wednesday, Sept. 30"},{"id":25468,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/finals-stat-lakers-heat-4","date":"2020-10-01","title":"The Finals Stat, Game 1: Lakers beat Heat at their own game","content":" The Los Angeles Lakers are in control. After trailing by 13 points early in Game 1 of The Finals , they outscored the Miami Heat 75-30 over the next 22 minutes of basketball, eventually cruising to a a 116-98 victory on Wednesday. The Heat have more to worry about than the loss. In the process, they lost both Goran Dragic (left foot) and Bam Adebayo (left shoulder) to injuries. Jimmy Butler also turned his left ankle twice. And if any of those three guys is unavailable going forward, the task of winning four of the next six games (against a team that\u2019s won 13 of its last 15) becomes much tougher. One stat stood out from the rest as the Lakers took a 1-0 series lead. 25-11 \u2014 Made free-throw differential in Game 1. Entering The Finals, the Heat ranked second in postseason free throw rate (33.2 attempts per 100 shots from the field) and had outscored their opponents by 3.9 points per game (the third best differential) from the free throw line. The Lakers ranked third in free throw rate (30.9 attempts per 100 FGA), but 15th in opponent rate (31.7), and had been outscored by 1.5 points per game at the line. The Lakers starting Dwight Howard, the postseason leader in fouls per 36 minutes , increased the chances of the Heat being able to get to the line, and Howard did commit three fouls in just 14:55. But Miami\u2019s 14 free-throw attempts were tied for their fewest in the postseason . Adebayo matched his postseason average (six attempts) in just 21 minutes and Butler drew a game-high seven fouls . But his five free-throw attempts were four fewer than his postseason average and the Heat had just three attempts beyond those two. Meanwhile, the Lakers were 25-for-27 themselves from the line. Anthony Davis drew six fouls and was 10-for-10. And it was LeBron James who took Adebayo into the paint late in the first quarter to draw the second straight foul on the Heat center, a critical play in the Lakers\u2019 comeback from that early deficit. The Lakers\u2019 3-point shooting (11-for-15) was the story of that extended, 75-30 run . But that\u2019s obviously not sustainable and Miami\u2019s bigger concern could be inside the arc. If the Heat can\u2019t outscore the Lakers at the line, they\u2019re in trouble. Butler and Adebayo are their main source of free throws, but losing Dragic\u2019s 14 drives per game ( 10th in the postseason through the conference finals) would hurt their ability to put pressure on the Lakers\u2019 defense and get to the stripe. The Finals:  Traditional | Advanced | 4 factors | Players | Player shooting | Lineups Matchups:  Lakers on offense | Heat on offense Lakers playoffs:  Team stats | Advanced splits | Player stats | Player shooting | Lineups Heat playoffs:  Team stats | Advanced splits | Player stats | Player shooting | Lineups * * * John Schuhmann is a staff writer for NBA.com. The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25473,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/2020-nba-finals-adam-silver-press-conference","date":"2020-10-01","title":"Adam Silver succeeds navigating 'bubble' but uncertainty ahead","content":" Although figuratively known as the \u201cbubble,\u201d the site of the NBA\u2019s ambitious and unprecedented restart of its 2019-20 season has been, in fact, on a campus \u2014 the ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex at Walt Disney World Resort outside of Orlando. Sticking with campus culture, then, it\u2019s fair to say that even with its Finals just beginning Thursday, the league already has aced most of its exams in bringing back basketball in a pandemic. Not that anyone wants to come back for sophomore year. \u201cI\u2019m most proud that we collectively came together as a community and pulled this off,\u201d said commissioner Adam Silver, before Game 1 of The Finals between the Miami Heat and the Los Angeles Lakers. \u201cBy that I mean all of the stakeholders. The players, the team governors, 30 teams \u2014 not just 22 teams \u2014 [and] the support we received from our fans.\u201d Silver added: \u201cEspecially, frankly given all the division in our country right now, the fact that people could set their minds to something, come together, make enormous sacrifices, compromise.\u201d This was not a victory lap \u2014 not yet, not with two teams and another week or two to go. But it was a moment of appreciation and gratitude, with some pride folded in. \u201cThe pride of the sense that we\u2019ve accomplished this against many obstacles,\u201d Siver said, \u201cand at a time also when I think people needed to see this.\u201d Silver met with reporters Thursday evening, an annual tradition at the start of his league\u2019s championship series. But the media reps were both nearby and remote, a limited number in the room and many more scattered across the country and around the globe, checking in via Zoom. And of course, when the commissioner finished, he carefully donned a mask before stepping from the podium. That\u2019s the new yet odd NBA normal, life as the league has come to live it. The Heat and the Lakers will blow by the three-month mark this week for time spent in the bubble. Their mental and physical endurance, their focus, their sense of purpose has been topped only by the time, effort, manpower, expense and defiance of a determined and dangerous virus that the NBA has logged. With the help of literally thousands. Silver pegged the number at 6,500 who made the bubble possible, from the players, coaches and staffs to so many support workers from the Orlando community assisting at the arenas and the hotels. \u201cI analogize it a bit to when you go to a movie and you see the actors on the screen and then the credits start rolling at the end, and they keep rolling and they keep rolling,\u201d Silver said. \u201cThat\u2019s the 6,500 people. \u201cAnd it\u2019s the essential workers, the people who do our testing every day, take our temperatures, clean our rooms, maintain these facilities. It\u2019s the bus drivers. \u2026 It\u2019s everyone who\u2019s been involved down here. A huge \u2018thank you\u2019 to the people of Orange County, Florida, who have taken such good care of us over our time here.\u201d So now that they\u2019ve gotten pretty good at it, there\u2019s zero chance any of them wants to repeat it for the 2020-21 season. Which is entirely beside the point. The NBA and everyone involved with it might have no choice but to yield and react all over again to COVID-19. Already, the \u201c2020\u201d signage on next season can be removed, with whatever schedule gets played likely to fit entirely in 2021. A January start seems to be the earliest fans again will see games that matter. With a bunch of unknowns from there. Teams in their cities? Fans in the arenas? Multiple bubbles rather than one? Eighty-two games or maybe fewer? Legit questions all, in search of answers. \u201cNothing has really changed in this virus, as far as I know,\u201d Silver said. \u201cIn fact, I think the majority of states right now, cases are ticking back up again. There\u2019s predictions of a combination of flu and coronavirus season, what that will mean. People are moving back indoors. In some cases, people have COVID fatigue and aren\u2019t following the same protocols. \u201cSo in many ways we\u2019re looking at a lot of the same factors we looked at determining what to do this season.\u201d Wait, there\u2019s more: Any changes in terms of the collective bargaining agreement between the teams and the players would require negotiations, at a point when the patience of so many principals has worn thin. Sequestering on the Disney campus one time for one, two or three months is one thing; signing up for another full season would be quite another.  Gaining access to better, quicker testing could help contain the virus\u2019 spread by identifying carriers immediately. It also would allow for attendance at arenas, not 19,000 strong necessarily but several thousand spectators, properly distanced. \u201cBased on everything I\u2019ve read, there\u2019s almost no chance that there will be a vaccine, at least that is widely distributed before we start the next season,\u201d Silver said. \u201cSo I do not see the development of a vaccine as a prerequisite.\u201d As for the league\u2019s internal business \u2013 particularly establishing the salary cap and luxury tax threshold for next season \u2013 operations have been gummed up by so many variables. The NBA still was calculating the financial hit from splintered relations with China \u2013 estimated as a $200 million loss or more this year, after the political controversy of last fall \u2013 when the virus shutdown began. Silver has estimated the portion of revenue derived from fan attendance at games at approximately 40 percent, worth hundreds of millions more. The Draft, rescheduled from June, has been pegged for now to Nov. 18. But there is no date yet for the start of free agency, and without cap and tax numbers, the roster-building work of salary structures and possible transactions can\u2019t get done. The best-case scenario might be that the league works a second season with the 2019-20 limits \u2014 $109.14 million for the cap, $132.6 million to enter the luxury tax. That would kick the can of a financial reckoning down the road for a year or longer, hopeful that some glimmer of the old normal NBA might see a rebound in revenues. Coming together to confront big problems isn\u2019t going to end anytime soon, then, no matter how soon this bubble pops. ALSO OF NOTE \u2022 The NBA\u2019s deep dive into social and racial issues was a component of what made the bubble successful, Silver said. \u201cTo me, certainly it began with what\u2019s important to our players is important to us. \u201cBut it wasn\u2019t just our players. The players know and the NBA community knows there\u2019s a long history in this league of fighting for social justice, for racial equality.\u201d \u2022 Silver understood the view of many fans, weary of nonstop big issues in a virus-riddled election year, \u201cwho look to sports as a respite.\u201d \u201cMy response is that, again, I\u2019m listening,\u201d he said. \u201cBut these are unique times. \u2026 I still firmly believe it was and is the right thing to do.\u201d \u2022 The league\u2019s weekly release of coronavirus test results stopped when the cases did, Silver said. There was no news, so no reports. That, in fact, might be the biggest takeaway of the Orlando bubble, even after the 2020 NBA champion is crowned. The worst-case scenario of a seriously ill player, coach or staff member simply never happened. * * * Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25411,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/president-barack-obama-shaq-james-worthy-virtual-fans","date":"2020-10-01","title":"Former President Barack Obama attends Game 1 virtually","content":" Former Lakers Shaquille O\u2019Neal and James Worthy bracketed another celebrity among the virtual attendees in Game 1 of The Finals: Former President Barack Obama. No fans are in attendance at The Finals, but the league is using video technology as throughout the seeding games and playoffs to give a simulated-audience feel to the games on the NBA campus in Orlando. Obama, who plays the game and has a deft left-handed jumper, is a big fan of the NBA. He later revealed attending Game 1 alongside poll workers from More Than a Vote, and implored the American public to act in the upcoming Nov. 3 general election."},{"id":25497,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/social-media-follower-growth-nba-restart-official-release","date":"2020-09-30","title":"LeBron James, Tyler Herro lead NBA in social media follower growth during NBA restart","content":" Multiple NBA players have increased their popularity on social media due to successful oncourt performances during the NBA Restart. Five of the top 15 will compete in the NBA Finals presented by YouTube TV, tipping off tonight at 9 p.m. ET on ABC. LeBron James is at the No. 1 spot after seeing an increase of more than 4M followers during the restart while Miami Heat rookie and breakout star Tyler Herro has landed at No. 2 after seeing an increase of more than 790K followers. The Top 15 Players by follower growth across Instagram and Twitter since the beginning of the NBA Restart (July 30): The Top 5 Players by follower growth across Instagram and Twitter during the Conference Finals (Sept. 15-28): \u2022 LeBron James +573K \u2022 Tyler Herro +522K \u2022 Jamal Murray +220K \u2022 Anthony Davis +201K \u2022 Jimmy Butler +141K \u2022 Tyler Herro saw the biggest increase in followers added (+41%) among all players during the Conference Finals. \u2022 Tyler Herro ranks second in followers added on Instagram since the NBA Restart tip-off. He began the NBA Restart with 69M Instagram followers and sits at 72.6M as of September 29."},{"id":25514,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nbas-most-popular-jersey-and-team-merchandise","date":"2020-09-30","title":"LeBron James, Lakers lead NBA's jersey and merchandise list during restart","content":" NEW YORK \u2013 The National Basketball Association (NBA) and National Basketball Players Association today jointly announced that LeBron James and the Los Angeles Lakers secured the top spots on the NBA\u2019s Most Popular Jersey and Team Merchandise lists during the 2020 NBA Restart. Denver Nuggets"},{"id":25498,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nba-announces-12-officials-finals","date":"2020-09-30","title":"NBA announces 12 officials for The 2020 Finals","content":" NEW YORK \u2014 The NBA today announced the list of 12 referees who will officiate the NBA Finals 2020 presented by YouTube TV. The championship series between the Miami Heat and Los Angeles Lakers tips off on Wednesday, Sept. 30 at 9 p.m. ET on ABC. \u201cCongratulations to this outstanding group on a well-deserved honor. A Finals assignment is the pinnacle of the profession for our officials,\u201d said Byron Spruell, NBA President, League Operations. \u201cWe are grateful for their dedication to the game and the sacrifices they have made during an unprecedented season.\u201d Finals officials were selected by the NBA Referee Operations management team based on their performance throughout the first three rounds of the 2020 playoffs. Officials were evaluated after each round to determine advancement in this year\u2019s postseason. The officiating roster also includes three first-time Finals referees, Tony Brown, Pat Fraher and Josh Tiven. NBA officials Courtney Kirkland and Kevin Scott have been assigned as Replay Center officials for The Finals 2020. Individual game assignments for referees are posted at NBA.com\/official at approximately 9 a.m. ET each game day."},{"id":25507,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/film-study-how-lakers-can-attack-heat-zone","date":"2020-09-30","title":"Film Study: How Lakers can attack Heat's zone defense","content":" The Los Angeles Lakers and Miami Heat haven\u2019t played each other in 9 1\/2 months. So there are many questions to be answered when Game 1 of The Finals tips off at 9 p.m. ET on Wednesday (ABC). One of those questions is in regard to the Heat\u2019s 2-3 zone defense. After using it for 157 possessions (27% of all defensive possessions) in the conference finals, how much of it will they play against the Lakers? The Heat themselves probably don\u2019t know the answer just yet. The Lakers are a very different team than the Boston Celtics, and the Heat actually went through two series (against Indiana and Milwaukee) without playing any zone at all. But there\u2019s one big reason why zone would make a lot of sense against this particular opponent \u2026 The Heat played eight possessions of 2-3 zone in the first quarter of Game 6 against Boston, and the Celtics made five 3-pointers on those eight possessions. That, along with Boston having had its best game against the zone (14 points on nine possessions) in Game 5, might have been reason to go away from it. But the Heat stuck with the zone and used it for almost all of the 37-27 fourth quarter that put them in The Finals. The Celtics certainly got more comfortable against the zone as the series went on, and they got a lot of open 3s (many from the corners) against it. But overall, they scored 1.11 points per possession against the zone and 1.15 otherwise. As we look forward to Lakers-Heat, the point-per-possession numbers may not be the most important. Against the zone, the Celtics took more than half of their shots (73\/145) from 3-point range and attempted just 13 free throws per 100 shots from the field. Otherwise, they took only 39% of their shots from 3-point range and attempted 33 free throws per 100 shots from the field. So the zone forced more jump shots and allowed fewer free throws. That\u2019s an even more important formula against the Lakers, the team that, in the regular season, had the biggest differential between its field goal percentage in the paint (60.9%, first) and its effective field goal percentage on shots from outside the paint (47.7%, 26th). That outside-the-paint number has been higher (50.4%) in the playoffs, but protecting the basket remains priority No. 1 against the Lakers. In the postseason, the Lakers have scored 1.06 points per attempt from 3-point range (1.20 on corner 3s), but 1.42 per attempt in the restricted area and 1.49 per (2-shot) trip to the line. And the zone may be the best way to prevent the latter two. When the Heat play man-to-man, Bam Adebayo switches almost every ball screen. That allows him to neutralize the man with the ball (he\u2019s allowed just 0.58 points per possession on isolations), but it also takes him away from the rim . In Games 3 and 5, the Heat played 25 total possessions of zone, and the Celtics scored 133 total points in the restricted area or on free throws. In Games 4 and 6, the Heat played 89 total possessions of zone and the Celtics scored 91 total points in the restricted area or on free throws. As noted, forcing jumpers is more important against the Lakers than it is against the Celtics, who had the sixth smallest differential between their field goal percentage in the paint (54.6%, 22nd) and their effective field goal percentage on shots from outside the paint (51.6%, ninth) in the regular season. So don\u2019t be surprised if we see zone early and often in The Finals. If we see the zone, here are some ways that the Lakers might attack it \u2026 1. Inside screen and go from there The Celtics attacked the zone the same way for much of Games 5 and 6. They had their big man set a ball-screen on the inside of one of the top defenders. If that screen is solid and the other top defender doesn\u2019t slide over to the nail (the middle of the foul line), the ball-handler is able to get into the paint \u2026 If the other top defender does slide over, the ball-handler can pass to the opposite side of the floor, where a huge seam has been created\u2026 And if the defender on the weak-side baseline steps up to close off that seam, a shooter is wide open in the corner. LeBron James is the Lakers\u2019 primary ball-handler (especially in the starting lineup), but would obviously be the best guy to attack the seam from the wing, as he did in the first regular-season meeting when the Lakers set an inside screen up top \u2026 So the inside-screen action may work best with Rajon Rondo or Alex Caruso in the game and with Danny Green ( 18-for-43 on corner 3s in the playoffs ) or Kentavious Caldwell-Pope (18-for-38) in the corner. 2. Outside screen and attack If one of the ball-handling guards isn\u2019t on the floor, the Lakers can set a screen for James on the outside of the zone, allowing him to attack those seams on the side of the zone directly. A shooter in the strong-side corner gives the baseline defender a difficult decision to make. 3. Davis in the middle That inside-screen play above (where James drew a flagrant foul on Meyers Leonard) was one of 27 possessions of zone that the Heat played in the November meeting between these two teams (they played just eight possessions of zone in the December game). But it was one of only a few times where the Lakers used that inside-screen action. Most of the time, they had somebody (usually Anthony Davis) flash into the middle of the zone. More often than not, he got a shot for himself ( a layup and a short jumper are two examples). But if the Lakers are playing big and Adebayo steps up to guard Davis in the middle of the zone, he can find either JaVale McGee or Dwight Howard on the baseline, which he did a couple of times in November \u2026 With the lineups the Heat have been using in the playoffs, they\u2019re relatively small at those two baseline positions in the zone. So McGee and Howard can score above guys like Tyler Herro and Duncan Robinson. And if the baseline guys manage to take away the high-low option, Davis can kick out to open shooters . 4. Post and cut Enes Kanter was the only guy that the Celtics posted up against the zone, but the Lakers have both Davis ( third in the postseason with 8.0 post-ups per game ) and James (12th with 3.1). Getting the ball into the post against the zone is tougher than it is against man-to-man, but it can open some things up by turning the defense around. McGee actually got a post-up in that November game. Jimmy Butler turned his head and Caldwell-Pope cut behind him for a layup\u2026 You can get into the teeth of the zone via the dribble or the pass. James could be the toughest guy in the league to stop off the dribble, while Davis is arguably the league\u2019s best interior target. But getting into the paint isn\u2019t the same as getting all the way to the basket. And if the Heat can mostly force short jumpers from Davis or James or catch-and-shoot 3s from the Lakers\u2019 guards, that\u2019s a lot better than a heavier diet of layups and dunks. The Lakers have options in regard to bending the zone. Breaking it is easier said than done. * * * John Schuhmann is a senior stats analyst for NBA.com. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25490,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/chris-paul-enrolls-hbcu-encourage-vote","date":"2020-09-29","title":"Chris Paul enrolls in North Carolina HBCU to encourage vote","content":" WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) \u2014 NBA star Chris Paul has enrolled in a historically Black college in North Carolina, where he will take a class and encourage students to get to the polls. The Oklahoma City guard has enrolled at Winston-Salem State, across town from Wake Forest, where he played for two seasons before going to the NBA, the Winston-Salem Journal reported. His parents also attended Winston-Salem State. \u201cWe are providing transportation to HBCU students to get the polls so we are working on that now,\u201d Paul said recently on ESPN\u2019s \u201cFirst Take,\u201d adding that he\u2019s partnered with two other NBA players to help HBCU students get to the polls. During the NBA playoffs, Paul raised awareness of HBCU\u2019s by wearing different shoes representing schools such as Winston-Salem State, North Carolina A&T and N.C. Central."},{"id":25519,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/lebron-james-returns-nba-finals-10th-time","date":"2020-09-29","title":"LeBron James knows anything is possible in The Finals","content":" The first time LeBron James reached The Finals, in 2007, he was a 22-year-old trying to pull off a grown-man stunt. The Cavaliers were in no position to beat the dynastic Spurs, not with Boobie Gibson, Larry Hughes, Drew Gooden and Zydrunas Ilgauskas as the main pieces next to LeBron . Tim Duncan and Tony Parker and Gregg Popovich didn\u2019t lose much sleep in a series that lasted slightly longer than lunch. He is now 35 and once again back at the dance, for a 10th time , a staggering amount by any measure, especially considering nine of those trips have come in the last decade. That alone puts him beyond the reach of most athletic immortals in any professional team sport and certainly more than many of us will ever see in our lifetimes. As the NBA Finals begin with him on the floor at tipoff, the only unusual aspect of this familiar scenario is the series taking place in October instead of June. These trips aren\u2019t getting old for him, and from a performance standpoint, he doesn\u2019t seem to be getting old, either. LeBron made first-team All-NBA with the Lakers and was runner-up for Kia MVP this season, his 17th in the league. He led the NBA in assists in his first full-time role as ball distributor. Some of the greats in this game were relegated to supporting duty and just hanging on a roster, mainly for the money, at this stage of their careers. They were nothing more than hood ornaments, reminders of what they used to be. LeBron, much like Michael Jordan (scoring championship and an NBA title at the same age), remains the outlier as the centerpiece of his team, with all due respect to Anthony Davis. \u201cHe\u2019s seen everything,\u201d said Erik Spoelstra, who coached LeBron with the Heat. \u201cAt this point in his career, it\u2019s just about winning. And his ability to do what he does at his age is incredibly uncommon.\u201d We can discuss and analyze what it will all mean if he wins his fourth championship on his third team. That\u2019s for another day, sometime in the next week if he and the Lakers beat Miami. For now, it\u2019s all about reaching this point, a milestone in itself. \u201cTo be back in the Finals against Miami I think means a lot more to him winning this than anyone else,\u201d Davis said. \u201cI think this championship is probably second behind Cleveland, being able to get this one for him. It\u2019s been fun to watch him. He goes to The Finals every year. Win or lose, he always comes back the next year. And to finally get back after last year and go against his former team, I\u2019m pretty sure he\u2019s going to have a competitive series.\u201d Former Yankees star Derek Jeter, who knows something about playing for multiple championships, once said that the title is never guaranteed once you get there; but you must keep giving yourself those chances. He\u2019s right, and that\u2019s sometimes lost when taking into account the six times LeBron came up short in The Finals. The more swings you get, the better the odds of connecting. LeBron agrees and says: \u201cDo you always become successful at it? Are you always going to win? No, it doesn\u2019t happen like that. But you\u2019re able to sleep a little bit better at night when you know you\u2019ve punched the clock.\u201d LeBron has carried lesser teams to The Finals and more talented teams. None of his teams in Cleveland were favored to win. The 2007 series with the Spurs was projected as a blowout (and didn\u2019t disappoint). In his four cracks at the Warriors, only one of them successful, and his lone formidable teammate was Kyrie Irving, who was injured early in one of those Finals and sat out. Only with Chris Bosh and Dwyane Wade in Miami did LeBron bring ample firepower before this season, where Davis and a decent collection of veteran role players will give the Lakers the significant upper-hand over the superstar-lacking Heat. \u201cI never had a problem with any team I went to The Finals (with),\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve always been confident that we had the ability to win. If you\u2019re going to a Finals saying you\u2019re undermanned or you feel like you don\u2019t have enough, then who are you? The game is won between the four lines, not won on paper. At the end of the day, when I\u2019ve lost in The Finals, the better team won because they played well, they were more prepared and they did what they needed to do to win those four games. \u201cWhen I\u2019ve won, the same thing. I\u2019m not here to talk about the talent we all have, the team that we have. The game is won in between the four lines, 94 feet. The team that is prepared and the team that executes, the team that is not careless throughout 48 minutes will give themselves a chance to win each and every game. I\u2019m confident going into this Finals, as I\u2019ve always been in my career.\u201d LeBron continues to defy basketball logic in multiple ways in his mid-30s. He\u2019s 6-foot-8 and roughly 250 pounds but moves fluidly and has full ownership of a spin-move in the paint that flummoxes the defense no matter how often he executes it. His 3-point shooting has never been better and, similar to how Jordan developed a baseline turnaround jumper, is aiding LeBron here in the latter stages of his career. His defense was lackluster last season, yet has improved. And his court-sense and ability to find teammates with bounce and bullet passes remains sharper than ever. He makes a wide imprint on almost every game he plays, if not with passing, then leadership, scoring, rebounding and playmaking, particularly in the moment of truth, when a close game begs for a turning point. The run on Finals appearances for LeBron can\u2019t be taken for granted, because the end is probably near. Next season he\u2019ll be 36 and while his body has rarely betrayed him, he is human and there\u2019s lots of mileage on his limbs. Likewise, Davis has a rich history of injury issues and, despite his great health now, that\u2019s always a question with him until it isn\u2019t. Here\u2019s the larger and more sobering issue, though: The competition starting next season will be fierce. Every contender this season should remain just as good if not better next season. That includes the Clippers, Nuggets, Jazz, Bucks, Heat and Celtics, and beware of spoilers such as the Mavericks, Raptors, Blazers and Pelicans. Meanwhile, there are potential monsters forming in Brooklyn and San Francisco, where healthy superstars await anxiously. If LeBron isn\u2019t aware of his own mortality and the multiple threats that\u2019ll assume the championship chase next season, or cares not to subscribe to it, he\u2019ll find out soon enough. Time has a way of bringing even the greats to their knees, begging for mercy. You can eat right and live right and lift all the weights and run all the hills, but gravity is never starstruck; it spares no one and offers no compassion. All you can do is cheat the process as long as possible. * @KingJames : \"I\u2019m here for one reason and one reason only, and that\u2019s to compete for a championship.\" \u2014 Mike Trudell (@LakersReporter) September 29, 2020 Right now, LeBron is winning that game and pushing those limits. Whether he can win four more games in this NBA restart and extend the boundaries of his legacy remains to be seen. At least he has given himself that chance. That, in itself, must be respected and saluted. \u201cTo see what LeBron has done, when he moved on to Cleveland and then to here, it really is just a testament to his greatness and his commitment to winning,\u201d Spoelstra said. \u201cTo be able to do it with different rosters and uniforms is really remarkable.\u201d * * * Shaun Powell has covered the NBA for more than 25 years. You can e-mail him  here , find his archive here   and follow him on  Twitter  . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25508,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/new-california-law-prompted-helicopter-crash-kobe-bryant","date":"2020-09-29","title":"New California law prompted by crash that killed Kobe Bryant","content":" SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) \u2014 Gov. Gavin Newsom on Monday approved legislation prompted by the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant and eight other people that makes it a crime for first responders to take unauthorized photos of deceased people at the scene of an accident or crime. Reports surfaced after the Jan. 26 crash that killed Bryant, his daughter Gianna and the others that graphic photos of the victims were being shared. Eight deputies were accused of taking or sharing graphic photos of the scene, Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva said then, adding that he had ordered the images deleted. He said the department has a policy against taking and sharing crime scene photos, but it did not apply to accident scenes. The measure that will take effect Jan. 1 makes it a misdemeanor with fines up to $1,000 per offense to take such photos for anything other than an official law enforcement purpose. Bryant\u2019s widow, Vanessa Bryant, has sued the department over the photos."},{"id":25512,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nba-restart-numbers","date":"2020-09-29","title":"A Whole New Finals: NBA restart by the numbers","content":" ORLANDO \u2013 The Eastern Conference champion Miami Heat and the Western Conference champion Los Angeles Lakers will tip off the NBA Finals 2020 presented by YouTube TV on Wednesday, Sept. 30 at 9 p.m. ET on ABC and ESPN Radio in the United States. YouTube TV\u2019s NBA Finals plans include launching a new brand TV spot, featuring branding throughout the arena and bringing the product experience to life through innovative broadcast integrations on ABC. TMZ Sports first reported the news of Cuban picking up West, who played for the Mavs in the 2011-12 season. West disclosed in 2009 that he has bipolar disorder and has struggled with off-the-court issues for years. Cuban confirmed to ESPN\u2019s Tim MacMahon that he is attempting to help West get his life back on track. Per The Athletic\u2019s Shams Charania, Cuban reunited West with his mother, Delphina Addison, in Dallas on Monday and West has now checked into a rehab center in Florida. Cuban had asked Addison how he could help and she said she simply needed someone to find West. Cuban waited with West in a hotel until Addison arrived at a hotel and then West entered rehab, Charania reports. Friends and family of West, reports TMZ Sports, have been trying to get West to go to a drug rehabilitation facility and Cuban has offered to pay for treatment. In two videos that went viral in January, West was shown being hit by another man in a street near Washington D.C. In the other , a shirtless, handcuffed West was being asked about the attack. Several former teammates and coaches \u2014 as well as Cuban \u2014 have expressed concern for West. Cuban reportedly made an attempt recently to help West after photos of him panhandling in the Dallas area circulated online last week. West was the No. 24 overall pick of the 2005 draft by the Boston Celtics and played eight seasons in the NBA, averaging 9.7 points, 2.9 rebounds, 3.6 assists and 1.1 steals per game. His last NBA season was in 2011-12 with Dallas, when he averaged 9.6 ppg, 2.3 rpg, 3.2 apg and 1.3 spg in 44 games. He was eventually waived by the Mavs that season for conduct detrimental to the team. After his playing days in the NBA ended, West played for the Mavericks\u2019 NBA G League franchise, the Texas Legends. He logged two separate stints with the Legends, playing in eight games in 2012-13 (averaging 10.3 ppg, 3.8 rpg, 4.4 apg and 2.3 spg) and four games in 2014-15 (14.8 ppg, 4.8 rpg, 3.8 apg, 2.3 spg). He was also a part of the LA Clippers\u2019 Summer League team in 2014 , but was waived shortly after that ended. "},{"id":25506,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nba-unveils-court-design-2020-nba-finals","date":"2020-09-29","title":"NBA unveils court design for 2020 NBA Finals","content":" The NBA unveiled its new court design ahead of the 2020 NBA Finals Presented by YouTube TV. New design elements include the addition of the 2020 NBA Finals Presented by YouTube TV logo at center court as well as the iconic Walt Disney World script written outside opposing lane lines on each side of the court. The 2020 NBA Finals Presented by YouTube TV tips off on Wednesday, Sept. 30, at 9:00 p.m. ET on ABC ."},{"id":25528,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/4-factors-how-heat-can-upset-lakers","date":"2020-09-29","title":"4 factors that could help Heat upset Lakers","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 In the battle between the blue blood program and the blue chip program, someone has to play the role of underdog. The Los Angeles Lakers, chasing championship banner No. 17 and heavily favored in most circles outside of South Florida, don\u2019t mind the blue-blood distinction. And no one relishes the long-shot tag more than the Miami Heat, given their roster loaded with underrated players who have scrapped and clawed their way up the ranks in this bizarre, pandemic-influenced season. The Lakers celebrated their first trip to The Finals since 2010 with a clear message: There \u2019 s more business to be done. The Heat disseminated a similar refrain to their group after clinching their first trip here since 2014: We\u2019re not done yet. But only one of them will leave with the title in what would be an exclamation point to a 2019-20 season filled with moments and obstacles no one could foresee. The No. 5-seed Heat vanquished three higher seeds \u2014 No. 4 Indiana in the first round, No. 1 Milwaukee in the conference semifinals and No. 3 Boston in the conference finals \u2014 to get here. And they come with a warning label. \u201cThey\u2019re super physical, super tough, very, very savvy,\u201d Celtics coach Brad Stevens said. \u201cI think they\u2019re the best team in the East and deserve to be representing the East in the way that they have played.\u201d An upset of the top-seed from the Western Conference is the logical next step. And with no home court advantage to lean on \u2026 anything is possible! ( In the Kevin Garnett voice \u2026) Here are four keys to the Heat springing that upset: * * * Heat coach Erik Spoelstra perfectly deployed a 2-3 zone defense against Boston. The wrinkle worked wonders in their Game 2 win and the threat of it the remainder of the series was invaluable. It\u2019s no gimmick. Spoelstra had no choice but to add the zone to their defensive playbook so All-Star center Bam Adebayo would stay out of harm\u2019s way. The zone lets him set the Heat\u2019s defensive parameters while also protecting the paint.  The bubble environment has allowed for a different sort of scouting experience, with every team getting a real-time look at the in-game adjustments in the same location. The element of surprise, then, won\u2019t be on the Heat\u2019s side. \u201cWe feel good about attacking whatever defense they throw out there,\u201d Lakers coach Frank Vogel said. \u201cWe\u2019re familiar with the different looks they like to show and we have a plan on how to attach each of them. At that point it\u2019s just about trusting your guys and making sure we\u2019re in the right spots. And attack the way the game plan suggests.\u201d The Celtics had the same plan. They couldn\u2019t beat the Heat consistently attacking or trying to shoot them out of their zone. And they were a significantly better 3-point shooting team than the Lakers (35.5% on 3-pointers in the playoffs). Adebayo\u2019s rim protection is compromised when the Heat are switching all over the place, as Boston exploited at times during the conference finals. Spoelstra countered by mixing in some zone stretches that worked to perfection. Kawhi Leonard (2014) and Andre Iguodala (2015) won Finals MVPs based largely on their ability to limit the effectiveness of LeBron James. But it wasn\u2019t a one-man job then and it isn\u2019t now. The Heat have an assortment of bodies to throw at LeBron, a challenge Spoelstra understands as well or better than any NBA coach after serving as James\u2019 coach during his four seasons with the Heat (2010-14). That said, Iguodala\u2019s work on James during their first Finals matchup is a masterclass on how to agitate, frustrate and contain a force like James. \u201cHe\u2019s a historically good perimeter defender, that\u2019s why he\u2019s going to go to the Hall of Fame,\u201d Vogel said of Iguodala. \u201cHe\u2019s got great length, great hands, great feet \u2026 toughness. He\u2019s just one of those types of defenders. There\u2019s a reason these guys are in the NBA Finals, because they have a lot of defensive firepower. And Andre fits in that bucket.\u201d Jimmy Butler and Jae Crowder have also had to match up with LeBron in recent playoffs, giving Spoelstra all sorts of options. Butler will no doubt get his fair share of time guarding LeBron and respects the challenge. \u201cThe main key, and it\u2019s been like this for a very long time, if you want to win, you\u2019re going to have to go through a LeBron James-led team,\u201d he said. \u201cAt the end of the day, that\u2019s what it normally comes down to. \u2026 Obviously you can\u2019t focus in on [just] him because he has so many really good players around him, but you\u2019re going to get the same test over and over again until you pass. And that test is LeBron James.\u201d Celtics point guard Kemba Walker said it best after Adebayo destroyed the Celtics in Game 6: \u201cBam\u2019s a star. And he played like it.\u201d For Spoelstra to turn Adebayo loose on the Lakers the way he did against the Celtics, someone will have to protect the heart and soul of this Heat team from bruisers like Dwight Howard, JaVale McGee and Markieff Morris. They are a significant step up in competition from Boston\u2019s Daniel Theis and Enes Kanter. \u201cYeah, he\u2019s earned it,\u201d Spoelstra said. \u201cThat\u2019s what all the great players have to go through, different schemes, different matchups, game plans against you. They know how important he is, and like I said before, he\u2019s an elite competitor, and he\u2019s as impactful as anyone in this association.\u201d Vogel agreed. \u201cHe \u2019 s is not becoming (a star). He \u2019 s already there. He \u2019 s terrific,\u201d Vogel said. \u201cHe really fits the modern NBA, in terms of playing the center position, with all that he can do. \u2026 He can really do it all, protects the rim, defensively. He can switch out and does a lot of things, and is a huge reason for their success this year.\u201d We could end up seeing Bam and Anthony Davis matched up as small-ball centers in this series (if both coaches decide to go that way). The underdog routine has worked fine to this point. But the Heat need the trio of Goran Dragic, Tyler Herro and Duncan Robinson to elevate their game to meet the magnitude of the moment. Dragic, not Butler or Adebayo, leads the Heat in playoff scoring (20.9 ppg). We\u2019ve already seen what Herro can do when his confidence is soaring and he starts cooking from deep (see his nuclear Game 4 effort vs. Boston). \u201cI think I came into the league more as like a catch-and-shoot guy and that\u2019s what I\u2019m labeled as, but as you can see, I can put the ball on the floor,\u201d Herro said. \u201cI can make plays for others. I can get my own shot off the dribble, and that\u2019s what I did my whole life before Kentucky and before the NBA. I grew up with the ball in my hands and making plays and making tough shots. I feel like that\u2019s my game.\u201d And Robinson, who is shooting 40% on 3-pointers, is due for one of those lights-out performances great shooters tend to have at least once in a series. There\u2019s a reason the Lakers aren\u2019t buying this underdog narrative. The Heat\u2019s profile outside of the bubble is one thing. Their reality is something different inside this diorama. \u201cThey have three All-Star players in Butler, Bam and, I \u2019 ve always felt that when healthy, Goran Dragic is an All-Star-level player,\u201d Vogel said. \u201cThey have shooting. They have toughness. And like I said, they are extremely well-coached. So it\u2019s no surprise they \u2019 ve had such a successful postseason run.\u201d Butler and the Heat have backed up his business trip talk and believe they will emerge on top in one of the most tumultuous seasons in NBA history. He reflected on as much a year to the day since his introductory news conference to announce that he was \u201ccoming home\u201d to Miami. \u201cA lot of ups and downs. Obviously, everything that\u2019s happened in 2020,\u201d he said. \u201cBut from a basketball standpoint, [it] couldn\u2019t be better. You talk about where we are right now going into The Finals, that\u2019s what I want. We talked about it and put that out there in the world, and I think all that positive energy we put out, it came back to us. We believed when not too many did, but that\u2019s okay. We\u2019re going to keep believing and get these next four.\u201d * * * Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst. The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25499,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/los-angeles-lakers-miami-heat-begin-finals-preparations","date":"2020-09-29","title":"Lakers, Heat get started with their Finals preparations","content":" LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. \u2014 Bam Adebayo woke up on Monday with the realization that only two teams still have a chance to win this season\u2019s NBA championship. Goosebumps kicked in at the thought. What was once a 22-team bubble at Walt Disney World is down to the final two, with Adebayo and the Miami Heat set to take on LeBron James and the Los Angeles Lakers in the NBA Finals that start on Wednesday night. It\u2019s the first finals matchup between the clubs, with the Lakers looking for a record-tying 17th title and the Heat seeking their fourth in the last 15 seasons. \u201cIt\u2019s pretty cool considering, when you really think about it, it\u2019s you and one other team that are still left standing and one of the two will be raising the Larry O\u2019Brien Trophy,\u201d Adebayo said Monday. \u201cBut we know that the job isn\u2019t done yet.\u201d The Heat were spending much of Monday resting up before an evening team meeting would officially start their finals preparation process. The Lakers, who won the Western Conference finals on Saturday \u2014 a day before Miami finished off the Eastern Conference crown \u2014 were starting to get their game plan in order after a one-day break as well. Much like the Heat, the Lakers took a moment to enjoy winning the conference title. Winning a day ahead of Miami just happens to give the Lakers a bit more time to prepare for Game 1. \u201cWe appropriately had fun with it that night, enjoyed it that night. And then the next day, it\u2019s time to move on to the next \u2026 and now it\u2019s all business,\u201d Lakers coach Frank Vogel said Monday. \u201cI don\u2019t think there\u2019s any kind of an eye towards the end of getting home or anything like that. It\u2019s really about staying single-minded in our focus about what needs to happen for us to beat the Miami Heat.\u201d Both teams are scheduled for regular practices Tuesday. It\u2019s definitely a tight squeeze, preparation wise, compared to last year: the 2019 NBA Finals started on May 30, with Golden State clinching its spot in the title series on May 20 and Toronto on May 25. \u201cI tell you, it\u2019s going to be brutalizing for our video staff,\u201d Heat coach Erik Spoelstra said. The Heat, who ousted East No. 1 seed Milwaukee in the second round, are trying to become the second team in the last 18 seasons to beat a pair of No. 1 seeds in the same playoff. Toronto did it last year, first to Milwaukee, then to Golden State. Before that, one would have to go back to 2002 when the Lakers pulled off the feat. \u201cI\u2019m full of emotions,\u201d Heat guard Goran Dragic said. \u201cI\u2019m happy. I\u2019ve been waiting for this for a long time, for 11, 12 years, and finally I\u2019m here. All the credit goes to those guys who are believing it and to my teammates. I\u2019m just happy. I\u2019ve been through a lot in those five years, ups and downs, and I\u2019m just happy to be here and to be part of this big moment. Can\u2019t wait for the finals.\u201d The Heat celebrated into the wee hours of Monday morning before retiring to their rooms for a few hours of sleep. Adebayo said he enjoyed himself \u2014 within reason. \u201cI had a Shirley Temple,\u201d Adebayo said. The bubble has been a grind. By Game 4 or so of this series, the Lakers and Heat will have been at Disney for three months. A few players have family or friends there now, but for the most part they\u2019ve been isolated throughout this process. It was tough mentally. It was tough physically, playing every other day for the most part once the season resumed on July 30. But all the teams have to get through now is one more series. \u201cWe\u2019re super locked in,\u201d Vogel said. \u201cOur group enjoys each other. We\u2019ve been through a lot. Even though we were really assembled this year, not a team that\u2019s been together for multiple years, with everything that we\u2019ve been through our chemistry is strong. And, you know, I think the fact that we enjoy each other away from the basketball court has really helped with the bubble environment and hopefully that will continue for us.\u201d"},{"id":25491,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/boston-celtics-see-bright-future-despite-loss-east-finals","date":"2020-09-29","title":"Celtics see bright future despite loss in East finals","content":" BOSTON (AP) \u2014 Jayson Tatum emerged as a bona fide star, Jaylen Brown showed he can be a consistent presence in the lineup and Kemba Walker helped the Celtics put the failed Kyrie Irving experiment behind them. But following their Eastern Conference finals loss to Miami, it\u2019s clear there is still work to do in Boston after the Celtics squandered their best opportunity yet under coach Brad Stevens to make it to the NBA Finals. Stevens said he heads into the offseason lamenting only the outcome and not the effort by his players during the abnormal season. \u201cMy regret is not what we put in. My regret is not how we prepared or worked or how hard our guys worked or how committed they were to playing and staying together,\u201d he said. \u201cYou look back at those first couple of games (against Miami) and it put us in a tough spot. I just think that ultimately we had our chances and we didn\u2019t take advantage of it enough.\u201d The Celtics returned from the COVID-19-caused hiatus and emerged as one of the hottest teams in the Florida bubble, winning five of their eight seeding games entering the playoffs. They then swept the Philadelphia 76ers in the first round and held off the defending champion Toronto Raptors in seven games to advance to the conference finals \u2014 all without Gordon Hayward, who was sidelined in the opening game of the Philly series with a sprained right ankle. Despite big efforts from Tatum, Brown and Walker, who all averaged 20 or more points per game in the playoffs, Hayward\u2019s absence was felt in the back-to-back losses to open the series against the Heat, as the Celtics struggled to score against Miami\u2019s athletic front line. That combined with uncharacteristic lapses in defense contributed to them being unable to close out games in the 4-2 series loss. But unlike in previous seasons, the issues were situational and don\u2019t seem to be systemic. That\u2019s something to build on for a team expected to remain a contender in the East next season. \u201cWe got to use this fuel to fuel us to come back stronger, better, mentally, physically, emotionally, psychologically, all of it,\u201d Marcus Smart said. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to use it to our advantage to come back. It\u2019s over. We can\u2019t change the past. We can only get ready for the future.\u201d It\u2019s also why Tatum said he doesn\u2019t believe there needs to be wholesale changes. \u201cI believe in this group. I think we were capable. We had more than enough to get the job done. We just let a couple slip away,\u201d he said. \u201cA lot of guys got so much better this year and throughout the season, so much better from last season. So just to see guys continue to grow and get better, it\u2019s a lot of fun. It was fun this year.\u201d"},{"id":25513,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/miami-heat-president-pat-riley-still-fight-75","date":"2020-09-28","title":"Heat's Pat Riley still up for a fight at 75","content":" Three decades ago, which is roughly three lifetimes ago for him, the man heard and saw a disturbance develop on the basketball practice court: Two Knicks were ready to kill each other. Charles Oakley and Anthony Mason, a pair of notable bad asses who were angrier than red ants, had a blowup and now were squaring off, with fists balled. Everything around them stopped cold. And then the two began throwing punches and wrestled each other to the floor. When a few teammates tried to rush and break up the fight, they heard a firm and direct order from the person in charge of preventing the chaos: \u201cLet \u2019em go,\u201d Pat Riley said. Riley was a coach then, he worked in New York, and his hair was still jet black. And those are the only differences with the man between then and now. He still believes in building winners, by any means necessary. He subscribes to toughness, a trait he insists is necessary for players to thrive in the NBA. And at 75, an age where many in Florida are shuffle boarding instead of preparing for an NBA championship, Riley is once again up for a fight. It\u2019s hard to say if the 2019-20 Miami Heat are Riley\u2019s magnum opus; after all, when it comes to traveling deep into the NBA calendar, he has been there and done that, almost too many times to count. But this represents quite the satisfying achievement for the Heat president, to put a team in the championship round without a superstar, to get the chance to stare down LeBron James and the Lakers in the process, and to build this title contender by kicking the idea of tanking in the groin. Maybe the best compliment you can pay Riley right now is to suggest this team reflects the personality of its boss. Which is exactly what Riley had in mind when he pushed enough of the right buttons to make a Heat appearance possible in these NBA Finals . \u201cPat is the man,\u201d said swingman Jimmy Butler, the team\u2019s spiritual leader. \u201cWe got a bunch of dogs on this team, and he\u2019s the big dog.\u201d In their first meeting last summer, when he was weighing the decision to sign with the Heat as a free agent, Butler said Riley won him over in five minutes. That sounds about right. Whether it\u2019s tossing championship rings on the table, or delivering compelling and stirring motivational talks, Riley usually gets his man. But that man must meet The Man\u2019s standards, which, in hindsight, Butler surely has. It\u2019s all turning out splendidly for Riley, who has masterfully rebuilt the Heat, six years after LeBron departed and the Big Three dismantled, without enduring a painful rebuild or having the luxury of a Draft pick higher than No. 10 overall. He\u2019s in a demanding, what-have-you-done-lately job that favors the young and penalizes the careless, yet Riley is neither. A winning attitude permeates the Heat culture that Butler raves about. In the last three offseasons, Riley has conducted a master class on how to do more with less. He signed Butler, drafted Tyler Herro and Bam Adebayo and grabbed undrafted diamonds in the rough in Duncan Robinson and Kendrick Nunn. Before this season\u2019s trade deadline, he got Andre Iguodala and Jae Crowder in exchange for basically three players who weren\u2019t really in the rotation. Butler has revved up the competitive pulse, bringing unapologetic fire and an appetite for taking over games in the moment of truth. Adebayo became an All-Star and just finished bulldozing the Celtics with a stellar Game 6 performance at both ends of the floor, and is just realizing how good he can be, especially defensively. Herro is developing rapidly as a big-time scorer who isn\u2019t afraid to take key shots and brings confidence rarely seen among mid first-round picks. Robinson, one of the NBA\u2019s best shooters, cannot be left unguarded on the perimeter. Nunn was an NBA G League standout who became an All-Rookie First Team pick this season. Iguodala is wise and championship tested, having played a key role during the Warriors\u2019 recent dynasty. Crowder has proven to be a solid 3-point shooter and floor-spacer while bringing an ability to guard multiple positions. \u201cHe didn\u2019t assemble this team for us to play 82 games and go home,\u201d Adebayo said. \u201cThat\u2019s not the reason why he brought Jimmy here, that\u2019s not the reason he drafted me, not the reason he got Andre and Jae \u2026 this is all about preparation on how we can win the championship. Pat wouldn\u2019t have assembled this team unless he knew we had great things ahead of us.\u201d What\u2019s impressive is how Riley managed to erase his mistakes to make this happen; great team-builders always do. He overpaid for James Johnson, Hassan Whiteside, Tyler Johnson and Dion Waiters, yet none are around anymore and the damage has been minimal at best. Even more impressive: Butler will be the Heat\u2019s only big-money player in 2020-21. Everyone else is either on rookie deals or minimal contracts. That means the Heat will be in play to sign A-list free agents, and how many will resist the temptations of South Beach and turn down Riley for the chance to play next to Herro, Adebayo and Butler? The prospects for the Heat dimmed considerably when LeBron took his talents from South Beach and went home to Cleveland. Riley felt betrayed. He told author and former NBA.com writer Ian Thomsen in his book, \u201cThe Soul Of Basketball\u201d, the following: \u201cI had two to three days of tremendous anger. I was absolutely livid, which I expressed to myself and my closest friends. My beautiful plan all of a sudden came crashing down. That team in 10 years could have won five or six championships.\u201d A chill developed between LeBron and Riley. LeBron won a championship in Cleveland, which some might say is worth five more in Miami. Chris Bosh had to retire for health reasons and Dwyane Wade turned gimpy and old. He went back home, to Chicago, then ring-chased with his pal LeBron in Cleveland, before a final reunion with Riley and the Heat. Riley was left to deal with the rubble, but he refused to break the team down and rebuild from scratch. Retreating is not in his basketball DNA. The Heat went through a few reinventions designed to stay respectable. The very next season, in 2014-15, the Heat missed the playoffs but were only one win from advancing to the conference finals the following season and had only had one losing season since. And now, this. Riley was the captain of \u201cShowtime\u201d with the Lakers in the NBA\u2019s golden age of the 1980s. He then brought respectability and grit to the Knicks and took them to Game 7 in the 1994 Finals. In Miami, he grabbed Shaquille O\u2019Neal and paired him with Wade to win the team\u2019s first championship in 2006. After that, he went full-time to the front office and formed the \u201cBig Three\u201d Heat. Counting his playing days with the Lakers, he has reached a Finals in six straight decades. When the Heat began the playoffs in this NBA restart, some in the organization urged Riley not to attend the games in Orlando out of concerns for his age, given the coronavirus. Outside the organization, the thought was, why bother? Miami was a No. 5 seed, with mild expectations of going very far. But Riley isn\u2019t easily intimidated, just like his team. He made the trip up Florida\u2019s Turnpike and became a fixture at Heat games, once again sitting next to his wife, Chris, just as they do at American Airlines Arena. And that\u2019s where he\u2019ll be, starting Wednesday, a senior citizen with a white mane watching calmly and showing no outward emotion after the ball goes up. Inside, however, there is a winner within who will expect his team, against steep odds, to fight the good fight. * * * Shaun Powell has covered the NBA for more than 25 years. You can e-mail him  here , find his archive here   and follow him on  Twitter  . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25529,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/2020-playoffs-numbers-preview-lakers-heat-finals","date":"2020-09-28","title":"Numbers preview: The Finals -- Los Angeles Lakers vs. Miami Heat","content":" The first NBA Finals in a bubble is also the first NBA Finals in which neither team was in the playoffs the season before. It\u2019s LeBron James vs. his old team and Pat Riley vs. his old team. The Los Angeles Lakers have two of the best players in the league and have continued to play some big ball. The Miami Heat have more of an ensemble cast and have played smaller in the postseason. Both teams have had success on both ends of the floor, but offense was the story in the conference finals. The Lakers and Denver Nuggets combined to score 115.3 points per 100 possessions, while the Heat and Boston Celtics combined to score 114.1. Those were the third and fourth most efficient series of the 14 we\u2019ve seen thus far. To win their 17th championship, the Lakers will have to keep up with the Heat\u2019s ball and player movement. To win their fourth, the Heat will have to protect the rim. In both cases, it\u2019s much easier said than done. Here are some statistical notes to get you ready for The Finals, with links to let you dive in and explore more. Game 1 is Wednesday at 9 p.m. ET on ABC .
