Karl Anthony-Towns got to work in Minnesota and his old coach started to mold his new team in New York. After six months without one, it felt so good for some NBA teams to practice again that even Allen Iverson might\u2019ve enjoyed it. \u201cI\u2019ve never seen a layup drill with such intensity,\u201d Atlanta coach Lloyd Pierce said. \u201cWe did a full-court layup drill and the guys were clapping and cheering. You know they haven\u2019t practiced in a long time if they\u2019re excited about layup drills.\u201d The teams that didn\u2019t qualify for the restart of the NBA season at Walt Disney World could begin voluntary workouts Wednesday to start preparing for their next game \u2013 whenever that is. \u201cAs of right now, we don\u2019t know when next season will begin, but there\u2019s obviously a lot of work to be done between now and then,\u201d Tom Thibodeau said after the Knicks practiced. The league allowed those eight clubs (Atlanta, Golden State, New York, Minnesota, Charlotte, Cleveland, Chicago and Detroit) to have voluntary team workouts by creating their own bubbles, where players and staff stay together and are tested daily for the coronavirus. While the other 22 teams had all played at least eight games at Disney, the bottom eight had been restricted to only voluntary individual workouts since the NBA season was suspended on March 11 because of the pandemic. Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse in Cleveland had essentially been vacant since then. For a young team like the Cavaliers, the interruption was a double blow since they had just undergone a coaching change and were playing their best ball of the season under J.B. Bickerstaff, who was promoted following John Beilein\u2019s stunning resignation. Love said it was \u201cparamount\u201d for the team to get together and make up for lost time. \u201cIt gives us some sense of continuity, some sense of togetherness,\u201d said Love, who didn\u2019t want to miss the voluntary workouts. \u201cUnlike those other teams, they were able to get together. Even other teams that didn\u2019t make the playoffs, they still had eight games. They got to play for something. \u201cWe weren\u2019t able to do that. So it\u2019s huge for us to be on the same court, even just seeing each other and spending time with each other and be around one and other.\u201d Under the agreement between the NBA and the National Basketball Players Association, players who planned to take part in the group workouts could continue their individual workouts at team facilities on Sept. 14, at which time they began their daily virus testing. Following two days of quarantine, workouts and scrimmages could begin Wednesday and run through Oct. 6. Stephen Curry and Draymond Green opted not to take part in the workouts, but Golden State coach Steve Kerr said the Warriors expect Klay Thompson on the court this week as he works his way back from a torn ACL in the 2019 NBA Finals. Pierce got the Hawks quickly playing 5 on 5, because they hadn\u2019t in so long. Coaches who didn\u2019t know what to expect were pleasantly surprised by the level of play they saw. \u201cWe know the basketball will get better and better,\u201d said Minnesota coach Ryan Saunders, whose group of 15 players included Towns and D\u2019Angelo Russell. \u201cHonestly, it was a lot better than I expected it to be after a six-month hiatus.\u201d The workouts allowed Clint Capela to finally join the Hawks for practice, having been sidelined by injury following his acquisition from Houston before the shutdown. Players and coaches had been in contact during that time, but not the way they were Wednesday. \u201cWe\u2019ve been texting, calling, Zooming a ton throughout the six months, but there\u2019s nothing like being live, eye to eye, face to face with another person,\u201d Charlotte coach James Borrego said. \u201cSo this time is really valuable for us.\u201d Unfortunately, they don\u2019t know when they\u2019ll be back together once the workouts end. Commissioner Adam Silver said the 2020-21 season may not start until at least January , so it\u2019s unclear when training camps would begin. At least the teams won\u2019t be off the floor until then. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing we can do about what we missed or didn\u2019t get to do,\u201d Pierce said. \u201cWe know how to navigate through what we\u2019ve been given. That\u2019s why the energy was great today. The guys want to maximize this and take advantage of this.\u201d"},{"id":25585,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nba-players-taylor-grand-jury-decision-not-enough","date":"2020-09-23","title":"For NBA players, Breonna Taylor decision 'not enough'","content":" LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. (AP) \u2014 LeBron James sent the word to the Los Angeles Lakers in a group text on Wednesday afternoon, and basketball suddenly seemed irrelevant. A grand jury in Kentucky had finally spoken. And James was letting his team know that NBA players, who have spent months seeking justice for Breonna Taylor, did not get what they wanted. \u201cSomething was done,\u201d Lakers guard Danny Green said, \u201cbut it wasn\u2019t enough.\u201d Wednesday\u2019s decision by the grand jury, which brought no charges against Louisville police for Taylor\u2019s killing and only three counts of wanton endangerment against fired Officer Brett Hankison for shooting into Taylor\u2019s neighbors\u2019 homes, was not unexpected by many NBA players and coaches. They had a sense it wasn\u2019t going to go how they hoped. \u201cI know we\u2019ve been using our platform down here to try to bring about education and a voice in a lot of players on our team, especially also spoken out on justice for Breonna Taylor,\u201d Denver coach Michael Malone said. \u201cWe have not gotten that justice.\u201d Teams came to Walt Disney World to finish the season and crown a champion, and hoping that the platform of the NBA\u2019s restart bubble could help amplify calls for change. Players and coaches have used the NBA spotlight to make statements at a time when the demand for racial equality and an end to police brutality is resonating as loudly as it has in generations. And Taylor\u2019s story \u2013 the tale of a 26-year-old Black woman who was killed March 13 by police in Louisville when they burst into her apartment on a no-knock warrant during a narcotics investigation centered around a suspect who did not live there \u2013 has captivated NBA players. Many have met, virtually, with members of her family to offer support. They say her name in news conferences, wear it on shirts, scrawl it onto their sneakers. \u201cWe have moms. We have sisters, nieces, aunties. And just like men of color have experienced traumatic instances, so have women,\u201d Boston forward Jaylen Brown said. \u201cThat is an example of some things that happen to women in our country. So, we wanted to stand alongside them, but also make it that it\u2019s not just us. I think the future is female, so it\u2019s important to show our sisters that we care. That\u2019s why it\u2019s been important.\u201d Many NBA players and others took to social media to share their thoughts following the news. Even for teams not in the bubble, it mattered. Atlanta coach Lloyd Pierce leads a committee of NBA coaches tasked with finding new ways to use their own platform to create change, and he\u2019s encouraged his own players \u2013 Black and white alike \u2013 to speak out and take action, whether in Atlanta or their own community. Pierce took Wednesday\u2019s news hard. \u201cYeah, there was a grand jury and yeah, they went through the information and yeah, they have facts to support whatever the claims may be,\u201d Pierce said. \u201cBut that doesn\u2019t provide any justice for those that are on the outside, those that feel like the police and law enforcement are there to protect them. \u2026 What currently is happening isn\u2019t good enough.\u201d National Basketball Players Association executive director Michele Roberts went a step further . \u201cSadly, there was no justice today for Breonna Taylor,\u201d Roberts said. \u201cHer killing was the result of a string of callous and careless decisions made with a lack of regard for humanity, ultimately resulting in the death of an innocent and beautiful woman with her entire life ahead of her.\u201d The league shut down for three days last month when a boycott that was started by the Milwaukee Bucks \u2013 in response to the shooting by police of a Black man, Jacob Blake, in Kenosha, Wisconsin \u2013 nearly caused players to end the season because they felt their pleas for change were not being taken seriously enough. And Wednesday\u2019s news was another disappointment for them. \u201cWe feel like we\u2019ve taken a step back, that we haven\u2019t made the progress we were seeking,\u201d Green said. \u201cOur voices aren\u2019t being heard loud enough. But we\u2019re not going to stop. We\u2019re going to continue. We\u2019re going to continue fighting, we\u2019re going to continue to push, we\u2019re going to continue to use our voices.\u201d"},{"id":25566,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/sacramento-kings-gm-mcnair-commits-luke-walton","date":"2020-09-23","title":"New Kings GM Monte McNair commits to Luke Walton as coach","content":" New Sacramento Kings general manager Monte McNair said he is looking forward to working with coach Luke Walton to revive a franchise that has the longest current playoff drought in the NBA. McNair was hired last week after a long tenure as an executive in Houston to replace Vlade Divac. He backed Walton publicly during his introductory news conference Wednesday. \u201cI\u2019ve got to know him the last few days, we\u2019ve had some good conversations,\u201d McNair said. \u201cI\u2019ve heard great things. So far I think we\u2019ve had a great rapport. Luke\u2019s going to be our coach next year. I\u2019m really excited to work with him. I think we\u2019re aligned with our vision and we\u2019re gonna start implementing it.\u201d Walton is the team\u2019s 10th coach since the Kings last made the playoffs in Rick Adelman\u2019s final season in 2005-06. Sacramento went 31-41 in Walton\u2019s first season at the helm. McNair and Walton will work together to end the 14-year playoff drought that is one year off the longest one in NBA history. \u201cI understand the frustrations of all the loyal Kings fans,\u201d McNair said. \u201cI\u2019ve already seen and heard about their passion. I think we\u2019re aligned on that goal. I was fortunate enough to spend the last 13 years at an organization where we were able to build those winning habits, that culture, where year in and year out we expected to be in the playoffs and compete for championships. My goal is to recreate that here. We\u2019re going to be flexible and just be ready whenever that opportunity arises to really improve the team and get us back into that consistent playoff hunt.\u201d McNair inherits a roster that has some intriguing young pieces but has not been good enough to contend in the Western Conference. Point guard De\u2019Aaron Fox is one of the better young players in the league. Marvin Bagley III, the No. 2 overall pick in 2018, showed flashes as a rookie but struggled with injuries this past season that limited him to 13 games. The Kings also have a pair of talented 3-point shooters in Buddy Hield and restricted free agent Bogdan Bogdanovic as some of the pieces to build around. McNair is a Southern California native who spent 13 years working for the Rockets. He has been the assistant general manager since 2018 and also was integral in the team\u2019s analytics department, working closely with the coaching staff on strategy. The Rockets made the playoffs for eight straight seasons with two trips to the Western Conference final and seven 50-win campaigns thanks to a playing style that relied heavily on 3-point shots. \u201cIn Houston, obviously we pushed some things to the extreme,\u201d McNair said. \u201cThat was partly due to our personnel there. There are some tenets that we\u2019ll apply here. We\u2019re definitely going to play fast and space the floor. There\u2019s a lot of versatility and talent on this roster. I think that\u2019ll dictate how we build the team.\u201d Divac was initially hired by the Kings in March 2013 as vice president of basketball operations and franchise operations. He became general manager in August 2015 but was unable to get the Kings back into the playoffs. He traded DeMarcus Cousins to New Orleans in 2017 and made the decision to draft Bagley second overall in 2018, one spot ahead of Luka Doncic."},{"id":25570,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nba-announces-format-2020-draft-combine-official-release","date":"2020-09-23","title":"NBA announces innovative format for Draft Combine 2020","content":"NEW YORK \u2014 The NBA announced today that NBA Draft Combine 2020 has been reformatted to be conducted both in NBA team markets and virtually, taking place in phases beginning Sept. 28 and continuing through early to mid-November. The reimagined Combine will continue to provide NBA teams with player evaluation opportunities during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. \u201cNBA Draft Combine is an essential part of the pre-draft evaluation process,\u201d said Byron Spruell, President, NBA League Operations. \u201cWhile the circumstances surrounding this Combine are unique, we\u2019re excited to creatively deliver a valuable experience for our teams, who have remained flexible through the process, and for prospective draftees who are just beginning their NBA journeys.\u201d  NBA Draft Combine 2020 will give players the opportunity to participate in league and team interviews, both conducted via videoconference from Sept. 28 through Oct. 16. Players will also take part in an individual on-court program consisting of strength and agility testing, anthropometric measurements, shooting drills and a \u201cPro Day\u201d video, all conducted in October at the NBA team facility nearest to a player\u2019s home or interim residence. Medical testing and examinations will be performed by NBA-affiliated physicians in the same market. As part of the event\u2019s innovative format, the NBA will incorporate HomeCourt, a mobile basketball training application that uses advanced machine learning and computer vision, to provide analytics and record the shooting evaluation portion of NBA Combine 2020 and for players to create a unique \u201cPro Day\u201d video. The video, used to showcase a player\u2019s skills, may feature only the individual player (and either a coach or trainer) and can be up to 45 minutes long. HomeCourt is developed by NEX Team, Inc., an NBA strategic partner. Additionally, the NBA has expanded its use of \u201cCombine HQ,\u201d an online tool developed by Fusion Sport in its software platform Smartabase. An interactive online platform, Combine HQ provides NBA teams with a one-stop shop for scouting information gathered during the on-court portions of this year\u2019s Combine. Using Combine HQ, NBA teams and scouts will be able to compare participating players to their peers, past Combine participants and current NBA players, and view detailed shot charts and statistics. NBA Draft 2020 presented by State Farm is scheduled to take place on Wednesday, Nov. 18 and will air on ESPN. The date remains subject to change as circumstances warrant."},{"id":25576,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/brad-stevens-erik-spoelstra-respect","date":"2020-09-23","title":"Opposing coaches Brad Stevens, Erik Spoelstra have healthy respect for one another","content":" At a point in the NBA postseason when teams are trying to bump off each other with the curled lips and sustained vitriol of the Hatfields and the McCoys, the coaches in the Eastern Conference finals sound like those polite gophers of Looney Tunes fame. You know the ones, always saying in their British accents \u201cAfter you,\u201d \u201cNo, you first\u201d and of course \u201cIndubitably!\u201d Having a healthy respect for one\u2019s opponent is one thing, but Miami\u2019s Erik Spoelstra and Boston\u2019s Brad Stevens are somewhere between mutual admiration society and man-crush in the praise and appreciation they lavish on the job each has done with the Heat and the Celtics, respectively. >> Game 4: Wednesday, 8:30 ET (ESPN) While players will dap up and make small talk after games, in the heat of competition we\u2019ll see everything from angry glares to heated words to actual, aggressive physical contact. Those flagrant fouls and ejections aren\u2019t for nothing, after all. But with the coaches, it\u2019s like they\u2019re providing blurbs for the back covers of each other\u2019s autobiographies. It\u2019s enough to make combative Red Auerbach throw up in his hat. Here\u2019s Stevens talking Tuesday about his Miami counterpart, who holds a 2-1 edge in the series that resumes with Game 4 Wednesday. All bouquets, no brickbats toward the guy whose staff and players are standing between Stevens and his team\u2019s goal. \u201c[I\u2019m] learning every day from Miami,\u201d the Celtics coach said. \u201cI think Erik is tremendous on both sides of the ball. I think that the way that they have morphed their team to play around the strengths of [Bam] Adebayo at the elbow and all those guys cutting off of him, and then to be able to play with [Goran] Dragic or [Jimmy] Butler in pick-and-rolls or isolations or get matchups or whatever, is tremendous. \u201cThen on the defensive end, I think the additions of [Jae] Crowder and [Andre] Iguodala gave them a ton more versatility at the trade deadline [and] made everyone else a better defender because it gave them a little bit more help,\u201d Stevens said. \u201cThe schemes that they\u2019ve put in place make it really hard to find a good shot. I think the world of Erik. I think the world of their whole program. I think they\u2019re tremendous. But that\u2019s the fun part of this.\u201d Spoelstra, meanwhile, has gone out of his way \u2014 particularly after the Heat won the first two games \u2014 to tout Boston as a formidable foe and yield to the impact the Celtics, in being coached-up by Stevens, have had in forcing adjustments on the Heat. \u201cLet\u2019s be real about it. We got down because they were playing great,\u201d Spoelstra said about one hole in which Miami found itself. \u201cThis is a very good team we\u2019re playing against. It\u2019s not as if it was just about us. I would love to say that, \u2018Oh, yeah, we were just kind of going through the motions.\u2019 We weren\u2019t. They were putting it to us. They are a very good defensive team and you have be so detailed and purposeful every single possession against them.\u201d There\u2019s a lot to be said about not giving the other team bulletin board material. But this is the other end of the kudos scale. And it\u2019s not some lame attempt to lull the bad guys into complacency. \u201cYou look at the coaches who are left, the four teams,\u201d former coach Jeff Van Gundy, now an ABC\/ESPN analyst, said. \u201cYou can\u2019t have more humility than those four guys. That doesn\u2019t mean they don\u2019t have egos or take great pride in their jobs. \u201cBrad and Eric have only known success. But Michael Malone was let go in Sacramento. Frank [Vogel] was let go in Orlando [and Indiana]. And the other two, I just think they have such a healthy respect for coaches and winning, they just have natural humility.\u201d  It\u2019s not just the four still in the bubble, either. It\u2019s hard to find any real rivalries between NBA coaches these days. Certainly not like in the combustible days of Auerbach, Hubie Brown, Don Nelson or George Karl. You don\u2019t see the Pat Riley vs. Phil Jackson bits of one-upsmanship. Or Jackson vs. Van Gundy (never forget his \u201cBig Chief Triangle\u201d crack). \u201cCoaching is great in the NBA now,\u201d Van Gundy said. \u201cBut I don\u2019t think the egos of the coaches are as big as they once were. I don\u2019t know why. I just see much greater humility now. And knowing how hard it is to win.\u201d Coaches have as much on the line as players. Pride. Ambition. A consuming desire to be the best. They, too, have multi-million dollar contracts at stake and are far more likely to be fired than players. Yet the fraternal air among the coaches is strong, beyond the end-of-game wave toward the opposite end. One theory Van Gundy offered stems from the NBA\u2019s intervention over the past decade or two. In hitting coaches\u2019 and owners\u2019 wallets. \u201cWhen Commissioner [David] Stern started to heavily fine them for the criticism of officiating, it helped to eliminate that,\u201d Van Gundy said. \u201cBecause when Coach A says what he says about officiating, then Coach B thinks he needs to protect his team. Then it starts to get a little bit contentious.\u201d The intended audience were the referees, complaining about calls the other guys got to plant a seed for the next game. But the other guys often fired back. Van Gundy had wondered if the fans-less bubble of the Disney campus restart might lead to some simultaneous bickering and resentment, but he hasn\u2019t seen it. \u201cI thought there might be more hearing what each other is saying, and working the officials at the same time,\u201d he said.  There\u2019s another big reason Spoelstra and Stevens are so respectful of each other. Game recognizes game, right? They are widely regarded as two of the top five or six coaches in the NBA. Spoelstra, 49, has two rings from the four consecutive Finals he went to, steering the LeBron James-Dwyane Wade-Chris Bosh rock band to the championship round each year from 2011 to 2014. Hired as a video coordinator, he spent 13 years in various Heat roles before taking over in 2008-09 for Riley. His .623 postseason winning percentage ranks fourth in NBA history. \u201cErik has had good teams, he\u2019s had championship-level teams and he\u2019s had lottery teams,\u201d Van Gundy said. \u201cI\u2019m not so sure he hasn\u2019t coached his lottery teams every bit as well as he coached his championship teams.\u201d Stevens, 43, hasn\u2019t won any titles yet or reached a Finals. But his work with Boston\u2019s front office in rebuilding the Celtics has been swift. The former Butler University coach went 25-57 in his first pro season, and has had the Celtics in the playoffs all seven years since. Ironically, the job requiring work and rolled-up sleeves that Doc Rivers no longer wanted in Boston in 2013 hasn\u2019t stopped Stevens from reaching the East finals three times. Rivers has failed to get the LA Clippers to the West finals even once. \u201cWith Brad, he came in, I thought he was extremely good from Day 1,\u201d Van Gundy said. \u201c He didn\u2019t have a good team. Since he\u2019s had a good team, he\u2019s done a great job with good teams, too.\u201d As with most coaches, it\u2019s fair to say that the pecking order for what gets them worked up \u2014 in order, their players, the officials, then the other team\u2019s player \u2014 doesn\u2019t leave much bile for the other team\u2019s coach. Said Van Gundy: \u201cYour team plays against the other team. But you really don\u2019t coach against the other coach. \u201cYou\u2019re coaching to try to get your team and your players to do their very best. Obviously, their best is impacted by what the other team does. But I\u2019ve never bought into the idea that \u2018So-and-so outcoached the other coach.\u2019 Teams outplay other teams, and sometimes you\u2019re upset with things you did or didn\u2019t do. But it\u2019s not like this intense head-to-head competition.\u201d  Typically, coaches are judged against whatever other options they didn\u2019t choose out of a timeout or in a clutch moment. Players used, players rested. Shots drawn up, other plays ignored. It rarely comes down to some chess move with which one coach snookered the other. \u201cIt\u2019s so hard to make all the individual choices you have to make as a coach,\u201d Van Gundy said, \u201cyou don\u2019t have a lot of time to think about, is the other guy annoying you?\u201d * * * Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25577,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/chicago-bulls-billy-donovan-report","date":"2020-09-23","title":"Bulls name Billy Donovan coach","content":" CHICAGO (AP) \u2014 Billy Donovan wasn\u2019t on the market for long \u2013 hardly a shocker given he\u2019s won everywhere he\u2019s coached. That he\u2019s headed to Chicago might be a surprise, only because big and bold moves have been few and far between for the team. Then again, these aren\u2019t the same old Bulls. Chicago struck it big Tuesday, hiring Donovan and landing one of the top candidates on the market to lead a rebuilding team with an overhauled front office. The 55-year-old Donovan spent the past five seasons with the Oklahoma City Thunder. He replaces Jim Boylen, who was fired after the Bulls finished 22-43 and were one of the eight teams that didn\u2019t qualify for the NBA\u2019s restart at Walt Disney World. In a statement, Donovan thanked ownership and said he\u2019s looking forward to working with new executive vice president of basketball operations Arturas Karnisovas. \u201cI\u2019m excited to partner with Arturas as we work together on behalf of this historic franchise,\u201d he said. The Bulls came into the season with their sights set on a playoff spot. They were 11th in the Eastern Conference when play was stopped in March and decided they needed new leadership. Chicago hired Karnisovas as executive vice president of basketball operations in April out of Denver\u2019s front office and shifted John Paxson into an advisory role. The Bulls also brought in general manager Marc Eversley to replace the fired Gar Forman, and they let Boylen go last month. Donovan went 243-157 as coach of the Thunder and reached the playoffs each year. He was a finalist for Coach of the Year this season after his team outperformed expectations and pushed the Houston Rockets to seven games in the first round of the playoffs. But with his contract expiring, the Thunder announced two weeks ago he would not return, saying it was a mutual decision. Before his time with the Thunder, Donovan coached for 19 seasons at the University of Florida, winning two NCAA titles. \u201cWe are very pleased to welcome Billy and his family to the Chicago Bulls,\u201d Karnisovas said. \u201cThe success that he has sustained over the course of his coaching career puts him on a different level. We feel his ability to help his players reach their potential, both individually and collectively, will mesh well with our roster. Whether as a player or as a coach, he has won everywhere his career has taken him, and we hope that will continue here in Chicago.\u201d Donovan inherited All-Stars Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook when he was hired before the 2015-16 season. Oklahoma City reached the Western Conference Finals, squandering a 3-1 lead against Golden State. Durant joined the Warriors after that season, shaking the Thunder and their fans. But Oklahoma City remained competitive. Westbrook averaged triple-doubles the next three seasons and was MVP in 2017. The Thunder traded for Paul George and Carmelo Anthony prior to the 2017-18 season in an effort to challenge Golden State. But they\u2019ve lost in the first round four straight times since that run to the conference finals. They came into this season with lower expectations after trading Westbrook to Houston for Chris Paul and sending George to the Los Angeles Clippers for Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Danilo Gallinari. But they went 44-28 and pushed the Rockets to the brink in the playoffs. The Bulls are counting on Donovan to give them a lift after the team missed the postseason for the fourth time in five years. On the court, the Bulls are led by Zach LaVine, who averaged 25.5 points this season, and Lauri Markkanen, who took a step back. The 7-footer from Finland missed 15 games with a pelvic injury and his scoring and rebounding numbers dropped. Chicago hosted the All-Star game but didn\u2019t have a player selected. That hammered home just how far the Bulls have fallen."},{"id":25575,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/lakers-nuggets-game-3-postgame-column","date":"2020-09-23","title":"Resilient Nuggets bounce back with crucial Game 3 win","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 They didn\u2019t wait until they were in dire straights, on the brink of elimination and facing expulsion from the NBA bubble. Nope. Not this time. After fighting off elimination six times in this postseason, the Denver Nuggets opted for an earlier response in the Western Conference finals. The bubble\u2019s most resilient team rebounded from Sunday\u2019s soul-crushing Game 2 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers for an impressive 114-106 Game 3 win Tuesday night at AdventHealth Arena, foiling any notion that this series would end in a sweep. There was some drama, of course, but nothing like that Anthony Davis buzzer-beating 3-pointer Sunday night. This is the Nuggets we\u2019re talking about. Everything about their bubble experience has been filled with in-game dramatics, including Mike Malone\u2019s team being the first in NBA playoff history to rebound from 3-1 deficits to advance multiple times in the same postseason. > Game 4: Lakers vs. Nuggets, Thursday at 9 ET on TNT Jamal Murray clearly does. He had to rescue the Nuggets Tuesday night to secure the win. A 97-77 lead dwindled to 101-98 in the final minutes. The Lakers chewing into that lead behind a furious push by LeBron James, who finished with a 30-point, 10-rebound, 11-assist triple-double. But with the game on the line, Murray kicked it into overdrive. He nailed a 3-pointer with 2:16 to play that pushed a four-point lead back to seven. And closed the door on the Lakers\u2019 rally with another deep 3-pointer with 54 seconds to play to back to double digits. \u201cI think they just kind of picked up their aggressiveness,\u201d Murray said. \u201cI didn\u2019t think I had a good game in total, to be honest with you. I think I didn\u2019t really get everybody organized. Had too many turnovers. Too many live-ball turnovers that led to easy two points. It happened a second time. I thought there were stints in the game where I just could have been a lot better. I can\u2019t have those, like I said, breakdowns for them to come back into the game. Even when they\u2019re playing good defense, I just got to play better. Got to take care of the ball, be shot ready like we all were today, we\u2019ll be fine. I got to have a better game if we want to win.\u201d A team that hasn\u2019t been through what Murray and the Nuggets have the past two seasons might have folded and gone back to their hotel down 3-0. But not these Nuggets. They\u2019ve shown that they are just built different. They don\u2019t recoil at the first sign of pressure. They don\u2019t crumble when things get tight, the way the game did in the fourth quarter. \u201cThe clock starts moving really slow, especially when you have LeBron putting his head down and driving, and Anthony Davis out there,\u201d Nuggets coach Michael Malone said. \u201cBut we know there\u2019s a lot of time left. No lead is safe, especially against a team like that. I\u2019m not sure what they cut it to, whether it\u2019s one or three, but it got to be really close. That\u2019s when I was proud that we gave up our lead, but we didn\u2019t collapse. We withstood their run, their punch. We had the poise to get ourselves out of it. That\u2019s the sign of a team that\u2019s been in a lot of close games and has won a lot of close games in the last three, four years.\u201d How about the last three or four weeks? The Nuggets have already gutted out two Game 7s here in the bubble, knocking off Utah in the first round and upsetting the LA Clippers in the conference semifinals . They\u2019ve done it with a devastating dose of Murray (28 points, 12 assists) and All-NBA center Nikola Jokic (22 points, 12 rebounds) and whomever else spikes from a deep supporting cast on a given night. It was Jerami Grant in Game 3. The veteran forward scored a playoff career-high 26 points and was a factor on both ends, guarding James and Davis. \u201cOh, we\u2019d be down 3-0, that\u2019s the bottom line,\u201d Malone said when asked where the Nuggets would be right now without Grant\u2019s monster night. \u201cJerami was spectacular. Twenty-six points, got to the foul line 12 times, made 10. Had really good defensive possessions guarding some of the best players in the world. \u201cWe knew going in what we were going to get every night from Nikola, Jamal. You always wonder who is going to step up and be that third scorer. For us tonight obviously Jerami came through in a big, big way at both ends of the floor. Proud of Jerami. Great to see him have some success offensively because he\u2019s been working so hard at it. His hard work paid off tonight.\u201d The Nuggets know they let Game 2 slip away. They fought back, much like the Lakers did using a zone defense in the fourth quarter, but got burned on that Davis buzzer-beater. The Lakers didn\u2019t get close enough to rekindle that magic Tuesday night. \u201cDenver came in and played exceptionally well,\u201d James said. \u201cThey played better than us, more aggressive than us through three quarters, 36 minutes, but you know, we\u2019ve got into the penalty in the third quarter with like nine and a half minutes to go and we had some turnovers that led to some easy buckets for them. We had 16 turnovers for 25 points and put them to the line 29 times. It\u2019s not going to be winning ingredients for us if we continue to do that and we knew that, even after Game 2, we talked about that, trying to assure that. Got to be better than that Game 4.\u201d The Nuggets would be wise to save the rest-and-recovery blueprint Malone utilized during Game 3. \u201c(Monday) when we met and we watched the film, I started off by watching the last play of the game,\u201d Malone said. \u201cGet the elephant in the room out of the way. Let\u2019s talk about the play, what happened. When we\u2019re in this situation again, let\u2019s learn from it. Yes, we all take ownership. Let\u2019s learn from it. \u201cAfter that, my goal was when we got done with that film, they saw so many positive clips of us doing the right things, which put us in a position to win. Now we had to do that for more than just a second half. We had to do it for four quarters. Tonight we did it at a high level for three. The fourth quarter we\u2019ll work on our zone offense tomorrow and taking care of the basketball. But very resilient group. I think this group has proven that.\u201d With his team operating at its confident best, they looked every bit the Lakers\u2019 equal. The same way they found another level against the heavily-favored Clippers in the previous round, they\u2019ll need to find and sustain that level to continually trade blows with the Lakers the way they did to win Game 3. Malone, of course, never doubted his resilient crew. \u201cYeah, I had no doubt that we were going to show up tonight,\u201d he said. \u201cThe reason I didn\u2019t have any doubt is because we won six straight elimination games. Everybody always has us packing our bags and leaving, but we\u2019re not ready to go. For some reason we love this bubble. I can\u2019t explain that, but this team loves the bubble.\u201d * * * Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25581,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/lakers-nuggets-game-3-analysis","date":"2020-09-23","title":"Despite dropping Game 3, it's still Lakers' series to lose","content":" The team that\u2019s leading the last six quarters of the Western Conference finals isn\u2019t the team that\u2019s leading the Western Conference finals. The Lakers are just an Anthony Davis Game 2 buzzer-beater from flipping their 2-1 advantage into a 1-2 deficit, and now the search begins in-house to discover why this is the case. They were out-hustled and outplayed through much of Game 3, save for a fourth-quarter flurry triggered by \u201cPlayoff\u201d Rajon Rondo, which briefly put a scare in the Nuggets before Jamal Murray perked up and Denver prevailed 114-106 . There\u2019s perhaps a sense of resignation in Laker World because this won\u2019t be a sweep, yet L.A. still brings Davis and LeBron James, so there\u2019s no trace of panic. This remains LeBron\u2019s series to lose. Yeah, but \u2026 Did the Lakers, after six straight wins, simply ease their foot off the pedal Tuesday? Or is there a simmering of Laker issues that, if not properly addressed, could give the Comeback Nuggets another reason to believe in themselves? Maybe it\u2019s a combination of both. > Game 4: Lakers vs. Nuggets, Thursday at 9 ET on TNT When a team that flaunts a pair of first-team All-NBA members rips through the first two rounds, and then sees their supposed biggest threat in the West \u2014 that would be the Clippers \u2014 get eliminated, then perhaps human nature takes over and a bit of overconfidence seeps in. You couldn\u2019t blame the Lakers for that; happens every year to someone. \u201cWe didn\u2019t come out aggressively or physically,\u201d said Davis. \u201cWe know we have to play from start to finish.\u201d If that\u2019s what they\u2019re guilty of more than anything else, then their problems are resolvable, certainly after the Nuggets just got their attention. But there are a few annoying headaches that will make things harder for the Lakers (if not in this series, then in the NBA Finals should they advance that far). At the very top is Kyle Kuzma. Before the playoffs, coach Frank Vogel said Kuzma \u201cmust be our third-best player.\u201d There are times when Kuzma isn\u2019t the third-best player off the bench. He\u2019s still an enigma wrapped in a riddle, a seasonlong tease, a skilled player who every now and then will escape the fog that suffocates him, but mostly doesn\u2019t. On the other bench Tuesday, the Nuggets got a breakout game from Jerami Grant and saw some glimmer from Monte Morris. Basically, someone other than Murray and Nikola Jokic surfaced for Denver and that\u2019s largely why they won. Meanwhile, Kuzma had a soft 11 points and one rebound in 26 minutes and was mostly invisible. There was one hair-pulling moment when, in the final minutes while the Lakers furiously rallied to come within three points, Kuzma pump-faked a wide-open shot. With the exception of one game in each of the first two rounds \u2014 that\u2019s two games out of 13 now \u2014 Kuzma had what could be classified as an impact. Nothing major, but reasonable. Isn\u2019t he supposed to be a difference-making third-wheel who feasts on open shots and takes advantage of having LeBron and AD command all the attention? Another issue for the Lakers, and this isn\u2019t breaking news here, is their 3-point shooting. In Game 3, they took 26 from deep and made six. Aside from the poor percentage, the Lakers settled too often on lazy 3s. That played right into the Nuggets\u2019 hands. Remember, L.A.\u2019s size was and is to its advantage. When the Lakers refuse to \u201cplay big,\u201d the Nuggets can compete more comfortably with them. Danny Green was supposed to supply that element to this team \u2014 that\u2019s why they gave him a three-year contract last summer \u2014 yet he\u2019s 5-for-17 so far against the Nuggets. If he doesn\u2019t make the shot, Vogel can\u2019t justify keeping him on the floor. Finally, the Lakers may go the entire series without finding a defensive solution for Murray. This was largely expected; Murray is on a major roll in these playoffs and the Jazz and Clippers had no answer for him, either. When his team began to crumble and shiver late in the fourth quarter Tuesday, Murray bailed them out with killer shots to preserve the win. There is something that\u2019s working for the Lakers as a bonus: Vogel\u2019s decision to put Rondo on Jokic for a handful of late possessions. On paper that seems a silly strategy; Jokic is almost a foot taller. But Jokic rarely sets up on the post. He plays high, and therefore right into Rondo\u2019s hands. When Jokic has the ball, Rondo is daring him to dribble, and Jokic was clearly uncomfortable doing so in that situation. He knows Rondo will go for the steal \u2014 Rondo had a pair of steals, albeit off Murray, that nearly stole the game for L.A. Jokic was spooked by that; he didn\u2019t even try to dribble or back Rondo down, and he didn\u2019t score a basket with Rondo guarding him. \u201cHe\u2019s our best activity-communicator, with his gambling and what not,\u201d Vogel said of Rondo. \u201cHe was a huge part of that run.\u201d Finally, the Lakers bamboozled the Nuggets with a 2-3 zone that aided the fourth-quarter comeback. Expect L.A. to revisit this again if necessary, although the Nuggets will surely watch the tape and try to counter with something. \u201cYou\u2019re looking for something to give your team a spark,\u201d explained Vogel, \u201cto change the game. It worked down the stretch but the hole we dug ourselves was too much to overcome.\u201d Before the game, Vogel joked how the Lakers needed to adjust to the high altitude in Denver for this game. Well, that was good for a few yuks. Weirdly, the Lakers then went and appeared out of gas in Orlando. Their issues are fixable. But they might want to get the toolbox out right away, before the plucky Nuggets get drunk on confidence and make a brave attempt to go a shocking two-for-two against L.A. basketball teams. * * * Shaun Powell has covered the NBA for more than 25 years. You can e-mail him  here , find his archive here   and follow him on  Twitter  . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting. "},{"id":25572,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/adam-silver-next-nba-season-will-likely-start-2021","date":"2020-09-22","title":"Adam Silver says next NBA season will likely start in 2021","content":" LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. (AP) \u2014 NBA Commissioner Adam Silver said Tuesday that his \u201cbest guess\u201d is that next season will not start until at least January, plus acknowledged that the later-than-usual schedule could mean top U.S. men\u2019s players miss next summer\u2019s Tokyo Olympics. Silver, a guest in a series of panel discussions on CNN, did not indicate that any decisions are finalized. The league was originally hoping for a Dec. 1 start to next season, then shifted its focus to the chance of a late December start, and now the target has apparently moved again. \u201cI continue to believe that we\u2019re going to be better off getting into January,\u201d Silver said in a discussion with Bob Costas during part of the \u201cCitizen by CNN\u201d event. \u201cThe goal for us next season is to play a standard season \u2026 an 82-game season and playoffs. And further, the goal would be to play games in home arenas in front of fans, but there\u2019s still a lot that we need to learn.\u201d The NBA hasn\u2019t played in arenas filled with fans since March 11, when the league suspended its season because of the coronavirus pandemic. A very small number of fans \u2014 maybe 30 or 40 per game \u2014 have been allowed to watch inside the NBA\u2019s restart bubble at Walt Disney World in recent weeks, all of them family members or close friends of players. Those guests all are tested daily for coronavirus, like everyone else in the bubble. A typical NBA season has a regular season that lasts for nearly six months, followed by about a two-month postseason. If next season is typical \u2014 and there\u2019s no way of knowing that it will be, or even could be \u2014 a January start could mean a June or July regular-season finish, with playoffs concluding in August or September. That could greatly affect Olympic plans. The rescheduled Tokyo Olympics are set to begin July 23 and run through Aug. 8 \u2014 if those games are held. Final qualifying rounds for the 24 teams still bidding for the four remaining spots in the 12-team men\u2019s basketball field would begin in June. \u201cThere are a lot of great U.S. players, and we may be up against a scenario where the top 15 NBA players aren\u2019t competing in the Olympics, but other great American players are competing,\u201d Silver said. \u201cAnd, obviously, there are many NBA players who participate in the Olympics for other countries. That\u2019s something we\u2019re going to have to work through.\u201d USA Basketball has been planning for various possible scenarios in recent months but can\u2019t make any concrete plans until it sees what the next NBA schedule officially looks like. The U.S. roster for the Tokyo Olympics will be 12 players; there were another 34 players competing for other countries at the Rio Olympics as well. Several NBA coaches are also planning to coach in the Tokyo Olympics or in qualifying: San Antonio\u2019s Gregg Popovich will coach USA Basketball and be assisted by Golden State\u2019s Steve Kerr and Atlanta\u2019s Lloyd Pierce; Golden State associate head coach Mike Brown is set to coach Nigeria; Toronto assistant Sergio Scariolo will coach Spain and Raptors head coach Nick Nurse will lead Canada in qualifying and then the Olympics should it qualify. \u201cThese are highly unique and unusual circumstances,\u201d Silver said. \u201cAnd I think just as it is for the Olympic movement, it is for us as well. And we\u2019re just going to have to sort of find a way to meld and mesh those two competing considerations.\u201d The U.S., Nigeria, Australia, Spain, Argentina, Iran, France and host Japan have qualified for the Olympic men\u2019s basketball field already. Among the top international teams still hoping to qualify: Greece (which could have two-time reigning NBA MVP Giannis Antetokounmpo), Serbia (led by Denver\u2019s All-NBA center Nikola Jokic), Lithuania, Russia and the Czech Republic."},{"id":25557,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/romeo-langford-has-season-ending-wrist-surgery","date":"2020-09-22","title":"Celtics' Romeo Langford has season-ending wrist surgery","content":" BOSTON, MA \u2013 Celtics guard Romeo Langford this morning underwent successful surgery to repair the scapholunate ligament in his right wrist. He will miss the remainder of the 2019-20 NBA season. Further updates will be provided as appropriate."},{"id":25622,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/boston-celtics-small-lineup-east-finals-analysis","date":"2020-09-22","title":"Gordon Hayward adds new dimension to Celtics' small-ball lineup","content":" As if we didn\u2019t have enough strategy wrinkles to keep watch for in the Eastern Conference finals , the Boston Celtics got Gordon Hayward back for Game 3 and gave us a look at a small-ball lineup that played just 18 minutes in the regular season . They just didn\u2019t give us a look at it. That lineup \u2013 Kemba Walker, Marcus Smart, Jaylen Brown, Gordon Hayward and Jayson Tatum \u2013 kind of won the game. In an 11-point victory that made it a 2-1 series, the Celtics\u2019 best-five lineup was a plus-13 in its 6:35 of playing time. It\u2019s a small sample size and the last 30 seconds (in which the Celtics outscored the Heat, 6-2) was Miami fouling intentionally. But small sample sizes are what you get in the playoffs and its certainly an intriguing sample for a lineup that could see more time going forward. Every possession counts, even more so in this series, which has been played at the second slowest pace ( 94.4 possessions per team per 48 minutes ) of the 14 series in these playoffs. All three games have been within five points in the last five minutes (though Game 3 was only a \u201cclutch\u201d game for nine seconds). In the postseason overall, nine of Miami\u2019s 12 games and 11 of Boston\u2019s 14 have been within five in the last five. Celtics coach Brad Stevens went to his best-five lineup late in each half, standard practice for super-lineups that include at least one guy off the bench (see the Thunder\u2019s best-five lineup from this season). And it made an immediate impact late in the second quarter when Smart checked in for Daniel Theis as Hayward put the Celtics up four with the second of two free throws. The small lineup is obviously more skilled than one with Theis, Enes Kanter or Grant Williams at center. It\u2019s also quicker. And you can certainly credit the added quickness for what happened in the first 63 seconds after the Celtics went small: Three stops and three fast breaks, pushing that four-point lead to a 10-point cushion: Play 1: Walker chases Tyler Herro around three screens, denies him the catch and pushes him 30 feet from the basket. Jimmy Butler enters the ball to Bam Adebayo at the left elbow. Herro fakes a cross-screen for Butler and slips to the basket, but Walker stays with him. Brown switches an outside hand-off for Butler and takes the ball away, leading to a dunk for Tatum. Play 2: Herro gets Walker off his tail with a dance move in the paint before using a cross-screen from Butler and taking a hand-off from Adebayo. With Walker trailing, Brown probably isn\u2019t aggressive enough in switching out to contest Herro\u2019s left-wing 3. But it\u2019s off the mark and the Heat (especially Goran Dragic in the weak-side corner) are slow to react. This time, Tatum pitches ahead to Brown for a dunk. Play 3: Adebayo flashes to the top of the key and Brown comes from behind to deflect Butler\u2019s entry pass, leading to a third straight fast break. There\u2019s an argument to be made that the Miami offense is defended better with quickness than with (interior) size. In the regular season, the Heat took only 29% of their shots , the league\u2019s fourth lowest rate, in the restricted area. In the playoffs, that number is below 26% . (League-wide, the percentage of shots that have come in the restricted area is down from 33.0% in the regular season to just 27.9% in the playoffs. Utah was the only team that saw a jump.) Of course, Smart is willing to play rim protector in that small lineup if needed \u2026  The Celtics did have some size issues with their small lineups, which included 1:49 of the fourth quarter (after Theis picked up his fifth foul) with Brad Wanamaker in place of either Hayward or Tatum . Maybe Theis contests this Butler spin move if he\u2019s in Tatum\u2019s place (guarding Kelly Olynyk) \u2026  And having both Walker and Wanamaker on the floor gave Butler two bully-ball targets after a switch \u2026  Switching more of Adebayo\u2019s screens (instead of having Theis try to contain and recover) could prevent some of his clean rolls to the rim. He did score on a jump hook over Hayward after a switch early in the fourth quarter, but did the same thing to Theis on the very next possession. Having Adebayo screen for Walker\u2019s man and roll quickly would put the Celtics in more of a scramble situation, which they can mitigate by pressuring the ball as much as possible after the switch to make the initial pass tougher\/higher\/slower. There was more good than bad on that end of the floor when the Celtics played small in Game 3. If you discount Miami\u2019s last two desperation 3-point attempts, the best-five lineup allowed 13 points on 15 defensive possessions. Six of those 13 were a result of the Celtics just not being aware of Duncan Robinson, once in transition and once after an offensive rebound . When the Celtics weren\u2019t turning turnovers into fast breaks (there was another midway through the fourth quarter), they were matchup hunting with the small lineup. They mostly went at Herro, both in the second quarter (with Tatum) and in the fourth (with both Tatum and Walker). One of the biggest shots of the game was a Walker corner 3 after Herro contained an isolation, but lost him off the ball. Having more skill on the floor allows the Celtics more matchup-hunting options. They can isolate with Walker, Tatum or Hayward. They can post-up Smart \u2026  \u2026 and Brown is one of the best fill-in-the-gaps players in the league. If you ignore the last 30 seconds in which the Heat intentionally fouled Smart three times, the Celtics\u2019 best-five lineup scored 20 points on 13 offensive possessions on Saturday. As noted, eight of those points came on four fast breaks. None of those possessions were against the Miami zone. Game 4 on Wednesday ( 8:30 p.m. ET, ESPN ) will provide more wrinkles on both sides of the ball. The Celtics need another win to even the series, and certainly won\u2019t go down without putting their best five guys on the floor. * * * John Schuhmann is a senior stats analyst for NBA.com. The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25609,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/michael-jordan-partners-nascar-team-denny-hamlin-bubba-wallace","date":"2020-09-22","title":"Denny Hamlin, Michael Jordan partner on NASCAR team with driver Bubba Wallace","content":" CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) \u2014 Denny Hamlin is starting his own race car team in partnership with Charlotte Hornets owner Michael Jordan and Bubba Wallace as the driver. Hamlin, a three-time Daytona 500 winner and top contender for this year\u2019s Cup title, made the announcement on social media. The team will be a single-car Toyota entry aligned with Joe Gibbs Racing. \u201cEleven years ago I met Michael Jordan at a then-Charlotte Bobcats game and we became fast friends,\u201d Hamlin wrote. \u201cNot long after, I joined Jordan Brand as their first NASCAR athlete. Our friendship has grown over the years and now we are ready to take it to the next level. \u201cDeciding on the driver was easy \u2014 it had to be Bubba Wallace.\u201d Hamlin said additional details would be forthcoming. Wallace is the only Black driver at NASCAR\u2019s top level. There\u2019s been speculation for months that Hamlin was organizing some sort of ownership group as he expects NASCAR\u2019s business model to become more favorable for team owners when the \u201cNext Gen\u201d car is released in 2022. NASCAR rules prohibit a current driver from owning a team and driving for another, but Hamlin works around the policy with Jordan as the primary owner. Jordan became a partial owner of the Bobcats in 2006 and bought the team outright in 2010, restoring the franchise to its original Hornets name. Hamlin has been a longtime season-ticket holder with courtside seats along the visitors\u2019 bench. Jordan has twice traveled to the NASCAR season finale to watch Hamlin race for the championship. Hamlin, who\u2019s 39, is still seeking his first title. Wallace, who has cobbled together about $18 million in sponsorship deals since he made social equality his platform, already said he\u2019d leave Richard Petty Motorsports at the end of the season. \u201cThis is a unique, once-in-a-lifetime opportunity that I believe is a great fit for me at this point in my career,\u201d Wallace wrote in a social media post coordinated with Hamlin\u2019s. \u201cI am grateful and humbled that they believe in me and I\u2019m super pumped to begin this adventure with them.\u201d"},{"id":25621,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/anthony-davis-lakers-possessions-count","date":"2020-09-22","title":"Anthony Davis knows every Lakers possession crucial this deep into playoffs","content":" Awash in the euphoria of the moment, Anthony Davis looked over to his right when a question regarding the significance of every single possession at this stage of the postseason caught his attention. The Lakers own a 2-0 series lead over the Denver Nuggets in the Western Conference finals and are 9-0 thus far in these playoffs in Games 2 through 5. That doesn\u2019t mean L.A. expects an easy ride the rest of the way against a Denver squad that is the only team in NBA history to have overcome two 3-1 series deficits in the same playoffs. > Game 3: Lakers vs. Nuggets, Tuesday at 9 ET on TNT \u201cTeams are great at this level [which have] made it this far,\u201d Davis said. \u201cPlayers are a lot better than teams you might see in the first round. This guy to my left (LeBron James) is a constant reminder of how we should play, the details, and what it takes to win championships. He constantly preaches that in the timeouts and the film room because he\u2019s been there. We want to be there, too. So, details matter. It\u2019s definitely a possessions game when you get this late in the playoffs.\u201d In his eighth NBA season, Davis is playing in his first conference finals. After perusing the box score on the heels of hitting the game-winner at the buzzer of the Lakers\u2019 105-103 win on Sunday, Davis lamented his team giving Denver 23 extra possessions by way of turnovers that the Nuggets turned into 19 points. Those 23 turnovers marked a postseason high for Los Angeles. \u201cEvery possession does matter,\u201d Davis said. \u201cTwenty-four turnovers [actually 23] tonight. We gave them 24 more possessions. We turned the ball over. We\u2019ve got to get shots at the rim. Things like that matter. Details matter because now teams will make you pay. Teams are already good enough to get this far that they\u2019re going to make plays. If when we have mistakes defensively, breakdowns offensively, not talking, not sprinting back on defense or whatever, and we give them extra points, then we make it a lot harder for us to win a game. So, you never want to give them extra possessions.\u201d The Nuggets, meanwhile, feel optimistic about slowing down the Lakers in transition in Game 2, as that was a main point of emphasis headed into the contest. Los Angeles scored just eight points on fast breaks in Game 2, after reeling off 16 points off the break in Game 1. Coach Michael Malone believes that improvement is what allowed Denver to remain competitive in a game that it trailed by as many as 16 points, before taking a one-point lead with just 20.8 ticks remaining on a Nikola Jokic tip-in. Davis\u2019 game-winning buzzer-beater marked Los Angeles\u2019 first in the postseason since Metta World Peace accomplished the feat in the 2010 NBA Finals, and gave Denver its first 2-0 series deficit under Malone. Since coming into the NBA bubble, the Nuggets are 5-7 on the heels of a loss. \u201cWe did a much better job of taking away their transition,\u201d Malone said. \u201cThat was a huge point of emphasis going in. So, to clean that up allowed us to be in the game. I thought our defense in that second half was tremendous. Our defense will keep us in games. We\u2019re 8-8 in the postseason. In our eight wins, the defense has been great. Defensive transition was tremendous. If we can continue that, we\u2019ll continue to give ourselves a chance.\u201d Denver also increases its prospects if it can find a way to keep Jokic plugging away in the face of all the adversity he\u2019s faced this postseason. In the opening round, Jokic emerged victorious in tough battles against two-time Defensive Player of the year Rudy Gobert, only to work against Ivica Zubac in the conference semifinals against the L.A. Clippers, as well as Sixth Man of the Year Montrezl Harrell. Now, Jokic faces a three-headed monster of Lakers bigs in Davis, Dwight Howard and JaVale McGee. Although he\u2019s held his own against that trio through the first two games, it\u2019s logical to question whether Jokic can keep up the production on both ends for the rest of the series against so much front-court depth. Led by James\u2019 11 boards, the Lakers out-rebounded Denver 44-31 in Game 2. \u201cTo be honest, I don\u2019t think about it,\u201d said Jokic, who scored 12 of his team-high 30 points in the fourth quarter of Game 2. \u201cWhoever is over there, I\u2019m going to try to beat him and try to win the game. It is what it is. Like I said: It\u2019s not just me against them. It\u2019s Nuggets against Lakers. We are underdogs. We need to fight. That\u2019s our only chance.\u201d Malone expressed a similar sentiment headed into Tuesday\u2019s Game 3. Going back to the regular season, the Lakers are 5-1 against the Nuggets and are in the midst of a six-game postseason winning streak. \u201cThe message is we\u2019re down 2-0. Let\u2019s go out and win Game 3,\u201d Malone said. \u201cThat\u2019s been our mindset in the first round, the second round and we\u2019re in the same situation here. Whether you\u2019re down 3-1 or 2-0, obviously, next game is the biggest game for us. Some guys like to win. Some guys hate to lose. I think we\u2019re a group of guys that hates to lose. Even though we\u2019re disappointed, we\u2019re frustrated, we\u2019re angry, we\u2019ll use that motivation to come out and try to take Game 3.\u201d * * * Michael C.
