The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25602,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/giannis-antetokounmpo-rookie-card-1812-million","date":"2020-09-22","title":"Giannis Antetokounmpo rookie card fetches $1.812 million at auction, highest ever for modern-day basketball card","content":" A rare Giannis Antetokounmpo signed rookie card sold for $1.812 million over the weekend, according to TMZ Sports, making it the most valuable basketball card ever. A LeBron James rookie card fetched $1.8 million in July. In addition to the signature, the card features the NBA \u201cLogoman\u201d patch from one of Giannis\u2019 game-worn rookie jerseys. It was graded a MINT 9 by the Beckett Grading Service, which is nearly perfect condition. Despite the high valuation, the Giannis and LeBron cards are dwarfed by the prices of the highest in baseball. A Mike Trout rookie card fetched $3.93 million earlier this year."},{"id":25633,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/qa-brendan-malone-mike-malone","date":"2020-09-21","title":"The Q&A: Brendan Malone on West finals and LeBron vs. MJ debate","content":" The common thread linking Denver Nuggets coach Michael Malone and LeBron James is a 78-year-old grandfatherly retiree who watches the Western Conference finals from afar, who roots hard for one man while taking special interest in the other. Brendan Malone has fingerprints on both, as the father of Michael and the former coach of LeBron James. The elder Malone spent nearly 30 years on NBA benches, most famously at the hip of Chuck Daly during the Detroit Pistons\u2019 championship years of the 1980s and early 90s. He was the inaugural coach of the Toronto Raptors and, for 18 games, was interim coach in Cleveland during LeBron\u2019s second season. Malone was briefly also an assistant with the Sacramento in 2013, the same year his son, Michael, was in his first season coaching the Kings. With all those years comes wisdom, and Brendan Malone is long valued for his honest and refreshing take on the game, for being a confidant to players and coaches, and obviously for his knowledge. He agreed to offer his take on his son\u2019s development, a teenaged LeBron, the Nuggets-Lakers series so far, what made Daly great, his analysis of the LeBron-or-Michael Jordan debate with a surprising answer to that \u2026 and how the Secret Service lost a chance to hire the right man to protect U.S. Presidents. * ** Q: The Nuggets are down 0-2 but we\u2019ve seen this movie before. Are you surprised by how they\u2019ve rebounded throughout the playoffs, fighting back from 3-1 to Utah and the LA Clippers? A: This didn\u2019t happen overnight. This is the maturation of Nikola Jokic and Jamal Murray being a tandem, especially in pick and rolls, and the other players maturing. They were down 3-1 against what many thought was the best team in the NBA and showed some grit. I think Murray scared me in the first few games in the Utah series because he wasn\u2019t looking to shoot and then he became aggressive. If he gets on a roll he\u2019s hard to stop. Very much impressed with the team. They have to become better defensively if they want to go anywhere. Jokic has to become a rim protector. Murray has to become a better perimeter defender. When and if they become good defenders they will be ready to make the next step. What about your son? He has developed along with the team, correct? I\u2019m impressed with Michael\u2019s coaching and his matchups and the way he uses his bench. He\u2019s been there for five years and each year he has become a better coach. He\u2019s controlling his emotions on the sidelines. The team\u2019s success is a reflection of coaching. He knows that when the game\u2019s on the line he has to go to the two-man game with Murray and Jokic on the high pick and roll. It\u2019s very difficult to guard. You\u2019ve got Murray coming off a 3-point shot and if Jokic flashes he\u2019s going to be open for a 3-point shot. He has that figured out. His substitutions are also very good. Did you try to discourage Michael from seeking this profession? Including college and the NBA, you coached in 10 different places, so he had to see the rigors first-hand. It\u2019s not easy on a family. I wanted him to go get married and have kids. But after he graduated from college and I was with the Pistons, he was living with us and got a call from Greg Kampe, the coach at Oakland University in Detroit, to be a volunteer assistant. Michael helped clean the gym to supplement his salary, and sometimes Barry Sanders would come by and they\u2019d play one-on-one. Then he just decided to be a Secret Service agent. Secret Service? That\u2019s a drastically different gig. But he went through basic training in 1995 to get the law enforcement experience needed for the job, right? He took the physical and the mental exams and passed. But before this, he \u2019 d written letters to a lot of head coaches for jobs, and the first coach who answered was Dean Smith, who didn\u2019t offer him anything. Well, Michael was two weeks away from going to the barracks when Pete Gillen, the coach at Providence College, called the house. I thought he wanted to talk to me and Pete said no I want to talk to Michael. He offered Michael a job. Michael didn \u2019 t go to the Secret Service. What kind of Secret Service agent would he have been? (Laughs) Well, he\u2019s a serious guy. I\u2019ll just say he would\u2019ve taken the job very seriously and been someone you wouldn\u2019t want to mess with. The coaching business is all about making connections. After Michael reached a dead end following his short stay as an assistant with the Knicks, another coach gave him a shot, right? That summer Brett Brown and Michael went to Argentina with Basketball Without Borders. Brown was [Spurs coach] Gregg Popovich\u2019s assistant coach with the Spurs. Popovich went down there to visit Manu Ginobili. Popovich, Brown and Michael went out to dinner every night. Popovich got to know Michael. After they came home Popovich called Mike Brown, who just got the job at Cleveland, and said, `You got to hire Michael as your assistant,\u2019 and he did. Mike Brown gave him a lot of responsibility. Your son\u2019s first head coaching job was in Sacramento but it ended badly, with Michael being fired 24 games into his second season. The Kings were a dysfunctional organization with lots of infighting and many believed Michael got a raw deal. I suppose you agree? I was angry. There were people there who had selfish motives. He was the only guy who could coach DeMarcus Cousins, who loved playing for Michael. They had a rapport. Right after Michael got the job he went down to Alabama to visit Cousins, stayed with his family. When they fired him, they mentioned his tempo. Well if he played up-tempo they would \u2019 ve been playing away from Cousins. He was smart enough to know you had to play through Cousins. He wasn \u2019 t a fast-break coach because his best player was his center and didn \u2019 t want the team to be running up the court while this guy was running from the back. I know this much: After seeing him come back 3-1 down twice in the playoffs, the people in Sacramento are saying, \u2018Why did we get rid of Michael M alone? \u2019 What was it like coaching a young LeBron? He was very competitive, an extremely hard worker and very smart even then. He wanted to win every drill. He was still developing, though. I tried to get the ball to him down low and he was not comfortable then. Right now he\u2019s a good low post player, but at that time he wasn\u2019t.  As an assistant with the Pistons, you helped devise a plan to stop Michael Jordan 30 years ago and it was termed \u201cThe Jordan Rules.\u201d What would be \u201cThe LeBron Rules?\u201d I don \u2019 t think any coach in the NBA has come up with that answer yet. He \u2019 s probably the best player in the open court. He \u2019 s so fast and strong going to the basket. He can finish. His best skill is passing. I would take away the drive, give him the 3-pointer, and if he goes to the basket, foul him because he\u2019s not a high percentage free throw shooter. Well, does this mean LeBron is better than Jordan, in your opinion? People ask me who was better: Michael Jordan or LeBron? And I always say you\u2019re asking the wrong question. Who was better, Kobe Bryant or Michael? I would say LeBron is in the conversation of course. There\u2019s a lot of people who would put LeBron ahead of Kobe. And some would put LeBron ahead of Michael. I saw how competitive Michael was. LeBron is competitive but didn\u2019t come up to the level as Michael. And the guy closest to Michael in that sense is Kobe. How would Jordan do in today\u2019s game, with no hand-checking or physical tactics that he endured when going up against Rick Mahorn and Bill Laimbeer? If you gave him that kind of freedom, he could flirt with 50 points every game if he wanted to. At the risk of having a second Malone coach this series, how should the Nuggets handle LeBron and Anthony Davis? Denver doesn\u2019t have a lock-down defender who can guard either one of those guys. What you have to do is play one-on-one and do the best you can. The temptation is to double team Davis and LeBron, but then you leave people open. Davis and LeBron are going to score their points; they may score 60 together. You can\u2019t let Dwight Howard have 13 points as he did in the first game and Kentavious Caldwell-Pope go for 18 or 19. You \u2019 ve got to shut down the other players and if you can do that, I think they can be successful. What did you think of your son\u2019s plea to have family members of the coaches visit at the Disney campus, as the players were allowed? He was hurt that some coaches didn\u2019t back him up and didn\u2019t support his position. Some coaches thought he was out of place. Look, he missed his wife and two girls. It\u2019s not easy being there alone. He rides a bike 20 miles every day in that bubble. He\u2019d go back to his room and felt alone. And what about a week ago when Michael Porter Jr. publicly talked about being more involved in the offense? How did your son react? Porter\u2019s a young man learning how to play. He has to learn to keep everything in the locker room. He says give me the ball. Well, they don \u2019 t run plays. It \u2019 s a free-flow offense. If you can hit Jokic and then cut, Jokic is always going to find you. Porter had to get himself involved in the offense. He hadn \u2019 t learned that yet. I think he \u2019 s learned a lesson. And I credit Michael for not blowing it up. He handled the situation pretty good. What\u2019s the best advice you ever gave your son? The best thing you can do as a coach is to instill confidence in your team. Always be in the foxhole with them when they\u2019re going through bad times. You have to pick them up after they \u2019 re down. Some coaches, and I don \u2019 t want to name names, were always with you when you won but didn \u2019 t want any part of you when you lost. I told Mic hael to be the same coach after a win and loss. The players have to feel you care about them individually.  Does this remind you of anyone? One of the best coaches who ever did that was Chuck Daly. We were walking one time and he said, `I\u2019m not the greatest X-and-O guy but coaching in the NBA is a people person business. You have to get along with your players, the general manager and the press.\u2019 That\u2019s what Chuck did. He subordinated his ego to the team\u2019s ego. That\u2019s what made him a success. What\u2019s the best advice you ever gave LeBron? Actually I would turn that question around. When we were struggling in Cleveland, I asked LeBron for advice. He was young but he knew the game, even then. * * * Shaun Powell has covered the NBA for more than 25 years. You can e-mail him  here , find his archive here   and follow him on  Twitter  . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25632,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/anthony-davis-mamba-shot-lakers-moment","date":"2020-09-21","title":"Anthony Davis hits 'Mamba shot' to create new Lakers moment","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 This was the type of moment that Anthony Davis has been craving, the type of opportunity that led him to the Los Angeles Lakers. Two seconds left with the Lakers trailing by a point in Game 2 of the Western Conference finals . Of course, he wants the ball, wants to take the shot that the great ones take, the one the champions and legends make. Davis drained the \u201cbiggest shot of his career thus far,\u201d his 3-pointer at the buzzer delivering the Lakers a 105-103 win over the Denver Nuggets for a 2-0 lead in this series. Two wins away from that biggest of stages that Davis has been yearning for. > Game 3: Lakers vs. Nuggets, Tuesday at 9 ET on TNT The celebration inside AdventHealth Arena was muted compared to what it might have been in a crowded Staples Center with a raucous home crowd joining in on the pandemonium that left Lakers rookie Talen Horton-Tucker flattened after Davis leaped into a crowd of his teammates after the buzzer sounded. Lakers coach Frank Vogel called it a \u201cMamba Shot.\u201d The Lakers were wearing their \u201cBlack Mamba\u201d uniforms, in honor of the late Kobe Bryant. And Davis channeled his inner-Kobe in that moment. He didn\u2019t hesitate, rising and firing the way the Lakers icon Bryant did so many times during his Hall of Fame career. \u201cWell, we want to embody what Kobe Bryant stood for and honor his memory,\u201d Vogel said after Davis saved the Lakers from squandering a 16-point lead and control of the series . \u201cObviously, there are certain games where we are going to feel it a little bit more than others. When we have that uniform on, I think we feel it more than others. That\u2019s a shot Kobe Bryant would hit. To me, AD coming off just flying to the wing like that, catch-and-shoot with the biggest game on the line of our season, nothing but net, it\u2019s a Mamba shot.\u201d Davis yelled \u201cKobe!\u201d after the shot swished through the net. \u201cI did. You know, I mean, obviously wearing the jerseys. He\u2019s hit countless shots like that to win games, whether it\u2019s in the playoffs, Finals,\u201d Davis said. \u201cBut it was a special one for me. Special one for my teammates. I told \u2018Bron, in L.A., right before the hiatus against the Brooklyn Nets, same spot, slightly different play and I missed a shot. I was upset with myself. And he said, \u2018Man, we gonna live or die with you shooting that shot.\u2019 I got the same opportunity tonight. Ready to make it. \u201cSpecial moment for me. Special moment for the team. Especially in a situation like trying to go up 2-0 against a special team who are great competitors and going to fight for the entire 48 minutes. To do something like that, and with the jersey we wore tonight, it just makes it even more special.\u201d Special is the only way to describe what Davis is doing in the deepest playoff run of his career. He smoked the Nuggets for 37 points in Game 1 and 31 Sunday night. He was the only Lakers player to score in the final five minutes. And his final shot, of course, was the most significant to date in this postseason run for the Lakers. \u201cJust a big-time shot by a big-time player,\u201d Vogel said. \u201c We have a set where we can basically isolate LeBron on a baseline out-of-bounds situation like that. [Rajon] Rondo came up and whispered in my ear about do I want him in there as a passer, and obviously I said heck yes. He made a great read on it, and Anthony flew over to the wing. We talked about missing that shot, similar type of shot, against Brooklyn before the hiatus. Like I said, big-time shot by a big-time player.\u201d Rondo called it the biggest shot of Davis\u2019 career, so far, and Davis agreed. Rondo would know, having played with Davis in New Orleans in the only other significant postseason run of his career (the Pelicans made it to the conference semifinals in 2018). So he understood the magnitude of this moment for Davis, the man who led the Lakers in 13 statistical categories in his first season playing alongside James. He had no doubt Davis would come through. \u201cAD had it going in the second half. He was scoring from inside out, and fortunately came through in the end,\u201d Rondo said. \u201cBut he\u2019s arguably the best scorer in our game. He\u2019s 7 feet tall. He can take bigs off the dribble. He can post smalls. He\u2019s a foul magnet and shoots 99 percent from the line, so he\u2019s definitely a great option to have. And also LeBron, 1A or 1B, it doesn\u2019t matter. You have two guys on the floor who can draw fouls or get a wide-open look. \u201cHe\u2019s always been dominant force for any opponent he\u2019s ever played against. But to see him grow and hit a shot in this type of environment, the Western Conference finals, it doesn\u2019t get any bigger than this. I\u2019m extremely happy for him as a teammate, as a friend. And I love watching him grow.\u201d Growing into moments like the one the Lakers experienced Sunday night is why Davis forced his way out of New Orleans and into the partnership with LeBron. All of the scrutiny and pressure that comes with it, the opportunity to face a moment with a conference final game on the one and the ball in his hands, he wanted that, too. \u201cWhen I left, I just wanted to be able to compete for a championship, and I know that moments like this comes with it,\u201d Davis said. \u201cEspecially being in L.A., the biggest market in basketball. I know the quote, unquote, pressure is going to be on us, going to be on me, especially the first year with everything that happened last year, and then also playing alongside \u2018Bron. I know he gets criticized more than any basketball player ever. \u201cSo just being able to play alongside him, and he kind of helped me with all this quote, unquote, pressure, going out and playing. You guys saw that in Game 5 of the Rockets [series] where he comes to me at the scorer\u2019s table and talks to me when I was struggling. Just going out there and just playing basketball. He makes it a lot easier for me. Just being able to want this type of pressure, this type of spotlight, and go out and play in big games and make big-time plays and big-time shots for my team, it was definitely what I wanted.\u201d James knows the feeling. That same yearning for the big moments has led him on a journey from Cleveland to Miami, back to Cleveland and, ultimately, to these Lakers. He knows what it feels like to take the type of shots Davis nailed Sunday. He knows what it\u2019s like to miss them. He knows that only certain players can deal with that sort of pressure, that sort of responsibility. \u201cAD, he knows how special he is and when he doesn\u2019t, I\u2019ll be the first one to tell him how special he is,\u201d James said. \u201cHe wanted to be here. I\u2019m happy he wanted to be here, because if he didn\u2019t, we wouldn\u2019t have a moment like tonight. That\u2019s what it\u2019s all about. You put that pressure on yourself when you don\u2019t really care what other people think, because what other people think doesn\u2019t really matter because they don\u2019t understand. Anybody can talk from outside, but if they got into the ring or they got into the arena, probably 10 times out of 10, they [expletive] their pants.\u201d Not Davis. Not in that jersey, in that moment he\u2019s been craving for so long, and not with everything riding on the outcome of those final two seconds. Watch the replay again and again and you\u2019ll see the look of certainty on Davis\u2019 face as the ball left his hands and he watches it in flight. \u201cIt was a big shot,\u201d Davis said. \u201cLike I said, we\u2019ll celebrate it for a couple hours. But they could have easily won this game and we have to be ready for Game 3 \u2026the job is definitely not over until we\u2019re able to win the ring. I mean, that\u2019s when it\u2019s over and that\u2019s when the test is completed. * * * Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25641,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nuggets-botch-best-chance-beat-lakers","date":"2020-09-21","title":"Nuggets botch final play, and what could be their best chance","content":" In the words of Nikola Jokic, it was \u201ca little\u201d miscommunication, which is sorta like surveying the Pacific Ocean and comparing it to a hot tub. So with all due respect to Jokic, who was merely being kind to the guilty party Sunday \u2014 teammates must always be supportive of each other \u2014 the mistake by Mason Plumlee was actually massive. And now, in due time, the extent of the damage will determine how much longer the Nuggets remain in the Western Conference finals. Because right now, no thanks to a poor decision by Plumlee in Game 2\u2019s moment of truth, they\u2019re down 2-0 to the Lakers . That\u2019s pushing the envelope, even in terms of their much-applauded comeback-ability. Plumlee is the raw and limited backup center who normally wouldn\u2019t even be on the floor for Denver in the final seconds of a tight game. Yet the Lakers bring size, and so Plumlee was inserted for the final possession: Nuggets up a point, Lakers with the ball, 2.1 seconds on the clock. By now, hours after the fact, you either screamed this at your TV or the replay or both: \u201cWhat is Plumlee doing?\u201d And you wouldn\u2019t be alone. Anybody who ever played the game, and those who haven\u2019t, know you do not, under any circumstances, allow yourself to be stopped by a phantom screen. It\u2019s rather surprising, because Plumlee is a veteran player and \u2026 he went to Duke. But Anthony Davis was free to catch the inbounds pass from Rajon Rondo, square up and release the game-winning 3-pointer. It swished at the buzzer, because Plumlee gave up the chase. Before the inbounds pass, Plumlee was assigned to Davis. He and Jerami Grant, who was guarding LeBron, had a brief conversation about switching if LeBron picked Plumlee. LeBron never moved. There was no screen. And when Davis sprinted away from Plumlee, the trailing Nuggets\u2019 center pursued him for about a step, then stopped and pointed at Davis, as though Grant should suddenly leave LeBron. Remember, there\u2019s only two seconds left. Grant was locked on LeBron, and he\u2019d have to go around LeBron to pickup Davis. So Grant correctly stayed with his man, who would\u2019ve had a clear path for a dunk had Grant switched off. Meanwhile, Plumlee released a guy who was the Lakers\u2019 leading scorer in the second half and finished with 31 points, and two days earlier dropped 37 on Denver. Just a reminder: Plumlee wasn\u2019t even screened. He just \u2026 surrendered and pointed. You can watch and re-watch this play a million times and still come away with the same head-scratching reaction. (Also curious: After Davis\u2019 shot swished, Rondo merely walked toward the ensuing chaos like nothing happened). Making matters more depressing for Denver, it was the lone second-half lapse by a Nuggets\u2019 team that was far better prepared defensively than in the previous six quarters (including the four in Game 1). Denver gave up just 22 points in the third and 23 in the fourth and that allowed the Nuggets to rally hard and assume the lead on a tip-in followed by a 3-pointer from Jokic (he and Davis combined to score the last 22 points in the game). They had unsolved the Lakers\u2019 riddle. \u201cIt\u2019s not easy to figure them out,\u201d Jokic said. \u201cWe can just make them uncomfortable. They\u2019re really talented, they\u2019re going to find solutions. They have two really good, really good, really good players. We just need to stay on top and just make it uncomfortable.\u201d Nuggets coach Michael Malone also reached deep down his bench and inserted PJ Dozier, a second-year sub who hadn\u2019t played many meaningful minutes in the playoffs, for the second half. Dozier did miss four free throws in the fourth quarter Sunday, but he had energy and wasn\u2019t afraid of the moment, to the point where he became a problem for L.A. As a vote of confidence from the coach, Dozier was on the floor instead of Michael Porter Jr. for the final play, and slammed the ball in frustration after Davis\u2019 shot fell through. The inspiring lift from Dozier, the late take-charge by Jokic, the comeback \u2014 once again \u2014 by the Nuggets in these playoffs, all of that for naught because of how they finished up Game 2. \u201cWe had it and kind of lost it in the end,\u201d Jokic said. \u201cWe put effort in it, put fight in it. We played well most of the game. We\u2019re going to keep our heads up and on to the next one.\u201d That remains to be seen. For sure, the Nuggets are not your head-hanging team. They refused to give up against Utah or the Clippers \u2014 maybe you heard? They were flicked aside rather easily by the Lakers in this series opener and now they must elevate themselves out of another hole. They will hear how you cannot keep falling behind and fighting back. They\u2019ll also learn that LeBron is 22-0 lifetime whenever his team has a 2-0 lead in a best-of-seven series. They\u2019ll keep chanting the encouraging words of Malone, who stayed with the glass-half-full approach and said: \u201cWe were in the game and they had to rely on a great play by a great player to beat us.\u201d Well, sure, that is correct. But that great player was able to catch a pass, aim and shoot because Mason Plumlee suffered from brain lock. Maybe Anthony Davis makes that shot anyway. But in a best-case scenario for Denver, he doesn\u2019t, and this series is tied. \u201cIt happened, you know,\u201d said Jokic. \u201cIt happened.\u201d * * * Shaun Powell has covered the NBA for more than 25 years. You can e-mail him  here , find his archive here   and follow him on  Twitter  . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25608,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/horry-scale-anthony-davis-lakers-nuggets-game-3","date":"2020-09-21","title":"Horry Scale: Anthony Davis secures Lakers 2-0 lead over Nuggets","content":" A reminder on The Horry Scale: It breaks down a game-winning buzzer-beater (GWBB) in the categories of difficulty, game situation (was the team tied or behind at the time?), importance (playoff game or garden-variety night in November?) and celebration. Then we give it an overall grade on a scale of 1-5 Robert Horrys, named for the patron saint of last-second answered prayers. * * * The Lakers looked like they were running away with Game 2 , and then the Nuggets did their comeback thing. And then they took the lead. Trailing 1-0, a win would even the Western Conference finals, allowing these upstart Nuggets to envision a myth-destroying NBA Finals appearance over one of the league\u2019s most storied franchises. But Jamal Murray\u2019s block left 2.1 seconds on the clock for L.A. And then, the inbounds. The bucket. The mayhem. Davis became only the seventh Lakers player to win one at a playoff buzzer. And the first since Metta World Peace during the 2010 Western Conference finals vs. Phoenix. DIFFICULTY: Not much time to work with, and everyone admitted the play was intended for LeBron. At the inbounds whistle, Davis broke from the right elbow on a curve toward the left wing. Rondo, with LeBron doubled, bounced a pass to meet Davis at the spot. He picked up the ball into his shooting motion and that. was. a. swish. Jokic was flying by on the closeout, but didn\u2019t impact the shot. >  Game 3: Lakers vs. Nuggets (Tuesday at 9 ET on TNT) GAME SITUATION: The Nuggets ripped off another one of their monster comebacks, this one capped by 11 \u2014 yes, 11 \u2014 straight points from Nikola Jokic. The last two came on a bullyball hook with 20.8 seconds left, as Jokic just backed Davis all the way to the cup before putting the Nuggets ahead, 103-102. Alex Caruso missed a clean 3-pointer with 6.9 seconds left, but Danny Green grabbed the rebound, only for Jamal Murray to swat his shot attempt out of bounds. That set up the decisive inbounds. CELEBRATION: The bench started flying upcourt, and Davis met them near the halfcourt sideline in a flying shoulder bump. Talen Horton-Tucker was unfortunately on the receiving end, and wiped out completely as everyone else celebrated. Fun times. GRADE: Denver led for precious little of the second half. Completing the comeback would have driven Denver\u2019s confidence in this series through the roof. Instead, they\u2019re in a 2-0 hole and Anthony Davis has embedded himself in every Lakers fan\u2019s heart. The shot wasn\u2019t complicated, but neither was the result. 5 Horrys . "},{"id":25600,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/meyers-leonard-out-heat-rotation","date":"2020-09-20","title":"Meyers Leonard, once a starter, now out of Heat's rotation","content":" LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  \u2014 Meyers Leonard was bent forward at the waist, standing a few feet away from Miami coach Erik Spoelstra on the Heat sideline, screaming with every bit of the volume that his deep and booming voice can generate. This is his role right now for the Heat. His only role. Leonard is in a tough spot these days; a full-time starter during the regular season, he is now out of the rotation as the Heat have made their run to the Eastern Conference finals . It is a bitter pill for him to swallow \u2014 yet to his credit, he hasn\u2019t acted the least bit bitter about his current reality. > Game 4: Wednesday, 8:30 p.m. ET on ESPN \u201cMy team knows this, and our coaching staff knows this,\u201d Leonard told The Associated Press . \u201cI would do anything to be out there. And I\u2019d be lying if I said that I\u2019m not competitive as hell. I wish I was impacting the game on the floor. I\u2019m not, but as a person and as a player, I want what\u2019s best for everybody.\u201d So for now, the 7-foot, 260-pound, chiseled center is the tallest, strongest and best-paid assistant coach in these playoffs. He calls out what he\u2019s seeing on every possession, pulls aside teammates for quick one-on-one chats when necessary, and on off days he\u2019s getting his on-court work in just in case he\u2019s needed to play. Leonard has started 49 of his 51 appearances with the Heat this season, more starts than he made in his seven seasons with Portland combined. But in the playoffs, he\u2019s logged a total of nine minutes, all in one appearance. \u201cMeyers is one of the most special people I\u2019ve ever had the opportunity to coach and to be around,\u201d Spoelstra said. \u201cHe is just an incredible human being and teammate. He has all our hearts. We will do anything for him because he is so pure.\u201d Leonard, more than anything else, got unlucky at the worst possible time. He badly sprained his left ankle in early February and wasn\u2019t anywhere near being ready to return to the lineup when the NBA season was suspended March 11 because of the coronavirus pandemic. And then when team facilities shut down as a precaution, Leonard\u2019s rehab process had to be amended as well.  That was the first issue. The second was Miami became a different team a few days after he got hurt, pulling off a trade to bring Andre Iguodala, Jae Crowder and Solomon Hill to the Heat. Crowder has become a starter, and Spoelstra told Leonard before Miami resumed play in the NBA\u2019s restart bubble that he was taking the rotation in a different direction. It was tough on Leonard mentally. He was struggling when he got to the bubble because of his ankle, then spent days wrestling about whether he should stand for the national anthem or kneel with his teammates, and on top of all that he essentially lost his job as well. \u201cThere\u2019s just two things that I won\u2019t ever let be questioned and that\u2019s character and work ethic,\u201d Leonard said. \u201cEvery day when I walk through the door, I\u2019m going to be a great guy, a great teammate. It\u2019s not fake. So I\u2019m trying to make my impact now from the sideline.\u201d There are a few starters who aren\u2019t in the same roles that they were for the four teams remaining in this NBA season. Avery Bradley opted out of joining the Los Angeles Lakers in the bubble. Will Barton \u2014 who led Denver in minutes per game this season \u2014 has a knee injury and has missed the Nuggets\u2019 entire postseason run. Gordon Hayward has missed much of Boston\u2019s playoff stint while recovering from a sprained ankle. Heat rookie Kendrick Nunn, a starter all season, is in Miami\u2019s second unit now. Leonard saw the Heat change, and his role change with it. He didn\u2019t sulk, lash out or complain. \u201cIt\u2019s not easy, being in this kind of situation, going through the injury he went through and having the hiatus where he didn\u2019t get the full opportunity to rehab it,\u201d Spoelstra said. \u201cBut he\u2019s making the most of it, and if he gets his opportunity, he will be ready.\u201d Leonard also sees the reason why he should be helping the Heat however he can right now. He\u2019s never been this close to an NBA championship; the Heat lead the Celtics 2-1 in the East finals, with Game 4 on Wednesday night. He\u2019ll be ready to scream some more then, too. \u201cI am, in the best way possible, the most jealous of watching our team\u2019s success,\u201d Leonard said. \u201cI literally said this to my wife the other night. I said, \u2018Elle, we are six wins away from a ring.\u2019 That is so damn special.\u201d"},{"id":25623,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/film-study-celtics-heat-game-3-rim-protection","date":"2020-09-20","title":"Film Study: How Celtics attacked the rim in Game 3 vs. Heat","content":" Three games into the Eastern Conference finals , the most memorable play of the series (no matter how you rank it historically) remains Bam Adebayo\u2019s incredible block on Jayson Tatum\u2019s drive in overtime of Game 1. That play is why this series is 2-1 in favor of the Miami Heat instead of the Boston Celtics after Boston\u2019s 117-106 victory on Saturday. The difference in Game 3, the reason why the Celtics aren\u2019t down 3-0, was their 60-36 advantage in points in the paint. The league is shooting more 3-pointers every season (and more in these playoffs than it did in the regular season), but shots in the restricted area remain the most valuable on the floor. And the Celtics got there early and often to make this series interesting. The Celtics 60 points in the paint were 10 more than they\u2019d scored in any of their previous 13 playoff games and tied for the second most the Heat have allowed in regulation all season. Critical in that attack, especially with that Game 1 block in mind, is that Adebayo was nowhere near the rim for the vast majority of the Celtics\u2019 21 baskets in the restricted area ( video ). That block in Game 1 was spectacular, but Adebayo didn\u2019t grade as an elite a rim protector in the regular season. Opponents shot 58.9% at the rim when he was there to protect it, a mark that ranked 27th among 79 players who defended at least 4.5 attempts at the rim per game. That 58.9% was the best mark on the Heat , but for a starting big man, Adebayo didn\u2019t protect the rim all that often. The 5.0 shots that he defended at the rim per 36 minutes on the floor ranked 62nd among 246 players who played at least 1,000 minutes this season. (For context, Celtics center Daniel Theis ranked ninth, defending 8.7 shots at the rim per 36.) The low number is partly about the Heat preventing those shots in general. They ranked fourth in the (lowest) percentage of their opponents\u2019 shots that came in the restricted area (29.6%). It\u2019s partly because Adebayo played more than half (56%) of his minutes alongside another big (Meyers Leonard or Kelly Olynyk). And it\u2019s partly because Adebayo switched a lot of screens so that he could shut down opposing guards. The switching has had its benefits. According to Synergy play-type tracking, the Heat ranked third in points allowed per possession on isolations (0.82) in the regular season, with Adebayo defending the fifth most isolation possessions in the league (108). In the playoffs, opponents have scored just 0.64 points per possession on 33 isolations against the Heat\u2019s center. In Game 1, the Celtics isolated against Adebayo *seven times, and the results were not good. They scored just three points on those seven isolations in an otherwise efficient offensive game. In Game 2, they scored five points on *four isolations against him. * These are different counts than those from Synergy above. They include isos that don\u2019t end a possession. On Saturday, the Celtics only tried playing one-on-one against Adebayo twice. Tatum drew a non-shooting foul on Adebayo early in the third quarter and then committed an offensive foul early in the fourth. So it seems that, since Game 1, the Celtics have learned not to attack one particular defender. But they spent most of Game 3 attacking others, and Adebayo generally wasn\u2019t in position to help. Duncan Robinson hurt the Celtics in Game 2, shooting 6-for-12 from 3-point range in Miami\u2019s five-point win. He was 4-for-8 from beyond the arc in Game 3, but the Celtics got a lot of those points back by targeting Robinson on the other end of the floor. Here are some examples of them scoring against Robinson both off the dribble and in the post: Play 1: On the Celtics\u2019 third possession of the game, Tatum gets a screen from Daniel Theis and Adebayo stops his drive. He kicks the ball out to Jaylen Brown, who attacks Robinson off the dribble. Adebayo is in position to help, but just swipes at the ball and retreats to Tatum in the strong-side corner. Play 2: Marcus Smart takes a hand-off from Tatum and gets a screen from Theis that Adebayo switches. Smart gets the ball back to Tatum on the left wing and he drives baseline. Because of the switch, it\u2019s Jimmy Butler and not Adebayo protecting the rim. Play 3: Brown contests a Robinson 3-pointer, leaks out, and establishes early position on Robinson under the basket. Tatum gets him the ball and he converts an and-one before Adebayo can get there. Play 4: Adebayo switches another Smart-Theis screen and Tatum again attacks Robinson along the left baseline. Robinson cuts off the drive, but Tatum turns it into a post-up and draws a foul on a drop step with Adebayo remaining on the perimeter. Play 5: With Adebayo off the floor, the Celtics run their double-drag screen for Kemba Walker and the Heat switch both screens, putting Robinson on Smart. He takes Robinson into the post and gets another and-one on a turn into the lane. Play 6: With Adebayo still off the floor, Robinson switches a hand-off from Smart to Walker, who initially gives up the ball. But Tatum gets it right back to him and Walker easily beats Robinson off the dribble. Robinson didn\u2019t get burned every time the Heat went after him \u2013 he actually blocked Tatum on the first possession of the third quarter \u2013 but the Celtics will continue to challenge him defensively. In addition to getting layups, they\u2019re getting fouls ( he has 10 in 77 minutes ), which can take away one of Miami\u2019s weapons on the other end of the floor. Four of the Celtics\u2019 21 restricted area buckets (including the last two above) came with Adebayo off the floor , and another five came on fast breaks. But the other 12, including each of the Celtics eight restricted-area buckets in the first quarter, came in the half-court with Adebayo on the floor. And on only two of those 12 \u2013 a Brown cut against the Heat\u2019s 2-3 zone where Jae Crowder wasn\u2019t guarding anybody and a Smart drive that he didn\u2019t contest \u2013 was Adebayo in position to protect the rim. Here are some more Boston layups that Adebayo couldn\u2019t get to: Play 1: The Celtics ran the same play \u2013 Smart taking a hand-off from Walker and using a screen from Brown \u2013 on their first two possessions of the game. Both times, Adebayo was guarding Theis, who was stationed in the right corner. On the first possession, Smart beat Crowder off the dribble for an and-one . Here, he hits Brown rolling to the rim, with Goran Dragic helping off of Walker instead of Adebayo helping off Theis. Play 2: Walker brings the ball up the left side of the floor in transition. Adebayo is around, but doesn\u2019t get all the way back to wall off the paint and just swipes at the ball when Walker beats Crowder off the dribble. Play 3: Robinson and Dragic don\u2019t switch an exchange between the Celtics\u2019 two guards, but Adebayo switches Theis\u2019 screen for Walker. Crowder alertly switches onto Theis when he dives into the paint and Butler stops Brown\u2019s first drive. But when Brown spins away from a Robinson switch and drives again, Crowder steps up and, with Adebayo still outside the paint, Theis is able to tip-in the miss. Play 4: Adebayo again switches a Walker-Theis screen, Walker again quickly gets rid of the ball, and Crowder again leaves his man to get Dragic off of Theis. Robinson forces a tough shot from Smart, but Theis again gets position for a put-back. Play 5: With Olynyk on the floor and guarding Theis, Adebayo has Brown in the right corner. Walker gets Brown the ball, but he knows there\u2019s a better matchup elsewhere. Tatum backs down Tyler Herro and gets an easy layup with Adebayo watching from a few feet away. Some of this stuff can be cleaned up with better effort from the Heat defense, which will have three days to soak this one up and build up the requisite energy and focus needed for Game 4 on Wednesday ( 8:30 p.m. ET, ESPN ). \u201cLacking communication,\u201d Adebayo said of his team\u2019s performance in Game 3. \u201cThis is a series where you have to guard your yard. Sixty points in the paint is not guarding our yard.\u201d But the Heat might also be better off if Adebayo didn\u2019t switch so often. It\u2019s great that he can guard \u201cone through five\u201d and a lot of perimeter players in this league have learned the hard way that he can shut anybody down in isolation. But his ability (and eagerness) to switch onto guards can put the Heat in bad situations elsewhere on the floor, and it seems that the Celtics have figured that out. If Adebayo is on the perimeter, they can attack the Heat\u2019s weaker defenders, and he won\u2019t be at the rim to protect it. \u201cWe just got to stay in front of our man,\u201d Butler said about the Celtics\u2019 60 points in the paint on Saturday. \u201cSimple as that. I think we put too much on Bam to always be there, and he can\u2019t save us every single time. He\u2019s great at help defense and he\u2019s great on the ball but he already does enough for us. You can\u2019t just get beat and expect for Bam to come and save you every time.\u201d Theis is 4-for-24 from 3-point range in the playoffs. If he\u2019s stationed on the perimeter, Adebayo (if he\u2019s actually guarding Theis) can sag off and be in better position to protect the rim. If Theis is stationed inside, the paint will be crowded and it will be more difficult for the Celtics\u2019 perimeter players to drive. Choosing not to switch means choosing between a softer (drop) coverage or an aggressive (blitz) one on pick-and-rolls. Dropping back means allowing the league\u2019s best pull-up jump shooting team to shoot pull-up jumpers. Blitzing means leaving yourself open to 4-on-3 situations behind the pick-and-roll. The Heat generally blitz when Olynyk is playing center and Walker has handled double-teams well, but Adebayo would be quicker to recover back to his man than Olynyk is. Playing zone is the easiest way to keep Adebayo closer to the basket. But the two zone scores noted above were part of a third quarter where Boston scored 13 points on seven zone possessions, easily their best stretch against it in the series. Through three games, the Celtics have still been less efficient against the zone (1.05 points per possession) than they\u2019ve been otherwise (1.15). It will return, but maybe not for as much as we saw in Game 2 (27 second-half possessions). No matter what defense they\u2019re playing against, the Celtics saw the benefits of being aggressive in Game 3. \u201cI think we should play like that all the time,\u201d Tatum said, \u201clike we\u2019re fighting for our lives. And we realize that.\u201d They\u2019re going to keep attacking the rim. The question is whether Bam Adebayo will be there to protect it. * * * John Schuhmann is a senior stats analyst for NBA.com. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25631,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/3-takeaways-heat-celtics-game-3","date":"2020-09-20","title":"3 takeaways from Celtics crucial Game 3 win over Heat","content":" Three takeaways from the Boston Celtics\u2019 117-106 victory over the Miami Heat Saturday in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals: OK, so the Celtics beat the Heat. But the real winners were the NBA and most of its fans, when you stop to consider the alternative. Imagine this series being 3-0 in favor of Miami, with everyone waiting through the first scheduled extended break of this postseason. The games have been coming fast compared to a normal, non-bubble year, every other day. But with the Eastern Conference finals a couple games out in front of the West edition, the NBA opted to push Game 4 of this series out to Wednesday. Down 3-0 \u2014 from which no NBA team in playoff history has survived \u2014 the Celtics would have been waiting in vain for a reprieve from the governor. So would the rest of us. Now we\u2019ve got a series again. Better still, the Celtics have themselves a series again. Boston seemed on the verge of a death spiral after Game 2, adding acrimony in their locker room to their struggles on the court. The audible squabbling after that loss from Marcus Smart and mates, leading to the hastily called meeting by coach Brad Stevens with the team\u2019s key players put Boston, already in a must-win predicament, in a must-buck up situation as well. \u201cI told the team this yesterday \u2026 like, this result didn\u2019t really matter to me,\u201d Stevens said. \u201cIt was more about: What are we going to show ourselves to be?  And I thought that we are a really special group.\u201d Said Jaylen Brown, who scored a team-high 26 points: \u201cTo be honest, I didn\u2019t get much sleep the last 48 hours. I was so antsy to get back and play basketball. I don\u2019t think the last two games exemplify what this team is about. So, I couldn\u2019t wait to come out and be the best version of myself and try to add to a win.\u201d The Celtics, rather than coughing up leads as they had in the first two games, never let the Heat catch or pass them this time. That Miami zone that so stymied them in the second half of Game 2? Boston attacked it this time, not only putting to use Gordon Hayward in his return from a sprained ankle, but also focusing more aggressively on the paint (60-36 scoring edge from there). The Celtics also had the rebounding advantage and held Miami below 40% shooting. \u201cJust about honing in, focusing,\u201d Brown said. \u201cThere\u2019s some great guys in that locker room. A lot of emotion, a lot of passion. But we\u2019re a family. We are here for each other at the end of the day. So we exemplified that when we came out together. We stayed together during some tough moments.\u201d Miami coach Erik Spoelstra had as many things to be displeased about as the Celtics had to be pleased. With three extra days to ponder that. \u201cI want our guys thinking about this,\u201d Spoelstra said. Here are a couple of things: The Heat can head into Game 4 remembering that a team (Milwaukee) that started 10-1 in the playoffs last season, like them, still found itself sitting at home by the 2019 Finals. The Celtics can recall that a team (Toronto) that started 0-2 in the 2019 East finals still found a way to roar back and sweep the next four games. The stats weren\u2019t much: six points on 2-for-7 shooting, with five rebounds, four assists, three steals and a plus-1 rating in nearly 31 minutes off the bench. But Gordon Hayward was back from his sprained right ankle, the Celtics were delighted to have him and his impact was felt all night. \u201cHe is a stabilizing force for our team,\u201d Stevens said. \u201cHe just can make the right play and make a play for somebody else at the right time. And he hit the big 3 as they were making a run, so I think he makes us better, that\u2019s for sure.\u201d Boston wasn\u2019t just better Saturday, it was playoffs-throwback better. Brown, Jayson Tatum, Kemba Walker and Smart each scored 20 or more points \u2013 the first time four Celtics did that in a game since May 15, 1986. That night, five Celtics (Larry Bird, Kevin McHale, Robert Parish, Dennis Johnson, Danny Ainge) got 20 or more in a victory over Milwaukee. What did Hayward have to do with this breakout? Tatum counted the ways: \u201cJust his decision-making, his ability to make plays for others and for himself,\u201d the young Celtics forward said. \u201cIt just opens up the floor so much more. They\u2019ve got to respect him. So, it\u2019s just having a bunch of guys out there you really can\u2019t hop off of, because everybody can shoot, knock down shots and make plays.\u201d Stevens admitted there were moments when Hayward was gassed, but he kept him on the court anyway, to fast-track the return of his stamina. The versatile wing had not played in a month since his injury in Boston\u2019s playoff opener against Philadelphia. But now he has three full days to rest and get a little practice time to aid his rhythm. The Heat has fallen into a bad habit of spotting the Celtics leads in each game of the series. Not just a point or two in the early going but substantial holes, dug quickly and deeply, demanding no small effort when the Miami players and coaches get around to digging out. Or in Saturday\u2019s case, not. \u2014 In Game 1, Miami trailed by nine after just five minutes and by 13 with 4:18 left in the first quarter. They were down 14 early in the fourth, before clawing back to force the overtime they needed to win. \u2014 In Game 2, the Heat fell behind by 17 points in the second quarter. It was elevator-shaft stuff, plummeting from a two-point deficit to 58-41 in a span of barely seven minutes. From there, Jimmy Butler, Bam Adebayo and the rest hitched up their shorts, outworking and outscoring Boston 65-43. It wasn\u2019t easy. \u2014 And in Game 3 Saturday, Miami found itself down by seven points in the first 4:01. This time, there was no coming back. This was a wire-to-wire loss, down early, down by as much as 20, down at the end. The Heat\u2019s 21-7 run deep into the final quarter would have been more exciting if they hadn\u2019t begun that stretch in a 19-point hole. So 109-104 was as close as they got. \u201cIt gets old, playing from behind, consistently,\u201d Butler said afterward. \u201cWe should stop put ourselves in that position.\u201d Should? More like must. \u201cWe got to start the game how we start the fourth,\u201d Adebayo said. \u201cI feel like we\u2019re not the type of team where we can go through the motions and try and figure out everything in the first half, and then in the third or fourth, we just try to turn it on. \u201cI guess they got tired of us being down 13 and coming back and winning.\u201d Resiliency is a great thing, in games as much as in series. But you\u2019d rather not put yourself in the position to test it. Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . So, in familiar territory once again down 1-0 to the Los Angeles Lakers, Denver Nuggets coach Michael Malone quickly identified what hurt his squad most Friday in a 126-114 Game 1 loss . It was even a primary concern going into the series. >> Game 2: Sunday, 7:30 ET (TNT) \u201cI think it\u2019s obvious for anybody that watched the game is just getting back [in transition],\u201d Malone said. \u201cThey had 35 transition points. As I told our players this morning when we watched the film, \u2018I told you about this. We talked about them being the No. 1 running team in the league. We talked about the pace at which they played with and that is off makes, that\u2019s off misses, that\u2019s off turnovers. That\u2019s off free throws.\u2019 We did a poor job of that. We could\u2019ve taken away so many easy baskets. Give them credit. They get the ball up the floor in a hurry, and they attack.\u201d LeBron James discussed after losing Game 1 of the Western Conference semifinals against Houston how the Lakers needed to actually experience the small-ball Rockets\u2019 overall team speed in a game setting to catch a firm grasp for how to combat it. For Denver, the same applies regarding the Lakers in transition. The Nuggets learned that lesson the hard way after closing the opening quarter Friday on a 16-8 run to take a 2-point lead (38-36) going into the second quarter. Los Angeles quickly reeled off a 17-1 run to start the second quarter, and in just the first 5:35 of that frame, the Lakers outscored Denver 20-3 on 7-for-8 shooting from the field and 2-for-2 from deep, while churning out seven points on seven Nuggets turnovers. Up 11 to start the third quarter, Los Angeles eventually pumped up the lead to 24 going into the final frame. Denver owns a record of 1-6 this postseason when it surrenders 110-plus points. \u201cTheir ability to convert from defense to offense is remarkable,\u201d Malone said. \u201cA lot of teams say they want to run, but they\u2019re not in shape to do so for 48 minutes. I think the second thing about it is they have a player in LeBron James who could very well be the best passing forward ever to play the game. He\u2019s always looking up the floor. They have bigs that are athletic, [and] put pressure on the rim. They have wings that are disciplined and dedicated to getting out on the break. And the ball is thrown up the floor. They\u2019re used to the advance pass, as opposed to always using the dribble. A lot of people talk about it. They do it. \u201cIt definitely was a concern coming into the series. You can talk about it. You can try to prepare people for it, but once you\u2019re up against it and you really feel it, I think that\u2019s when it takes hold. Hopefully, going into Game 2 our guys understand that and we can be a lot more disciplined, because there were times even when we were back we just didn\u2019t point and talk. And communication would clear up a lot of confusion and take away some of the easy 3s we allowed them to walk into. For us to try to even the series up, it\u2019ll have to start and end with that transition.\u201d Nuggets forward Michael Porter Jr. concurred. \u201cIt\u2019s mostly just an awareness we\u2019ve got to have, especially for us guys that crash the offensive glass,\u201d Porter said. \u201cBe selective with that, and just make sure we\u2019re getting back because they\u2019re a great transition team. They hurt us last game with that.\u201d Los Angeles coach Frank Vogel anticipates Denver working to make the necessary adjustments to handle his team\u2019s transition game, and the Lakers are already devising potential counters. \u201cAfter each game, we watch the tape and we come in as we\u2019re watching tape saying, \u2018Hey, Game 2, this is probably what Denver\u2019s gonna do,\u2019\u201d Vogel said. \u201cWe go through that list so our guys have thought about it, prepared. It\u2019s conversational. It\u2019s something we do talk about in between every playoff game.\u201d Besides that, the Lakers \u2014 winners of five straight playoff games for the first time since 2010, when they captured eight straight \u2014 understand the resilience Denver displayed in getting here. \u201cAfter watching them beat two great teams back-to-back after being down 3-1, they\u2019re the comeback kids. That\u2019s what we\u2019re gonna keep going by,\u201d Lakers forward Markieff Morris said. \u201cThey like to come back. So, we know we ain\u2019t had their best shot yet. It\u2019s still early.\u201d * * * Michael C. Wright is a senior writer for NBA.com. You can e-mail him  here  , find his archive  here   and follow him on  Twitter  . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25616,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/gordon-hayward-return-game-3","date":"2020-09-19","title":"Gordon Hayward returns to Celtics\u2019 rotation in Game 3","content":"LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. (AP) \u2014 Gordon Hayward has been part of Boston teams that have made the Eastern Conference finals twice in the past three seasons. He finally got to play in that playoff round. Hayward returned to the Celtics\u2019 rotation in Game 3 of their East title series against the Miami Heat on Saturday night, after missing a month while recovering from a right ankle sprain. It was his first time in an East finals game; he was inactive for all seven Boston games in the 2018 series and the first two this year, both times because of injuries. Hayward had six points, five rebounds, four assists and three steals in 31 minutes, and Boston won 117-106 . \u201cI think it was really fun to be back out there with the team, with the guys,\u201d Hayward said. \u201cI just tried to impact our team in winning ways, whatever I could do.\u201d Hayward checked in with 5:06 left in the opening quarter and finished with finished with six points, five rebounds, four assists and three steals. \u201cHe can score the ball. He can switch all the different positions. He gives us a lot of defensive flexibility there. He just gives us a lot,\u201d Celtics coach Brad Stevens said. \u201cAnd I think that he\u2019s always been a guy that provides a great sense of stability.\u201d Hayward played 34 minutes in Game 1 of Boston\u2019s first-round series against Philadelphia when he hurt the right ankle. The Celtics said Hayward would be out at least four weeks with what they said was a Grade III sprain, the most severe level; his absence was about 4 1\/2 weeks, so he was right on the envisioned schedule. \u201cWe don\u2019t expect him to be a world-beater, but I think his presence helps us,\u201d Stevens said. Hayward had a strong season for the Celtics, averaging 17.5 points, 6.7 rebounds and 4.1 assists on exactly 50% shooting. Hayward was only the second Boston player to have those numbers, or better, over a full season; Larry Bird is the other, and he did it five times for the Celtics. The Celtics\u2019 win Saturday cut Miami\u2019s lead in the series to 2-1. Game 4 isn\u2019t until Wednesday, so Hayward gets plenty of recovery time. \u201cI\u2019m extremely tired right now,\u201d Hayward said postgame. \u201cMy ankle\u2019s pretty sore.\u201d Hayward was a top target of Miami in the free agency summer of 2017 before he chose the Celtics. The Celtics lost that East title series to Cleveland in seven games."},{"id":25627,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/lebron-james-upset-kia-mvp-finish","date":"2020-09-19","title":"LeBron 'pissed off' with another Kia MVP second-place finish","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 LeBron James is fine. Just fine. His Los Angeles Lakers are up 1-0 on the Denver Nuggets in the Western Conference finals and he promised to sleep good in the NBA bubble. But that doesn\u2019t mean the Kia MVP voting, announced Friday, didn\u2019t rile him up. He agreed that back-to-back winner Giannis Antetokounmpo had a great year. It\u2019s the system and the voting breakdown \u2014 he received 16 of the 101 first-place votes \u2014 that caused a problem. For a four-time winner of the award in his 17th season who led the league in assists and guided the Lakers to the No 1 seed in the Western Conference playoff chase, and has his team three wins away from The Finals \u2026 that\u2019s math he can\u2019t comprehend. Finishing second for a fourth time, however, left him more angry than anything. \u201cPissed me off. That\u2019s my true answer,\u201d he said when asked for his thoughts on his place in the race. \u201cIt pissed me off because out of 101 votes, I got 16 first-place votes. That\u2019s what pissed me off more than anything. You know, not saying that the winner wasn\u2019t deserving of the MVP. But that pissed me off. And I finished second a lot in my career, either from a championship, and now four times as an MVP. \u201cI never came into this league to be MVP or to be a champion. I\u2019ve always just wanted to get better and better every single day, and those things will take care of itself. But some things is just out of my hand and some things you can\u2019t control. But it pissed me off.\u201d I get it. The MVP debate\/discussion stirs passion and emotion 24 hours a day, seven days a week and 365 days a year. I\u2019ve been responsible for NBA.com \u2018s Kia Race to the MVP Ladder long enough to know that my email inbox and social media feeds have the scars to prove how partisan the MVP discussion can get. LeBron\u2019s legion of supporters, my own father included, have no problem letting me know how wrong they think I was to be among the evil 85 that didn\u2019t have LeBron at the top of my ballot. And there\u2019s no doubt that LeBron presented a strong case for the top spot this season and basically every season since he entered the league. It pissed me off because out of 101 votes, I got 16 first-place votes. That\u2019s what pissed me off more than anything. LeBron James on Kia MVP voting I would point out that in this strangest of NBA seasons, with shutdown for the coronavirus pandemic and the restart here in the bubble and the fact that we\u2019re seeing the conference finals in September, the awards conversation is as strange as it\u2019s been in years. Is it any coincidence that in this strangest of NBA seasons it marks the first time since the 2006-07 campaign that none of the main award winners \u2014 MVP, Defensive Player of the Year, Most Improved Players, Rookie of the Year, Sixth Man Award and Coach of the Year \u2014 are in the conference finals? So maybe there\u2019s good reason for LeBron to be upset about the MVP race. After all, a slight, real or perceived, has always been a great motivator, even for the game\u2019s all-time greats (see Jordan, Michael and The Last Dance for a reminder). But it\u2019s clear he\u2019s been thinking about the voting process for season-ending awards for some time, the MVP criteria in particular. \u201cI don\u2019t know. I\u2019m not going to sit up here and talk about what the criteria should be or what it is,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s changed over the years since I\u2019ve gotten into the league, I know that. It\u2019s just changed. It\u2019s changed a lot. Sometimes it\u2019s the best player on the best team. Sometimes it\u2019s the guy with the best season statistically \u2026 Giannis had a hell of a season, I can definitely say that.\u201d While he doesn\u2019t need any extra motivation to add a fourth Larry O\u2019Brien Trophy to his wickedly long list of accomplishments, LeBron did rattle the saber when he offered his thoughts about those aforementioned fluid requirements for finishing first in any award category.  \u201cI mean, I\u2019m fine. Don\u2019t get it twisted. I\u2019m going back to my room. I\u2019m perfectly fine. We\u2019re 1-0 in the Western Conference finals. I\u2019m absolutely fine. I was pissed off at the reaction earlier when I saw it, (but) I\u2019m absolutely great now. I\u2019m going back to my room (to) drink some wine and sleep very well tonight. Let\u2019s not get it twisted. I\u2019m great.\u201d But \u2026 \u201cIt\u2019s just the voting scale is a little weird to me sometimes,\u201d he continued. \u201cI mean, if you take 2012. If you just stick with me \u2014 or 2012-13, I had a chance to be Defensive Player of the Year and also MVP in the same season. And that year [Marc] Gasol was [voted] Defensive Player of the Year, but he made Second Team All-Defense. So that doesn\u2019t make sense. It\u2019s like being MVP of the league, but you make Second Team All-NBA. That\u2019s when I really started to look at things differently. I was like, how does that even make any sense? It\u2019s like being Rookie of the Year but you make Second Team All-Rookie. \u201cAnd then I looked at the Most Improved this year, and rightfully so Brandon Ingram was amazing and I thought he should have won it. But did you see the vote that Devonte\u2019 Graham got? He averaged four points last year compared to 17 and a half (this year). If that\u2019s not improving, what is? \u2026 I don\u2019t know how much we are really watching the game of basketball or are we just in the narration mode, the narrative.\u201d Anthony Davis finished sixth in the MVP voting this season, his first playing alongside LeBron. There\u2019s no question who he would have voted for. \u201cHe deserves it. What he\u2019s been able to do for our team, the things he\u2019s been doing individually, on a consistent basis, night-in, night-out. It\u2019s not even a question who deserves it,\u201d Davis said. \u201cYear 17, doing what he\u2019s doing. I\u2019m pretty sure he said everything that I was going to say \u2026 They kind of choose the MVP before the season even starts. If the Lakers needed a rallying cry for this postseason run beyond the career-making accomplishment of winning a title or restoring the glory to a proud franchise that hasn\u2019t been in this space since 2010, they surely have it now. * * * Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst.
