The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25615,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/davis-lakers-overpower-nuggets-game-1","date":"2020-09-19","title":"Lakers overpower Nuggets in West finals opener","content":" Too big, too physical, too experienced, too talented and too much. The Denver Nuggets heard this before, of course, when they lost the previous series opener by 23 points to the other LA team less than two weeks ago \u2014 and lived to tell. Well, if the Western Conference finals remains on course after a dominant opener Friday night by the Los Angeles Lakers, then LeBron James and Anthony Davis (and Dwight Howard?) will flex their way to the NBA Finals. The Lakers used size to overpower the Nuggets, rolling up 32 free throw attempts in the first half of the 126-114 victory . They also got Nikola Jokic into early constant foul trouble, which is why all suspense turned to vapor by midway through the third quarter. \u201cWe want to be the most physical team on the floor every time we take the floor no matter what team we\u2019re playing,\u201d said Lakers coach Frank Vogel. \u201cI was happy where that was at tonight. We built a plan to give us the flexibility to play against small teams with Anthony at the five or going big with our two centers.\u201d Forced to deal with Howard and Davis, Jokic was simply outnumbered and couldn\u2019t elevate his team as LeBron did his. But that was the Lakers\u2019 plan, not only from the start of this series, but last summer when they added Howard to compliment the LeBron-AD nucleus. Loading up on height was done with an eye toward the postseason, just in case the Lakers saw Jokic along the way. They just didn\u2019t anticipate seeing him here in the West finals \u2014 but no need to pile on the Clippers any further. Howard was a wandering and unwanted soul for much of last summer when he was unceremoniously cut loose by the Wizards, his fourth team in four years. His career, while headed toward Springfield and the Hall of Fame someday, had taken a wicked detour, caused by a back injury \u2014 he would require surgery for it \u2014 and a poor locker room image. The Lakers signed him on the cheap, on a non-guaranteed deal at that. It was a harsh reflection of where Howard stood around the league, an embarrassing plight for an eight-time All-Star and former three-time Defensive Player of the Year. A year later, the Lakers and Howard are looking wiser right now for choosing each other. He was clearly the X-factor for Los Angeles in Game 1 against Denver after playing sparingly in the previous series against the small-ball Houston Rockets. He targeted Jokic almost immediately after checking into the game, baiting the Nuggets star into costly fouls that sent Denver\u2019s All-Star to the bench for much of the second quarter. Meanwhile, Howard also made himself a presence offensively by catching lob passes from LeBron and Rajon Rondo for easy buckets. As a reward, Howard started the second half over JaVale McGee, and within minutes, the game was essentially over. Howard finished with 13 points in 16 minutes. You could argue that, at one stretch, Howard was the second-best big man on the floor after Davis and ahead of Jokic. The Lakers can\u2019t lose in that situation. \u201cI liked his energy,\u201d Vogel said. \u201cDwight has a physical presence and this is going to be a physical series.\u201d As for Davis, he punished the Nuggets repeatedly and especially thrived with Jokic sitting with foul trouble. Because Davis is such a tough assignment given his shooting range and ability to score around the rim, Jokic is more vulnerable to fouls against the Lakers than in the previous two rounds when he faced Rudy Gobert and Ivica Zubac, a pair of centers who aren\u2019t primary scoring options. Basically, Jokic must expend energy at both ends of the floor because of Davis. \u201cWe have to do something different with him,\u201d Nuggets coach Mike Malone said of Davis. \u201cIt was too easy. He did not feel us.\u201d Davis finished with 37 points and 10 rebounds, while LeBron added 15 mainly because he wasn\u2019t needed; he also added 12 assists. \u201cWe followed the game plan, try not to foul, trust our game plan and what we\u2019ve been doing throughout this whole year,\u201d said LeBron. \u201cWe got a lot of length out there. Having that type of size and athleticism gives us an advantage.\u201d The Nuggets are perplexed, not only over the Lakers\u2019 size, but their own penchant for collecting fouls. The Lakers shot 24 free throws in the second quarter alone, and Malone was anxious to see the video replay of a majority of those foul calls. Regardless, he added: \u201cWe have to be a little bit smarter. We didn\u2019t guard anybody. We\u2019re not going to beat that team by putting them on the foul line 37 times. It was an extreme advantage for the Lakers in that first half. We can learn from our losses and see what we can do better to give ourselves a chance to win.\u201d The Lakers were taking no special satisfaction in capturing an opening victory against a Denver team that rallied from a pair of 3-1 deficits to reach this point. If anything, most of the postgame emotion was generated by LeBron over getting what he thought was a lack of respect in the MVP voting ; he finished second to Giannis Antetokounmpo. If that becomes a battle cry for LeBron for the rest of this series, then it\u2019s one more worry for the Nuggets. \u201cThis is a historic type of resilient team,\u201d Vogel said. \u201cWe got to make sure we put our foot on the gas.\u201d * * * Shaun Powell has covered the NBA for more than 25 years. You can e-mail him  here , find his archive here   and follow him on  Twitter  . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting. "},{"id":25628,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/championships-continue-elude-giannis-antetokounmpo","date":"2020-09-18","title":"As MVP awards pile up, championships continue to elude Giannis Antetokounmpo","content":"In a better world, Giannis Antetokounmpo could track down Robert Horry and offer him a simple swap: One Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award trophy for one of Horry\u2019s seven NBA championship rings. It would be a win-win, right? Horry, one of the league\u2019s most decorated role players ever, could show off on his mantle the Maurice Podoloff Trophy, presented annually to the NBA\u2019s MVP. (An award for which Horry never got a single vote in his 16 seasons, by the way.) Meanwhile, Antetokounmpo could forever flash that most coveted piece of sports jewelry, a championship ring. He has yet to win one in seven seasons with the Milwaukee Bucks, and it remains a hole in his remarkable resume that still needs filling. Horry \u2013 or Satch Sanders (eight rings), Tom Heinsohn (eight) or Sam Jones (10) \u2013 might not even miss one, and be happy to trade for the ultimate individual honor he never won. It doesn\u2019t work that way, of course. Modestly talented players pick up championship rings every season, validating their careers in ways the hefty paychecks do not. What makes them so very valuable is that, no, you can\u2019t go out and buy one, not a legitimate one. Can\u2019t swap for one, either. Conversely, only one performer each year gets hailed as the NBA\u2019s most valuable player. A select group have been honored with that award more than once. And an even more elite subset managed to stack up their MVPs back-to-back, distinguishing themselves one year, then defending the status the next. That\u2019s how Antetokounmpo did it, putting up historic numbers and again leading the Bucks to the NBA\u2019s best record, claiming the same MVP hardware for 2019-20 that he earned in 2018-19. With that, however, the Milwaukee star joined an even smaller club, one that could meet in a closet and maybe opt to keep the door closed: Back-to-back MVP winners who did not win \u2013 or in Antetokounmpo\u2019s case, have not won \u2013 a ring. Total membership? Two. It\u2019s former Phoenix point guard Steve Nash, the MVP in 2005 and 2006, and Antetokounmpo. Ten other NBA legends have been named MVP in consecutive seasons, and all won at least one championship. Nine, in fact, won two or more titles: Bill Russell, Wilt Chamberlain, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Larry Bird, Magic Johnson, Michael Jordan, Tim Duncan, LeBron James and Steph Curry. (Moses Malone won once, in 1983 with Philadelphia.) In all, the league\u2019s 65 MVP trophies have been won by 34 players. That includes 20 one-and-done winners, six players who each won twice and eight who combined to claim the honor 33 times: Russell (five), Chamberlain (four), Abdul-Jabbar (six), Malone (three), Bird (three), Johnson (three), Jordan (five) and James (four). Those eight Hall of Famers earned, between them, 35 NBA championships, led by Russell with 11 and Abdul-Jabbar and Jordan with six apiece. Of the 34 MVP winners overall, 26 of them also won rings. And fairly or not, the eight who never won might come to mind more quickly than several of those who did. The ringless MVPs: Charles Barkley (1993), Karl Malone (1997, \u201999), Allen Iverson (2001), Nash (2005, \u201906), Derrick Rose (2011), Russell Westbrook (2017), James Harden (2018) and Antetokounmpo. That\u2019s the group from which Antetokounmpo wants to distance himself now, not simply standing out from the other 450 or so active players. He said as much when he repeated his thought from last year\u2019s trophy announcement, asking that he not be called an \u201cMVP\u201d until he leads the Bucks to a championship. This time, he upped that to not being called a two-time MVP until that team prize is in hand. The Greek Freak, who actually was in Athens when the award balloting was released Friday, put up historical individual stats in 2019-20, averaging 29.5 points, 13.6 rebounds and 5.6 assists while shooting 55.3 percent and averaging a modest 30.4 minutes. Milwaukee went 56-17, posting the league\u2019s best record for the second season in a row. But the Bucks lost their formula before or during the long virus shutdown, sputtered in the Orlando restart bubble and suffered a gentleman\u2019s sweep (4-1) by Miami one round earlier than their 2019 exit. \u201cI always look forward,\u201d Antetokounmpo said in a Zoom news conference. \u201cI always try to figure out, how can I get better? How can I do it again? How can I do it for multiple years to come? How can I be a champion? I\u2019m happy. I\u2019m grateful. But how can I do it again?\u201d It\u2019s not likely Antetokounmpo will win a third straight MVP. It only has been done three times, and all three \u2013 Russell, Chamberlain and Bird \u2013 had won a championship before snagging their third Podoloff. Past back-to-back winners have faced voter fatigue, a tendency for those with ballots to seek out someone new for change\u2019s sake. There might be some, rightly or wrongly, who won\u2019t back Antetokounmpo again for the regular season award until he at least gets himself and his team to an NBA Finals. In the years after Nash\u2019s back-to-back MVPs, the Hall of Fame playmaker finished second, ninth, eighth and ninth in the balloting, though he continued to play at an All-Star level. By the way, Nash was 32 when he earned his second MVP. Antetokounmpo still is 25. There have been MVPs who had lengthy gaps between their first MVP and their first ring. Washington\u2019s Wes Unseld was a rookie when he was named MVP in 1969, then had to wait nine seasons to nail down a championship. It took Chamberlain (1960 to 1967) and Bob McAdoo (1972 to 1982) roughly that long before they backed up their individual greatness with a ring. So Antetokounmpo has time. But even superstars who got from MVP to champion pretty quickly, like Jordan and James (three years each from MVP to champion), heard about the missing piece of their puzzles constantly. Until they finally found it. That\u2019s why Antetokounmpo, asked Friday to channel the skinny Greek kid who was a steal at No. 15 in the 2013 Draft in reacting to all he has achieved so far, knit together so well his past, present and future. \u201cMy younger self would probably say, \u2018I\u2019m extremely proud of what you have accomplished. But we\u2019re not done yet,\u2019\u201d Antetokounmpo said. \u201cThe goal is always to be the best. The goal is always to be the champion. The goal is always to make your team successful.\u201d The goal for Antetokounmpo officially can shift to the Bill Russell Finals MVP Award, which will scratch all sorts of individual and team itches. Can\u2019t swap for that one, either. * * * Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25607,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/giannis-antetokounmpo-consecutive-mvp-winners","date":"2020-09-18","title":"Giannis Antetokounmpo becomes 12th player to win consecutive MVP awards","content":" Milwaukee Bucks star Giannis Antetokounmpo won his second straight Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award on Friday, becoming the 12th player in league history to secure the award in consecutive seasons. "},{"id":25629,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/kia-mvp-winners-second-season-playoff-run","date":"2020-09-18","title":"Winning MVP No. 2: How players fared in playoffs in second MVP run","content":"Giannis Antetokounmpo was already in elite company in winning the Kia MVP in 2018-19, becoming the first Bucks player to win the award since Kareem Abdul-Jabbar in 1973-74. Antetokounmpo also tied Steve Nash (No. 15 pick in 1996) as the lowest-drafted player to win MVP honors (Antetokounmpo was the No. 15 pick of the 2013 draft). He joins a whole new group of NBA legends in winning his second career NBA MVP. Abdul-Jabbar, Nash, Stephen Curry, LeBron James, Tim Duncan, Michael Jordan, Karl Malone, Magic Johnson, Larry Bird, Moses Malone, Wilt Chamberlain, Bill Russell and Bob Pettit also all won two (or more) MVPs in their Hall of Fame careers. Antetokounmpo, however, has yet to reach a NBA Finals and his Milwaukee Bucks were eliminated by the Miami Heat in the semifinals of the 2020 playoffs. Here\u2019s a look back at how each player\u2019s team fared in the playoffs in his second MVP season. And, of course, championship rings are always on the minds of fans. Here\u2019s a look at when each two-time (or more) MVP won (or didn\u2019t win) his first NBA title after securing an NBA MVP trophy."},{"id":25642,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/2019-20-kia-mvp-award-official-release","date":"2020-09-18","title":"Milwaukee\u2019s Giannis Antetokounmpo wins 2019-20 Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award","content":" NEW YORK \u2014 Milwaukee Bucks forward Giannis Antetokounmpo has been named the 2019-20 Kia NBA Most Valuable Player, the NBA announced today. This is the second straight Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award for Antetokounmpo, who becomes the 12th player to earn the honor in consecutive seasons. A native of Greece, Antetokounmpo is the first player from Europe to be selected as the NBA MVP more than once. Antetokounmpo, 25, also joins Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and LeBron James as the only players to win multiple NBA MVP awards by the age of 25. Antetokounmpo was previously named the 2019-20 Kia NBA Defensive Player of the Year. He joins Michael Jordan (1987-88) and Hakeem Olajuwon (1993-94) as the only players to be selected as the Kia NBA Most Valuable Player and the Kia NBA Defensive Player of the Year in the same season. (The NBA Defensive Player of the Year Award was first presented in the 1982-83 season.) Antetokounmpo received 85 of 101 first-place votes and earned 962 total points from a global panel of 100 sportswriters and broadcasters as well as the Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award fan vote. Los Angeles Lakers forward LeBron James received the other 16 first-place votes and finished in second place with 753 points. Houston Rockets guard James Harden (367 points) finished in third place, followed by Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Don\u010di\u0107 (200 points) in fourth place and LA Clippers forward Kawhi Leonard (168 points) in fifth place. Players received 10 points for each first-place vote, seven points for each second-place vote, five points for each third-place vote, three points for each fourth-place vote and one point for each fifth-place vote. The voting was conducted based on regular-season games played through March 11. The seeding games, which were played July 30 \u2013 Aug. 14 as part of the season restart, did not count toward voting for the Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award or the league\u2019s other traditional end-of-season awards. In games played through March 11, Antetokounmpo averaged 29.6 points, 13.7 rebounds, 5.8 assists, 1.04 steals and 1.02 blocks in 30.9 minutes in 57 games. During that time, he ranked third in the NBA in both scoring average and rebounding average. Antetokounmpo also shot 54.7 percent from the field and sank 83 three-pointers, which is 31 more threes than he made in any of his previous six seasons. Behind Antetokounmpo, Milwaukee posted an NBA-leading 53-12 record in games played through March 11, a mark that included an 18-game winning streak Nov. 10 \u2013 Dec. 14. The four-time NBA All-Star selection helped the Bucks excel on both ends of the court as they led the league in net rating (outscoring opponents by 10.7 points per 100 possessions), scoring offense (118.6 ppg) and defensive rating (101.6 points allowed per 100 possessions) in their first 65 games of the season. Antetokounmpo was honored as the Kia NBA Eastern Conference Player of the Month for October\/November, December and January, in addition to being named the NBA Eastern Conference Player of the Week four times. He was also voted as a starter to the NBA All-Star Game for the fourth consecutive season, serving as a team captain for the second year in a row. Among Antetokounmpo\u2019s other accomplishments in games played through March 11: Among Antetokounmpo\u2019s other accomplishments in games played through March 11: Antetokounmpo receives the Maurice Podoloff Trophy as the winner of the 2019-20 Kia NBA MVP Award. Podoloff served as the NBA\u2019s first commissioner from 1946 until his retirement in 1963. For the 11 th consecutive season, the NBA and Kia Motors America (KMA) gave fans the opportunity to vote for the Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award by voting online or by Twitter. The fan vote counted as one vote toward determining the winner. The voting results for the 2019-20 Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award are below. The balloting was tabulated by the independent accounting firm Ernst & Young LLP. Complete ballots for each voter will be posted at pr.nba.com on Saturday, Sept. 19. KIA NBA MOST VALUABLE PLAYER WINNERS 1955-56 \u2013 Bob Pettit, St. Louis 1956-57 \u2013 Bob Cousy, Boston 1957-58 \u2013 Bill Russell, Boston 1958-59 \u2013 Bob Pettit, St. Louis 1959-60 \u2013 Wilt Chamberlain, Philadelphia 1960-61 \u2013 Bill Russell, Boston 1961-62 \u2013 Bill Russell, Boston 1962-63 \u2013 Bill Russell, Boston 1963-64 \u2013 Oscar Robertson, Cincinnati 1964-65 \u2013 Bill Russell, Boston 1965-66 \u2013 Wilt Chamberlain, Philadelphia 1966-67 \u2013 Wilt Chamberlain, Philadelphia 1967-68 \u2013 Wilt Chamberlain, Philadelphia 1968-69 \u2013 Wes Unseld, Baltimore 1969-70 \u2013 Willis Reed, New York 1970-71 \u2013 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Milwaukee 1971-72 \u2013 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Milwaukee 1972-73 \u2013 Dave Cowens, Boston 1973-74 \u2013 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Milwaukee 1974-75 \u2013 Bob McAdoo, Buffalo 1975-76 \u2013 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, L.A. Lakers 1976-77 \u2013 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, L.A. Lakers 1977-78 \u2013 Bill Walton, Portland 1978-79 \u2013 Moses Malone, Houston 1979-80 \u2013 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, L.A. Lakers 1980-81 \u2013 Julius Erving, Philadelphia 1981-82 \u2013 Moses Malone, Houston 1982-83 \u2013 Moses Malone, Philadelphia 1983-84 \u2013 Larry Bird, Boston 1984-85 \u2013 Larry Bird, Boston 1985-86 \u2013 Larry Bird, Boston 1986-87 \u2013 Magic Johnson, L.A. Lakers 1987-88 \u2013 Michael Jordan, Chicago 1988-89 \u2013 Magic Johnson, L.A. Lakers 1989-90 \u2013 Magic Johnson, L.A. Lakers 1990-91 \u2013 Michael Jordan, Chicago 1991-92 \u2013 Michael Jordan, Chicago 1992-93 \u2013 Charles Barkley, Phoenix 1993-94 \u2013 Hakeem Olajuwon, Houston 1994-95 \u2013 David Robinson, San Antonio 1995-96 \u2013 Michael Jordan, Chicago 1996-97 \u2013 Karl Malone, Utah 1997-98 \u2013 Michael Jordan, Chicago 1998-99 \u2013 Karl Malone, Utah   1999-00 \u2013 Shaquille O\u2019Neal, L.A. Lakers 2000-01 \u2013 Allen Iverson, Philadelphia 2001-02 \u2013 Tim Duncan, San Antonio 2002-03 \u2013 Tim Duncan, San Antonio 2003-04 \u2013 Kevin Garnett, Minnesota 2004-05 \u2013 Steve Nash, Phoenix 2005-06 \u2013 Steve Nash, Phoenix 2006-07 \u2013 Dirk Nowitzki, Dallas 2007-08 \u2013 Kobe Bryant, L.A. Lakers 2008-09 \u2013 LeBron James, Cleveland 2009-10 \u2013 LeBron James, Cleveland 2010-11 \u2013 Derrick Rose, Chicago 2011-12 \u2013 LeBron James, Miami 2012-13 \u2013 LeBron James, Miami 2013-14 \u2013 Kevin Durant, Oklahoma City 2014-15 \u2013 Stephen Curry, Golden State 2015-16 \u2013 Stephen Curry, Golden State 2016-17 \u2013 Russell Westbrook, Oklahoma City 2017-18 \u2013 James Harden, Houston 2018-19 \u2013 Giannis Antetokounmpo, Milwaukee 2019-20 \u2013 Giannis Antetokounmpo, Milwaukee "},{"id":25670,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/film-study-celtics-heat-game-2","date":"2020-09-18","title":"Film Study: Heat's zone defense sends Celtics south in Game 2","content":" There are a lot of things about life in 2020 that a younger you would not believe. Maybe one of those is that zone defense is playing a big role in the NBA playoffs. A year after Toronto Raptors head coach Nick Nurse broke out a \u201cjanky\u201d box-and-one in the NBA Finals, zone defense remains more than just a gimmick to get a stop or two. And if the Miami Heat make it to this year\u2019s Finals, we may point to 20 minutes of zone defense on Thursday as a big reason why. The Boston Celtics\u2019 own defense was good enough in the conference semifinals to get past Nurse\u2019s Raptors, who played zone in all seven games of the series, throwing that janky box-and-one at Kemba Walker for almost the entire first half of Game 7. The Celtics\u2019 loss in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals on Tuesday was more about them letting their guard down defensively than it was about how they performed ( pretty well, actually ) on 14 possessions of Miami zone. Game 2 was another story. The Celtics blew a 17-point lead on Thursday in part because they couldn\u2019t execute against the Miami zone for much of the last 20 minutes of a 106-101 defeat that put them in an 0-2 hole. > Game 3: Celtics vs. Heat, Saturday at 8:30 ET on ESPN After handling the zone competently in Game 1, the Celtics scored the first two times Miami played zone in Game 2. Midway through the second quarter, they got an easy layup for Marcus Smart, who sneaked behind Duncan Robinson as Walker and Daniel Theis ran a pick-and-roll up top. Later in the second, Walker missed a wide-open pull-up jumper against the zone, but Jaylen Brown chased down the rebound and eventually made a pull-up himself , giving the Celtics that 17-point lead that they eventually blew. The Heat cut into the lead with some man-to-man stops at the end of the second quarter. But after the Celtics got Jayson Tatum to the line with a clever after-timeout play with a little more than eight minutes to go in the third, the Heat went back to the zone. And they would use it on almost every half-court possession from then on. While the Celtics were just as efficient against the zone as they were otherwise in Game 1, things were different in Game 2\u2026 For the most part, the Celtics\u2019 offense against the zone didn\u2019t look terrible. They were able to get into the paint and also attack from the baseline. But there\u2019s a difference between getting into the paint and scoring in the paint. After scoring 38 points in the paint (12 more than they had in all of Game 1) through the first 28 minutes on Thursday, the Celtics scored just eight points in the paint over the last 20 minutes. They made up some of that difference with free throws (7-for-8 through the first 28 minutes, 12-for-16 over the last 20), but it wasn\u2019t enough. Some of their jumpers against the zone were open, but open jumpers aren\u2019t layups. In all, the Celtics\u2019 16 empty possessions against the zone were a mix of bungled offense or bad decisions, open shots that were missed, tougher shots that were missed and great defensive plays. Bad offense Good looks That was the extent of the self-inflicted wounds against the zone on Thursday. The rest of the possessions that came up empty were more a result of how good the Heat were in that zone. There were some contested or rushed shots, for which this 10-foot floater from Walker is a good example\u2026 And there were some cases of the Heat just being athletic, smart and instinctive. For Heat coach Erik Spoelstra, the difference between the first half and the second half of Game 2 was less about man-to-man vs. zone and more about effort and energy. \u201cThere wasn\u2019t much that we liked about what we were doing defensively, man or zone,\u201d Spoelstra said afterward. \u201cI know everybody wants to talk about a scheme but for us it\u2019s disposition, effort, making multiple plays and multiple efforts, regardless of the scheme. And we were more committed there in the second half.\u201d Exhibit A in the effort-vs.-scheme argument is, well, the entire NBA. A lot of teams employ the same (or very similar) defensive schemes, but some execute those schemes better than others. It starts with buy-in and it continues with energy, cohesion, intelligence and instincts. And all of that was on display from the Heat over those last 20 minutes on Thursday. Here\u2019s some of their best work in the zone\u2026 Play 1: One way to beat a zone is to overload one side of the floor to the point where there\u2019s not enough defenders to guard everybody. The Celtics have done that at times, and early in the third-quarter stretch of zone, both Brown and Smart are open on the right side as Theis sets a screen for Walker\u2026 Walker gets the ball to Brown and he attacks the seam, drawing Bam Adebayo to the ball. But Adebayo is able to recover to Theis and block his layup. \u201cYou have to present a threat at the rim,\u201d Celtics coach Brad Stevens said of his team\u2019s execution against the zone, \u201cmake the guy in the middle play multiple guys, shrink the bottom in. I thought we did a good job attacking to the corners on several occasions. We missed shots or we drove it, dumped it to the roller and he just missed. But Adebayo had a big part of that.\u201d Play 2: The Heat apply some pressure in the backcourt (something they did a few times on Thursday) to work some extra seconds off the shot clock. Smart drives baseline and draws Adebayo and tries to hit Enes Kanter rolling to the rim. But Jae Crowder drops down from the opposite side to get his hand on the ball, forcing one of the Celtics\u2019 seven live-ball turnovers in the second half. Play 3: The Celtics seem to run a sideline out-of-bounds play for Tatum to flare off a back-screen from Grant Williams. He\u2019s open for a split second, but he\u2019s a few steps beyond the arc. Smart beats Derrick Jones Jr. off the dribble, but Jones makes an incredible recovery to contest (and maybe block) Smart\u2019s layup. (WYD, Kelly Olynyk?) Play 4: Smart flashes to the middle of the zone and quickly kicks the ball back out to Walker, but Butler and Tyler Herro keep Walker from launching off the catch. He gets into the paint, but Butler stays with him and Jones deflects his pass back to Smart. Tatum recovers the loose ball, but his pass to Brown on the baseline is wide. Play 5: On a baseline out-of-bounds play, Adebayo covers Tatum\u2019s dive to the rim and Butler bounces off of Theis\u2019 screen to deflect Smart\u2019s inbounds pass to Brown. Butler can sometimes get himself (and his team) into trouble with how aggressive he is in seeking steals and deflections. But it sure feels like he\u2019s guesses right more than he guesses wrong in those situations. He\u2019s one of two players who have played at least 100 minutes in these playoffs and have more steals than personal fouls. Kawhi Leonard finished with 30 steals and 29 fouls. Butler, who was one of two players (Memphis\u2019 Tyus Jones was the other) who played 1,000 regular season minutes with more steals than personal fouls, now has 25 and 20 through the Heat\u2019s 11 playoff games. You might have a hard time coming up with a better top line to a 2-3 zone than Butler and Jones ( more evidence here ). Having Adebayo as the back-line anchor is nice, too. \u201cIt\u2019s a hard zone to play against,\u201d Stevens said. \u201cWe did play well against it in Game 1. We played with way better pace than we did tonight. So we\u2019ll go back and look at it, figure out if it was a technical thing or a pace thing or an execution thing, or just not-as-focused-on-the-important-stuff thing.\u201d There was important stuff on the other end of the floor, especially in the third quarter , when the Heat scored 37 points on just 23 possessions, with Adebayo scoring 12 of those 37 in the restricted area. But the game really started going south for the Celtics when the zone slowed them down and kept them from getting to the basket. Spoelstra\u2019s it\u2019s-about-effort-more-than-scheme talk could mean that he doesn\u2019t see the zone as necessary to win more games in this series. Of course, he\u2019d ever give us any hint about how much he plans to use it going forward. Heck, his team played the most zone in the regular season, didn\u2019t play any zone through the first two rounds of the playoffs, and then had it ready for Boston in Game 1. Also, when the Heat went back to man-to-man for a couple of possessions midway through the fourth quarter on Thursday, the Celtics got a dunk from Tatum and a pull-up 3 from Walker . Maybe that was a temporary change of disposition and maybe the scheme had something to do with it. Whether it\u2019s about scheme or disposition (it\u2019s both), we can expect the Heat to go back to the zone at some point in Game 3. With more film to watch, Boston will have a better idea of what works and what doesn\u2019t. The Celtics\u2019 own disposition can be just as critical as that of the Heat. They\u2019ll certainly look to get into their offense quicker to avoid rushed shots late in the clock. And they may have an additional playmaker \u2014 Gordon Hayward, who hasn\u2019t played since the first game of the first round \u2014 to help find holes in the defense, maybe as the center in a tougher-to-guard small lineup that\u2019s played a total of 18 minutes this season. * * * John Schuhmann is a senior stats analyst for NBA.com. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25665,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nuggets-arrive-five-year-journey","date":"2020-09-18","title":"Nuggets have finally arrived after 5-year journey","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 Paul Millsap had seen and heard enough. The verbal jabs and blatant signs of disrespect from the LA Clippers had reached the point of no return for the Denver Nuggets\u2019 elder statesman. With 50.1 seconds to play before halftime of Game 5 in that Western Conference semifinal, and the Nuggets absorbing a pounding from the Clippers, Millsap decided it was time to take a stand. If the Nuggets, down 3-1 in the series and facing elimination, were going out, they were going to do it giving as good as they were getting from the favored Clippers. So when Marcus Morris Sr. and Millsap got tangled up under the basket fighting for space to chase a rebound, it clicked. Morris turned to face down the man shoving back and was met face-to-face by the usually measured Millsap, who was done backing up. > Game 1: Nuggets vs. Lakers, 9 ET on TNT Everything about that series \u2014 and ultimately this postseason \u2014 changed in that moment for the Nuggets, who rallied for a dramatic Game 5 win to keep their season alive. And then did the same again in Game 6 and Game 7 to shock the Clippers and set up a date with the Los Angeles Lakers in the Western Conference finals. But in that moment, Millsap recognized the need to show the Nuggets had arrived and had earned the right to that prime real estate as much as the Clippers, Lakers or anyone else toiling in the NBA bubble the past two plus months. \u201cI felt it. it definitely felt like everything changed right there,\u201d Millsap, the only player on the Nuggets\u2019 roster over 30, and a no-nonsense veteran with universal respect in the locker room, said of that defining moment between he and Morris. \u201cAnd to be honest, it should have happened earlier. I know the first game they blew us out and there was a lot of chatter and a lot of talk from those guys, telling us we were soft and all that stuff. So it was past overdue. And at that time, for me at least, enough was enough.\u201d Jamal Murray, All-NBA center Nikola Jokic and the rest of the Nuggets felt the same way. And it manifested in a historic effort to reach the conference finals \u2014 the Nuggets are the first team in NBA playoff history to rally from 3-1 deficits in multiple series in the same postseason; they did so in the first round against Utah as well. But what might look like some overnight fluke or global-pandemic-produced success story to the outside world is something totally different to the Nuggets. It\u2019s the fruits of a relentless five-year grind to build a legitimate contender under coach Mike Malone, whose team has shown a resilience unmatched in this bubble environment. Against all odds, the Nuggets believe. Even when no one else outside of the organization, and their most loyal fans, is buying them as a true contender. Murray demanded respect after they crushed the Clippers in Game 7, calling out everyone who has and continues to doubt them. \u201cYou\u2019ve got [Shaquille O\u2019Neal], you\u2019ve got Charles [Barkley], you\u2019ve got \u2014 I think \u2014 [ESPN NBA writer] Zach Lowe \u2026 [ESPN analyst Stephen A. Smith], all y\u2019all better start giving this team some damn respect, because we put in the work and we\u2019ve got a resilient team,\u201d Murray said. \u201cWe shouldn\u2019t have been down 3-1, but to come back from 3-1 against the Clippers is a big achievement. So it was fun just to change that narrative, where y\u2019all can finally shut up and start to change that narrative and putting us in a better light.\u201d Malone has been preaching belief in the system, in each other and in the work put in by the entire group from the moment he arrived. The Nuggets have drafted extremely well \u2014 Jokic, Murray, Gary Harris and Monte Morris, along with prized rookies Michael Porter Jr. and Bol Bol \u2014 and found the ideal pieces in free agency or on the fringes \u2014 Millsap, Jerami Grant, Torrey Craig, Mason Plumlee and others \u2014 to flesh out one of the deepest and most versatile rosters in the league. They have a player development program that has helped Jokic pivot from overweight toward two-time All-NBA status as arguably the best center in the league. Murray, the breakout star of this postseason, is on a similar trajectory. \u201cHis development, his growth\u2026 I think when we showed the belief that we had in him by the contract we gave him, you\u2019re a foundational piece, we believe in you,\u201d Malone said, referencing Murray\u2019s recent max extension. \u201cThis is something you have to understand, take responsibility for. You\u2019ve got to be better on the court, your preparation, your professionalism, your work ethic, and your leadership. He\u2019s taken all those things into account and tried to be better in every one of those areas, which is all you want. Now you have two core pieces in Nikola and Jamal that are still very young, bought in, have grown up in front of our eyes. \u201cI think most NBA teams, most pro sports teams don\u2019t do it that way. It\u2019s always a quick fix, go grab a guy, rent a guy. We built this from the ground up, which makes it that much more satisfying.\u201d The coach is another key ingredient. With the unyielding energy of Malone, who celebrated his 49th birthday on the same night they popped the Clippers to clinch the franchise\u2019s first trip to the conference finals since 2009, the Nuggets have a leader steeped in the process. \u201cI think the biggest question aside from themes, plays, personnel, is are our guys satisfied?\u201d Malone said. \u201cMan, we just made Playoff history, down 3-1, down 3-1 [again]. We\u2019ve gotten to the Western Conference Finals only the second time in franchise history. Take a breath, come up for air. The Lakers aren\u2019t coming up for air. They\u2019ve been waiting. I know LeBron, having been around him. They\u2019re going to try to come out and send a message. \u201cI don\u2019t think our guys are satisfied. That\u2019s going to be the greatest challenge, tomorrow can we match the intensity. I thought in Game 1 against the Clippers we did it for a quarter and a half, couldn\u2019t sustain it. I think we were just gassed. Hopefully tomorrow we\u2019re able to put forth a 48-minute effort.\u201d The Lakers aren\u2019t buying the humble underdog approach. James and Malone go back to their days in Cleveland, when they were chasing the same things they\u2019ll fight for in this series together. Malone was on Mike Brown\u2019s staff, working with LeBron before he was the three-time champion and Finals regular he would become in Miami and through that second stint in Cleveland. Knowing Malone\u2019s character and work ethic, watching his team take the Clippers apart down the stretch in three straight games is all the evidence James needed to know that they\u2019re in for a scrap in this series. \u201cVery resilient, very confident, very driven, very well-coached team,\u201d LeBron said. \u201cIt takes a lot of energy, effort, a lot of desperation to be able to come back from a 3-1 deficit. They did it twice. So the respect level is out of this world for what we have for this ballclub. That\u2019s how we\u2019re going into this series, understanding what they\u2019re capable of, where they stand. \u201cWhen you work hard on your craft, you see others working just as hard on their craft, it becomes organic and it becomes mutual respect. I know how much Coach Mo put into our schemes, put into our productivity, put into what we needed to do to go out and win ballgames when we were together in Cleveland. I saw that. So the respect level, just seeing what he was putting into his craft, it made it easy for me to grow likeness to him.\u201d Millsap said the Nuggets won\u2019t change their approach, not now. Not after what they\u2019ve been through to get here. So he\u2019ll gladly continue to remind his teammates that for all the work they\u2019ve put in, there remains plenty of folks who view them the way the Clippers did.  He doesn\u2019t have to do any convincing in the locker room. \u201cI mean, even when we beat the Clippers, they were talking how the Clippers lost,\u201d Jokic said. \u201cThey don\u2019t think about us. Not even the Lakers, not even anybody.\u201d * * * Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25666,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/heat-celtics-game-2-pivotal-third-quarter","date":"2020-09-18","title":"Heat's latest knockout quarter sets Celtics on their heels","content":" While Boston\u2019s Marcus Smart was making sure he won the fifth quarter Thursday night \u2013 jacking up decibels and temperatures in the Celtics\u2019 locker room, based on multiple ear-witness accounts in the Disney bubble \u2013 it was too late for him and his teammates to do anything about the third quarter. That was the lethal one. The game-breaker. The reason for Smart\u2019s and reportedly other Celtics\u2019 post-game anger. And the proof of that old saw that the playoffs are all about adjustments. Coach Erik Spoelstra and the Miami Heat adjusted midway through Game 2 like the Eastern Conference champions they\u2019ll be in a few days, if the Celtics don\u2019t adjust to the adjustments starting Saturday. > Game 3: Celtics vs. Heat, Saturday at 8:30 ET on ESPN A stingy zone defense, a jump-started Bam Adebayo, a late push of freelance creativity from Goran Dragic and the Heat\u2019s increasingly predictable resiliency flipped what began as an assured Boston performance. All that Heat freshness after halftime gave the south Floridians a 2-0 lead in the series, getting them halfway to the 2020 Finals before the West participant Lakers and Nuggets have even laced up their sneakers. The Celtics, after losing Game 1 in overtime, looked to have found their karma and their Kemba through two quarters Thursday. They led early, and pushed ahead by 17 before getting to the break at 60-47. Point guard Kemba Walker, after a cockeyed shooting night in the opener, was leading the way with 14 points on 6-for-10 from the field. The Celtics were hitting 58.1 percent as a group, while Miami, beyond Duncan Robinson\u2019s 4-for-9 shooting on 3-pointers, had little working at either end. \u201cWell, Boston was really getting us on our heels in the first half,\u201d Spoelstra said, \u201cand I don\u2019t think anybody was in any kind of rhythm or disposition defensively and a lot of it was them. They were backing us up and everything.\u201d So? Halftime, that interlude for studio shows, bathroom breaks and on-the-fly fixes. The Heat staff found some, throwing a zone in which its frontcourt guys often played out top. Even a little effectiveness helped Miami get back to playing in its personality, the scariest thing for Boston as this series plays out. Said Spoelstra: \u201cI know everybody wants to talk about a scheme, but for us it\u2019s disposition, effort, making multiple plays and multiple efforts, regardless of the scheme, and we were more committed there in the second half.\u201d The third quarter began innocently enough, Boston still up 67-52 at the 9:43 mark. But Adebayo had been activated after a quiet first half (4 points, 5 rebounds). The Miami center got a block, a couple of dunks, a steal and two more dunks in a span of less than four minutes. \u201cCoach came up to me in the third, was like, \u2018I need All-Defensive team now,\u2019\u201d Adebayo said. \u201cFrom there, I had to start it on defense and then my offense started flowing with it.\u201d It was Adebayo\u2019s floater at 4:17 that wiped Boston\u2019s lead completely. The Celtics got up only 12 shots in the quarter \u2014 seven turnovers against that Miami defense cost them possessions \u2014 and made four. Heck, the Heat were 5-for-12 on threes alone. \u201cWe pulled apart and we didn\u2019t play well,\u201d Boston coach Brad Stevens said. \u201cWe\u2019re not beating this team if we\u2019re not completely connected on both ends of the court. Got to get back to being that.\u201d Zones often turn an offensive team passive, searching for perfect shots rather than attacking along the baseline or at the rim. Stevens didn\u2019t think his guys were stymied \u2014 they had seen a variation of it in the previous round from Toronto \u2014 but it got the results Spoelstra sought. \u201cIt\u2019s a hard zone to play against [but] we did play well against it in Game 1,\u201d Stevens said. \u201cWe played with way better pace \u2026 So we\u2019ll go back and look at it, figure out if it was a technical thing or a pace thing or an execution thing or just not-as-focused-on-the-important-stuff thing.\u201d For those following along, this was only the latest in Miami\u2019s series of knockout-punch quarters. In Game 1 on Tuesday, their 35-23 fourth quarter erased the Celtics\u2019 12-point lead through three, making the Heat\u2019s OT victory possible. One round earlier, they seized absolute control against Milwaukee in Game 3 by undressing the Bucks 40-13 in the fourth. This time the damage came in the third, and Dragic was the difference in the fourth. Boston\u2019s last real push built a 94-89 lead, but it was down to two when Dragic returned with 3:17 left. He scored seven of Miami\u2019s final 11 points, controlling the ball and the pace in the time left. Said Spoelstra: \u201cYou just have to create something out of nothing [sometimes], and Goran was able to do that down the stretch.\u201d Now it\u2019s on Stevens and the Celtics to create something out of nothing so far in the series. The NBA announced after the game that there will be three days between Games 3 (Saturday) and 4 (Wednesday), and sitting around that long in a 3-0 hole would likely not improve the moods in Boston\u2019s locker room. * * * Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25654,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/celtics-heat-game-2-smart-locker-room","date":"2020-09-18","title":"Marcus Smart unloads on Celtics teammates in emotional tirade","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 No one had to wonder how Marcus Smart was handling the 2-0 hole his Boston Celtics have found themselves in against the Miami Heat in these Eastern Conference finals. Anyone within earshot of the Celtics\u2019 locker room at AdventHealth Arena after Thursday night\u2019s 106-101 Game 2 loss heard it loud and clear, as Smart was audibly screaming amid other voices in a heated exchange. It didn\u2019t stop after Smart exited the locker room and headed for a nearby bathroom. Smart exited the building without speaking the media, leaving Celtics coach Brad Stevens and teammates Jaylen Brown, Jayson Tatum and Kemba Walker to answer questions about what had gone on. Walker claimed he knew nothing about it. Tatum downplayed whatever went on. > Game 3: Celtics vs. Heat, Saturday at 8:30 ET on ESPN \u201cI don\u2019t know who said that,\u201d Tatum said. \u201cWe\u2019re frustrated. But that\u2019s team sports. You\u2019re not supposed to be happy we\u2019re down 0-2. Nothing going on there. Just talking about the game. It\u2019s cool. Got to get ready for the next one.\u201d Stevens admitted that \u201cGuys were emotional after a hard game, hard loss.\u201d Brown, however, acknowledged that the venting that went on in the postgame locker room was intense. \u201cAt the end of the day emotions are going to fly,\u201d Brown said. \u201cObviously, we wanted to win this game and we didn\u2019t. But the series is far from over. And we got to get ready for Game 3. You, this how it goes. In families there\u2019s up and downs, there\u2019s fights and emotions. But that\u2019s exactly what we are, a family. And you know, we\u2019re going to hold each other accountable and we\u2019ve got to do what it takes to come out and execute next game.\u201d When asked if what happened was needed, Brown agreed and acknowledged that a good Heat team is forcing the Celtics into all sorts of uncomfortable situations through the course of the first two games of the series. \u201cI think so,\u201d he said. \u201cA lot of people are passionate, emotional and I\u2019m one of those people, so I recognize it as that. I recognize it as emotions and passions and I don\u2019t recognize it as nothing else. How the media might see it or whatever, that\u2019s all it is passion just being expressed. So we gotta express that same passion next game for 48 minutes. Period.\u201d * * * Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst. The Los Angeles Lakers did their part, cruising through the first two rounds to reach the conference finals for the first time in 10 years. The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25672,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/celtics-heat-game-2-3-things-watch","date":"2020-09-17","title":"3 things to watch as Heat, Celtics head into Game 2","content":" If Game 1 was any indication, the Eastern Conference finals is going to be a long series. The Miami Heat and Boston Celtics went into overtime on Tuesday, with Bam Adebayo\u2019s incredible block of Jayson Tatum the difference in Miami\u2019s 117-114 victory. The Celtics led by 14 early in the fourth quarter, and that should have been a big enough cushion with how well they\u2019ve defended in these playoffs. But it wasn\u2019t, because the Celtics stagnated offensively and allowed the Heat to score critical early-clock buckets . > Game 2: Heat vs. Celtics, 7 ET on ESPN Amazingly, these are the only two teams that haven\u2019t trailed by 15 points during these playoffs, another reason to believe that this will continue to be a closely-contested series. Here are three things to watch for in Game 2: Heading into the 2020 Eastern Conference finals, we were among those who pointed to Boston\u2019s Marcus Smart and Miami\u2019s Tyler Herro as potential \u201cX-factors\u201d for their respective teams. But once a series is underway, underperformers are the ones who get outsized attention. And one game into the Celtics-Heat showdown, the guys capable of giving more are Miami\u2019s Duncan Robinson and Boston\u2019s Kemba Walker. Both had strong regular seasons to whet their teams\u2019 appetites for the playoffs. Both have had their moments so far in the Orlando bubble, even early in the postseason. But both are sputtering. And the first one to get on track could pull his team right along with him. Robinson\u2019s emergence in his second season caught rivals by surprise. Undrafted out of Michigan in 2018, signed as a two-way player, Robinson averaged 13.5 points and shot 44.6 percent on 3-pointers, starting 68 games for the Heat. He\u2019s at 10.1 points in 10 playoff appearances, though, and his accuracy from the arc has dipped to 38.2 percent. Over Miami\u2019s past seven games , Robinson has missed 33 of 48 3-pointers, including a 2-for-7 night in Game 1. A possible explanation is that the Robinson scouting report is complete and good teams do not neglect him in their game plan. It didn\u2019t help Tuesday that the Miami wing got in early foul trouble \u2014 defending without fouling is vital to the Heat\u2019s formula \u2014 and Herro\u2019s play has boosted the rookie as an option for some of Robinson\u2019s minutes anyway. \u201cSometimes you do all the right things and the ball doesn\u2019t go in,\u201d Robinson told The South Florida Sun-Sentinel Wednesday . \u201cIt requires adjustments on myself, also, to be more aggressive and also to make some.\u201d The Celtics similarly are searching for answers with Walker, or at least ways to shake him loose. Over their past seven games , the point guard has shot 20.4 percent on 3-pointers (10-for-49) and 38.8 percent overall. In Tuesday\u2019s Game 1, he wasn\u2019t having his usual success blowing by defenders, either. Boston center Daniel Theis talked Wednesday of how teammates might help Walker. \u201cWe got to help him [get] easy looks, especially me,\u201d Theis said. \u201cI\u2019ve got to get him open more on screens when he\u2019s got the ball, and even other guys, we\u2019ve got to get them open. \u201cSomething where he is off the ball, you have to set the screen for him so he\u2019s coming off screens and maybe a catch-and-shoot 3 instead of just iso and an off-the-dribble, step-back 3. Especially in the beginning of the game. We need him out there and we need him to be aggressive.\u201d Walker was hardest on himself after the opener, talking about how \u201cterrible\u201d he played in going 1-for-9 from the arc, 6-for-19 overall, and only showing a familiar spark later in the game (10 points in the fourth quarter plus overtime). That glimmer was enough for Celtics coach Brad Stevens to double-down on Walker. \u201cI don\u2019t lose any sleep over Kemba,\u201d Stevens said. \u201cNobody cares more than Kemba. Nobody wants to play better. We are constantly going to the drawing board to figure out how we can make his life a little bit easier from our own perspectives. So we\u2019ll keep riding.\u201d \u2014 Steve Aschburner Zone defense has seen an uptick the last couple of seasons and no team played more zone defense this season than the Heat, according to Synergy play-type tracking. And then the Heat didn\u2019t play any zone against the Indiana Pacers or Milwaukee Bucks in the first two rounds of the playoffs. But the Celtics struggled against multiple Toronto zones in the conference semifinals. Over seven games, Boston scored 90.3 points per 100 possessions (93 on 103) against the Raptors\u2019 different zones and 109.2 points per 100 possessions otherwise. So the Heat broke out their zone late in the first quarter on Tuesday, and they played it for 14 of the Celtics\u2019 99 possessions of Game 1. The results were mixed, but the Celtics generally handled the zone better than they did for most of the Toronto series. They scored 16 points on those 14 zone possessions, a rate (1.14 points per possession) better than their marks from all but one game in the last round (10 points on eight zone possessions in Game 5). A few of the empty possessions came when the Heat went to zone as the Celtics were taking the ball out of bounds with a short shot clock.* And there were a few really good looks against the zone \u2014 a wide-open corner 3 , an open pull-up jumper , and another open 3 from top of the arc \u2014 that Walker just missed. * This includes the possession in which Adebayo blocked Tatum at the end of overtime. It\u2019s tough to distinguish whether that was a zone or the Heat switching everything, even non-screen exchanges before the inbounds pass. Marcus Smart made a long, pull-up 3 in one of those short-clock situations, but the Celtics\u2019 other five scores against the zone came when they were able to get into the paint via the dribble or pass. One of those was a timely cut from Brad Wanamaker, leading to an open 3 for Tatum\u2026 We\u2019ll probably see more zone in this series. But Celtics were basically as efficient against zone on Tuesday as they were otherwise (98 points on 85 possessions, 1.15 per). Fourteen possessions is a small sample size, but we might not see longer zone stretches than that going forward. The Heat\u2019s man-to-man defense is a little like a zone in that they\u2019re switching most screens to keep the ball in front of them. \u2014 John Schuhmann On three different occasions in Game 1, the Heat ran a sideline out-of-bounds (SLOB) play that you\u2019ll see a few teams run ( here are two examples from the Milwaukee Bucks). It\u2019s fairly simple, with Adebayo flashing to the strong-side elbow and the inbounder (usually Jimmy Butler) getting a back screen from another guard coming up from the strong-side block. But it forces defenses to make a tough decision in how it guards the back-screen (shooters make the best screeners) and it has a lot of options without even involving the two guys on the weak side of the floor. Here are several examples of the play from the Heat, with the three Game 1 instances at the end: Early in the third quarter, Walker switches the back-screen from Dragic. So Butler seals Walker under the basket, gets the entry feed from Adebayo, and drops in an easy jump hook. Midway through overtime, Tatum wants to avoid that mismatch, so he stays attached to Butler when Jae Crowder sets the back-screen. But Walker still gets pushed into the paint and Crowder is left alone on the wing for a huge 3. Later in OT, Walker is already guarding Butler, so Herro doesn\u2019t bother with the back-screen and vacates the area. But before Adebayo can get the ball to Butler, Smart comes over from the weak side and rescues Walker. That causes Butler to hesitate and the Celtics force a tough 3 from Herro as the shot clock expires. \u2014 John Schuhmann The NBA\u2019s Last Two-Minute Report off Game 1 showed three incorrect decisions by the officials Tuesday, each of which seemed to favor Boston. One, however, might not have.  There was Derrick Jones Jr.\u2019s erroneous foul on Marcus Smart before the Celtics inbounded the ball with 22 seconds left in regulation. There was Tatum\u2019s uncalled traveling violation with 7.3 seconds left, before he launched and missed a 3-pointer at the end of that final quarter, tied 106-106. And there was a wrongly assessed foul on Goran Dragic with 32.7 seconds remaining in overtime. The foul that Smart sold when Jones bumped into him was the result of Walker pushing the Heat player into his teammate. Because the clock hadn\u2019t started, the Celtics got one free throw (made by Tatum) and the Celtics again got to inbound. But that free throw tied the score at 106-106. That\u2019s when Boston settled for Tatum\u2019s isolation shot on its final possession \u2014 and then complained afterward that their offense had gotten too stagnant. Had the Celtics still trailed 106-105, they almost certainly would have gone quicker, getting more action to get a closer shot or create contract to get to the line for the tie or lead. Smart\u2019s free throw seemed to lull them, as far as objective and energy. \u2014 Steve Aschburner"},{"id":25659,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/report-sacramento-kings-hiring-monte-mcnair-head-basketball-operations","date":"2020-09-17","title":"Kings hiring Monte McNair as general manager","content":" The Sacramento Kings are hiring Monte McNair as general manager, the team announced. McNair will be responsible for all decisions made in the Kings basketball operations department and serve as the team\u2019s top basketball executive. \u201cMonte is one of the NBA\u2019s top basketball minds who has played an instrumental role in building several winning teams in Houston,\u201d Kings owner Vivek Ranadiv\u00e9 said. \u201cI am excited to bring his extensive experience and vision onboard to lead our basketball operations department, and it is my pleasure to welcome Monte and his family to Sacramento.\u201d McNair has worked in the Rockets\u2019 front office since 2007, most recently as the assistant general manager under Daryl Morey. McNair was promoted into the assistant GM role in 2018. \u201cI am thrilled to join the Kings organization and honored to shape the franchise\u2019s bright future for the team\u2019s loyal fans,\u201d McNair said. \u201cI would like to thank Vivek for this opportunity and look forward to becoming a part of the Sacramento community.\u201d Over his 13 years with the Rockets, McNair was involved with all aspects of player evaluation, including trade, free agency and the Draft. He began his career in Houston as a Basketball Operations Senior Analyst in 2007, was promoted to Director of Basketball Operations in 2013 and became Vice President of Basketball Operations in 2016. A Princeton graduate, McNair has an extensive analytics background and has been a speaker at the MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference. The Kings parted ways with former GM Vlade Divac after the season. The Sacramento Kings also announced that Joe Dumars has been named Chief Strategy Officer. In this new role, he will continue to report to the owner and chairman, and help drive strategy across the organization\u2019s entire portfolio of activities, including business, basketball, new ventures, entertainment and real estate. Per team policy, terms of the deal were not disclosed.  \u201cJoe\u2019s business acumen along with his deep experience in the league will serve as a valuable resource across the organization,\u201d said Kings Owner and Chairman Vivek Ranadiv\u00e9. \u201cHe has achieved proven results in the corporate world on top of many notable accolades as a player and basketball executive, and I am excited to have him serve in this position.\u201d In June 2019, Dumars joined the Kings as Special Advisor to the General Manager, most recently serving as Interim Executive Vice President of Basketball Operations.  He has over 30 years of NBA experience both as a player and front office executive in addition to an extensive executive business background. Prior to joining the Kings, Dumars served as president of the Basketball Division for Independent Sports & Entertainment (ISE), a full-service sports agency representing more than 300 players from the NBA, NFL and MLB. Dumars was also the founder and CEO of automotive supply company Detroit Technologies Inc. for 10 years (1996-06), helping the company grow to more than $120 million in revenues. He is also the founder and owner of the Joe Dumars Fieldhouse, a multi-purpose, indoor sports complex and entertainment facility with two locations in Detroit."},{"id":25671,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/lebron-james-anthony-davis-lakers-all-nba-history","date":"2020-09-16","title":"LeBron James makes All-NBA history","content":" LeBron James earned his 16th All-NBA selection for the 2019-20 season with the Los Angeles Lakers. The First-Team honor moves him past NBA legends Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Tim Duncan and Kobe Bryant for the most All-NBA selections in a career. Throughout NBA history, only 18 players have earned more than 10 All-NBA selections. LeBron is the only active player on the list. LeBron also made history alongside teammate Anthony Davis as the eighth pair of teammates to each earn First-Team honors during a season. They\u2019re the first teammates to do it since Steve Nash and Amar\u2019e Stoudemire during the 2006-07 season with the Phoenix Suns. "},{"id":25677,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nba-2019-20-all-nba-teams-official-release","date":"2020-09-16","title":"Giannis Antetokounmpo, LeBron James unanimously selected to 2019-20 All-NBA First Team","content":" NEW YORK \u2014 Milwaukee Bucks forward Giannis Antetokounmpo and Los Angeles Lakers forward LeBron James have been unanimously selected to the 2019-20 All-NBA First Team, the NBA announced today. James has set the NBA record with his 16th All-NBA Team selection, which includes a record 13 selections to the First Team, two to the Second Team and one to the Third Team. He passed 15-time All-NBA Team selections Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Kobe Bryant and Tim Duncan.  Antetokounmpo, the 2019-20 Kia NBA Defensive Player of the Year, and James both received All-NBA First Team votes on all 100 ballots to finish with 500 points each. Named to the All-NBA Team for the fourth time, Antetokounmpo has earned his second First Team honor. The 2019-20 All-NBA First Team also features Houston Rockets guard James Harden (474 points; 89 First Team votes), Lakers forward-center Anthony Davis (455 points; 79 First Team votes) and Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Don\u010di\u0107 (416 points; 59 First Team votes). Harden and Davis have been voted to the All-NBA First Team for the sixth and fourth time, respectively. Don\u010di\u0107 is making his All-NBA Team debut in his second season. He is the first player selected to the All-NBA First Team in either his first or second season since Duncan in 1998-99. Don\u010di\u0107, 21, also becomes the sixth player named to the All-NBA First Team at age 21 or younger, joining Kevin Durant (2009-10), James (2005-06), Duncan (1997-98), Rick Barry (1965-66) and Max Zaslofsky (1946-47). The 2019-20 All-NBA Second Team consists of LA Clippers forward Kawhi Leonard (372 points), Denver Nuggets center Nikola Joki\u0107 (311), Portland Trail Blazers guard Damian Lillard (284), Oklahoma City Thunder guard Chris Paul (199) and Toronto Raptors forward Pascal Siakam (168). The 2019-20 All-NBA Third Team is composed of Boston Celtics forward Jayson Tatum (153 points), Miami Heat forward Jimmy Butler (147), Utah Jazz center Rudy Gobert (110), Philadelphia 76ers guard Ben Simmons (61) and Rockets guard Russell Westbrook (56). Siakam, Tatum and Simmons join Don\u010di\u0107 as first-time selections to the All-NBA Team. Paul and Westbrook have been voted to the All-NBA Team for the ninth time each. Lillard and Leonard have earned their fifth and fourth All-NBA Team selections, respectively. This marks the third All-NBA Team honor for both Butler and Gobert and the second for Joki\u0107.   The All-NBA Team was selected by a global panel of 100 sportswriters and broadcasters.  Players were awarded five points for each vote to the All-NBA First Team, three points for each vote to the Second Team and one point for each vote to the Third Team. Voters selected two guards, two forwards and one center for each team, choosing players at the position where they play regularly. Players who received votes at multiple positions were slotted at the position where they received the most votes. The voting was conducted based on regular-season games played through March 11. The seeding games, which were played July 30 \u2013 Aug. 14 as part of the 2019-20 season restart, did not count toward voting for the All-NBA Team or the league\u2019s other traditional end-of-season awards.  The voting results for the 2019-20 All-NBA Team are below. The balloting was tabulated by the independent accounting firm Ernst & Young LLP.  Complete ballots for each voter will be posted at pr.nba.com after the announcement of all end-of-season awards. Below are the other players who received votes for the 2019-20 All-NBA Team, listed at the position where they received the most votes. The \u201cTotal Points\u201d category represents points that players received at any position, not just the position where they are listed. *Karl-Anthony Towns received one Third Team vote at center and one Third Team vote at forward."},{"id":25676,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/film-study-celtics-heat-game-1","date":"2020-09-16","title":"Film Study: Heat's transition game catches Celtics off guard","content":" The Eastern Conference finals are already living up to expectations. The Miami Heat came back from a 14-point fourth-quarter deficit to win Game 1 in overtime . Bam Adebayo saved the game with one of the best blocks you will ever see and Jimmy Butler was 2-for-2 on shots to tie or take the lead in the final minute of the fourth quarter or OT, having shot 1-for-15 in those situations prior to Tuesday. Jayson Tatum was 0-for-2 on final-minute shots for the lead or the tie , and offensive stagnation was an issue for Boston. But the other end of the floor was the larger problem for the Celtics as they blew that 14-point lead. The Heat scored 35 points on their final 20 possessions of the game, part of a wacky sequence of events where Miami was more than twice as efficient in the second and fourth quarters (72 points on 43 possessions, 1.67 per) than it was in the first and third (34 on 46, 0.74 per). > Game 2: Heat vs. Celtics, Thursday at 7 ET on ESPN This was actually the slowest-paced game of the Eastern Conference playoffs thus far. So don\u2019t let the low score (106-106 after regulation) fool you. Despite the anemic first and third quarters, the Heat scored 117 points on just 99 possessions, making Game 1 the Celtics\u2019 worst defensive game of the postseason thus far (30 total games), with the two teams combining for just 198 possessions in 53 minutes. The slow pace overall doesn\u2019t mean that both teams walked the ball up the floor for 53 minutes. In fact, the Heat\u2019s 16 fast break points in Game 1 were more than they had in any game in the first round and just two fewer than their high in the conference semis . It was their transition game that sparked their offense early in the second quarter and ultimately made the difference on Tuesday. But more surprising than the Heat having success in transition was the Celtics allowing it to happen. One of the biggest keys to Boston\u2019s conference semifinals victory over the Toronto Raptors was transition defense. After the Raptors led both the regular season (18.8) and the first round (18.5) in fast break points per game, the Celtics held them to just 11.4 per contest in their seven-game series. If you want to know why Pascal Siakam struggled against the Cs, start with the fact that only three (2.7%) of his 110 field goal attempts came in the first six seconds of the shot clock, according to Second Spectrum tracking. In both the regular season and in the first round, 20% of Siakam\u2019s shots came in the first six seconds of the clock, but the Celtics cut off his transition opportunities, and he\u2019s not nearly as efficient in the half-court as he is in the open floor. The Heat, in general, do not run like the Raptors. They ranked second in transition efficiency according to Synergy tracking, but only 13.3% of the Heat\u2019s regular-season possessions, the league\u2019s fourth lowest rate , were in transition. Through the first two rounds of the playoffs, that number was just 11.2%. Maybe the Celtics let their guard down a bit? If that\u2019s the case, their guard will be back up after watching the film from Game 1. After the Heat scored just 20 points on their first 25 possessions of the game, Kelly Olynyk began a run of nine straight scores by squeezing in a reverse layup around Grant Williams. And then Goran Dragic went to work, sparking a stretch where five of Miami\u2019s next seven scores came from quick attacks against a Boston defense that just wasn\u2019t ready\u2026 Play 1: After Kemba Walker feeds Semi Ojeleye for a dunk, he\u2019s not prepared for a Dragic push. By the time Walker gets over to the left side of the floor, Dragic is going downhill on his way to a short runner in the paint. Play 2: After a dead ball turnover on the very next possession, Walker is in front of Dragic, but not in guarding position. Dragic abandons the set play (likely an entry pass to Adebayo at the left elbow) and attacks Walker again, getting an even better look than he had on the previous possession. Play 3: Two possessions later, Dragic rebounds a Brad Wanamaker miss and Wanamaker does a good job of stopping Dragic\u2019s initial push. But he passes ahead to Tyler Herro, who immediately attacks Grant Williams off the dribble, draws help from Walker, and passes to a wide-open Andre Iguodala in the corner. Play 4: The Celtics call timeout, but turn the ball over on their next possession. Butler pushes the ball up the floor and Tatum runs back to the paint instead of identifying Duncan Robinson in transition. Wanamaker is a little late with his contest and then watches what happens next. When Butler rebounds Robinson\u2019s miss, Wanamaker isn\u2019t there to contest the second-chance 3. Play 5: When Tatum hits the floor after a tough miss in the paint, the Heat have a 5-on-4 break. The other Celtics get back, but Jaylen Brown allows Butler to get between him and the basket and Herro hits Butler for an and-one. Credit the Heat for pushing the ball. Effective field goal percentage is highest in the first six seconds of the shot clock and taking advantage of a defense that\u2019s not set is a great way to get some easier points. But the Celtics will look at those plays above and realize that they could have been better. Walker not being ready to defend Dragic, Wanamaker ball-watching after contesting Robinson\u2019s initial 3, and Brown not taking the extra step needed to keep Butler out of the paint\u2026 Those are all mistakes that can be cleaned up with better focus and effort. Transition defense can come down to reaction time, because one step can be the difference between a contested shot or an open one. One second can be the difference between staying attached to an opponent running the floor and that same opponent running free. The Heat found more transition opportunities in coming back from that 14-point, fourth-quarter deficit, and they again got help from the Celtics\u2026 Play 1: On first glance, this is just a case of the Heat having numbers after a live-ball turnover. But look at where Dragic and Wanamaker are as Tatum\u2019s pass is in the air\u2026 Yes, Dragic has the inside lane, but he also reacts faster. He actually gives up that inside lane to run wide, but still has three steps on Wanamaker (who doesn\u2019t exactly have the strides of Usain Bolt) by the time he crosses into the frontcourt\u2026 Play 2: After Brown makes a 3, he thinks he\u2019s guarding Adebayo. And by the time he realizes that he\u2019s supposed to be guarding Jae Crowder, it\u2019s too late and Crowder gets a layup. Play 3: Daniel Theis picks up Crowder in transition, but trailing Crowder is Robinson, and Wanamaker is slow to meet him for the trail 3. Play 4: Walker hits a tough floater to put the Celtics up three with a little more than a minute to go in regulation, but the Heat get the ball up the floor quickly. Walker keeps Tyler Herro from launching a quick pull-up 3, but then leaves him for a split second as Marcus Smart (who lunged to deflect Dragic\u2019s pass) recovers back to Dragic. Herro reloads and drains a huge shot to make it a one-possession game. Play 5: In overtime, Adebayo leaks out after contesting a Tatum step-back 3 and gets an easy dunk. How do you stop that? Well, as Tatum was shooting the ball, Walker was standing above the 3-point line on the left side of the floor, and he didn\u2019t move until it was far too late\u2026 According to Second Spectrum, the Heat were 12-for-16 in the first six seconds of the shot clock in Game 1, with the 16 attempts being more than Toronto had in the first six seconds in any of the last five games of the conference semifinals. Dragic had five more shots in the first six seconds on Tuesday (he was 6-for-8) than Siakam had over seven games against the Celtics (1-for-3). \u201cTransition defense really stands out,\u201d Celtics coach Brad Stevens said of the Celtics\u2019 fourth-quarter collapse. \u201cThat Herro three with a minute left in regulation was a killer.\u201d The Celtics\u2019 mistakes weren\u2019t limited to transition situations. Botched switches led to a dunk for Butler midway through the fourth quarter and a wide-open 3 for Jae Crowder in overtime. \u201cThey executed very well down the stretch,\u201d Smart said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t, especially on the defensive end. Miscommunication on a lot of guys\u2019 part. And in transition, we allowed them to do what they do best, and that\u2019s get out and run.\u201d Given how many mistakes they\u2019ll see in the film, the Celtics will probably lean toward \u201cWe need to play better\u201d more than \u201cWe need to make changes\u201d for Game 2. The Heat, with their movement and versatility on offense, will continue to test them more than Toronto did on that end of the floor, but the Celtics are a better defensive team than what they showed in Game 1. Heck, they showed it in the first quarter. \u201cWe couldn\u2019t get anything going [early] and that\u2019s a big-time credit to their defense,\u201d Heat coach Erik Spoelstra said. \u201cThey got us out of our normal rhythm. It wasn\u2019t about us. That\u2019s just what they do, and Goran was able to shake free a few times and put some points on the board.\u201d Both teams will take a close look at how matchup-hunting worked for them. Miami was often looking to get Walker switched onto Butler, while the Celtics got very iso-heavy in the fourth quarter and overtime. Overall, their offense wasn\u2019t a big problem (this was only their third loss of the season when scoring more than 115 points per 100 possessions), but the Celtics will certainly look for ways to get the ball moving against the Heat\u2019s switch-everything (or zone) defense. The Heat did trap some of Walker\u2019s pick-and-rolls, and he handled that well, creating a couple of open 3s. The Celtics were switching a lot too and both teams have already tried slipping out of screens to catch defenders off balance. Gordon Hayward\u2019s status will remain a topic of conversation. He hasn\u2019t played since spraining his ankle in the first game of the first round, but he\u2019s been ramping up his activity over the last week. Hayward taking minutes from Wanamaker and Semi Ojeleye will be a heck of an upgrade whenever it happens. It might be tough for the Heat to shorten their rotation after an overtime game in which five guys played 39 minutes or more, but they played 10 on Tuesday and Kendrick Nunn\u2019s minutes were a struggle. They could eventually go back to their first-round, no-Nunn, nine-man rotation. A 1-0 series lead won\u2019t preclude the Heat from making their own adjustments. \u201cI don\u2019t think you can set the tone in a long series,\u201d Spoelstra said. \u201cObviously it\u2019s much better to get the win and go work on your teaching points from there, but we understand how we can\u2019t get too carried away with just one win.\u201d * * * John Schuhmann is a senior stats analyst for NBA.com. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter .
