The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25740,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/steve-nash-eager-new-career-nets-coach","date":"2020-09-10","title":"Steve Nash eager to get started on new career as Nets coach","content":" NEW YORK (AP) \u2014 Steve Nash was a leader, a guy who loved to get the best out of his teammates on the court and build relationships with them off it. Those qualities helped him become a Hall of Fame player. Now he thinks they can make him a successful coach. Nash was introduced Wednesday by the Brooklyn Nets, who picked him to guide Kevin Durant, Kyrie Irving and the rest of a team with high expectations despite him having no coaching experience. \u201cI love to compete. I love to teach, to lead and to be a part of a team. And so to be in a position where I can use all those things on a day-to-day basis and focus all my energy on those tenets is a perfect fit,\u201d Nash said. \u201cSo while I hadn\u2019t necessarily publicly stated my desire to coach, privately it\u2019s always been in my mind, it\u2019s always been an opportunity that suited me. When you can\u2019t run up and down the court anymore, what can you do? What can you contribute?\u201d The Nets believe there is plenty. General manager Sean Marks played with Nash in Phoenix, when the Suns helped usher in an exciting era of high-scoring basketball, and knows how his fearlessness can galvanize an organization. \u201cLook, there\u2019s nobody that I\u2019ve been around that hasn\u2019t wanted to be pressure tested on the spot quite like Steve. He\u2019s never shied away from a moment,\u201d Marks said. \u201cThis guy has never run from anything and he wants the ball in his hands at the end of games and his career spoke for itself. He made the right decision more times than not, so the experience that he\u2019ll bring here speaks volumes.\u201d The two struck up a friendship off the court, talking about life outside of basketball. When Marks was looking for a coach this summer, Nash called and asked if this was the time for him to pursue it. Marks agreed it was, citing Nash\u2019s ability to connect people and drive a culture. And Nash, having played against Durant and Irving and becoming friends with both, is eager to impart his smarts on a roster that has plenty of skills. \u201cThey\u2019re obviously at an incredible point in the history of this organization, so I think the timing is fantastic, the opportunity is fantastic,\u201d Nash said. The hiring was a surprise, with Nash apparently not telling many of his friends within the league of his interest in coaching. And it led to some criticism that he got a coveted opportunity at the top without having to work his way up from the bottom. \u201cWell, I did skip the line, frankly, but at the same time I think leading an NBA team for almost two decades is pretty unique,\u201d Nash said. \u201cSo while I haven\u2019t necessarily learned some of the skills that I\u2019ll definitely seek to understand and learn as far as the technical aspects of coaching, I was never far from that.\u201d There were also a criticism that Black assistants with similar qualifications don\u2019t receive the same opportunities in a league where there are only five Black head coaches. Nash agreed that he has benefited from white privilege in some aspects but not this one. \u201cI\u2019m not sure that this is an example that fits that conversation but I own it and I understand why it\u2019s important to talk about it and that we do need more diversity and more opportunity for African American coaches and staff in all capacities,\u201d Nash said. Nash had worked only as a player development consultant with Golden State, but Marks wasn\u2019t looking for coaching experience. The attributes he sees in Nash go far beyond X\u2019s and O\u2019s. \u201cHis winning past, the way he\u2019s played the game, his family values, and just the curious and creative mind that he has brought to the game over a 20-year career,\u201d Marks said, \u201cand also maybe more importantly than anything the joy with which he played the game and the joy with which he led his teams and his teams played were deciding factors in making Steve Nash the right choice for the Brooklyn Nets.\u201d Brooklyn reached the playoffs even while Irving played only 20 games and Durant missed the entire season while they recovered from injuries. With them back and a number of players growing from the experience they got playing without them, Nash couldn\u2019t ask for many better places to start a new career. \u201cI think the chemistry and culture has been well lauded. We have a roster that is very wealthy, and I mean that from a basketball standpoint,\u201d Nash said. \u201cWe have talent, versatility and good human beings. So as a coach there\u2019s so much to be thankful for when you walk in the doors here. I just can\u2019t wait to get started.\u201d"},{"id":25774,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/lakers-playing-rockets-smallball-hand-successfully","date":"2020-09-10","title":"Rockets force Lakers to go small, might regret the result","content":" Houston\u2019s small-ball style generates the headlines, but the Los Angeles counterattack to it might be playing significantly into the results we\u2019ve seen over the last two games of this Western Conference semifinal series. After the Lakers snatched a 2-1 lead in the series Tuesday night, Rockets coach Mike D\u2019Antoni talked about his team running \u201cout of a little steam,\u201d saying, \u201cI think our legs got a little tired. They upped their stuff.\u201d Perhaps the Los Angeles Lakers\u2019 small-ball lineup of LeBron James, Rajon Rondo, Markieff Morris, Alex Caruso and Kyle Kuzma factored heavily into all of that. \u201cLast game, it was Markieff [Morris], this game it was Rondo,\u201d said James Harden, after scoring 33 in Tuesday\u2019s losing effort. \u201cSo, we\u2019ve just got to make sure that we\u2019re engaged and locked in on the role players.\u201d Given their impact on these last two games, that certainly makes sense. It\u2019s a small sample size, no doubt, but over the last two games the Lakers small-ball lineup of James, Rondo, Morris, Caruso and Kuzma has scored 56 points on 33 possessions, while allowing just 30 points on 31 defensive possessions. Although they\u2019ve played a total of just 16 minutes on the floor together over the last two games, you can\u2019t minimize the group\u2019s impact (169.7 offensive rating, 96.8 defensive rating, 81.8% on defensive rebounds and a true shooting percentage of 93.1) Over the last two games, the Lakers have outscored the Rockets 57-37 in the fourth quarter, limiting Harden to 3-for-7 shooting from the field and just five points in the fourth quarter of each of his last two outings. \u201cWe\u2019re doing a good job, numerically,\u201d said Lakers coach Frank Vogel. \u201cThe thing about James and this team is you\u2019re never comfortable. It doesn\u2019t matter what the score of the game is, what the series looks like. We\u2019re just not gonna be comfortable against a team that has the type of firepower that they have. We\u2019re going to just continue to try to execute our coverage and scheme to try to minimize him and obviously the backside 3\u2019s as much as possible.\u201d So, it comes as no surprise that of the 16 minutes spent on the floor together, that Lakers lineup of James, Rondo, Morris, Caruso and Kuzma has logged half of those minutes solely in the fourth quarter of the last two games, producing impressive numbers. Vogel didn\u2019t deploy that lineup in Game 1. When he did for Game 2, the group shot 87.5% in outscoring the Rockets 35-14. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to play smarter, and harder for longer periods of time,\u201d said Rockets center P.J. Tucker on Wednesday. \u201cObviously, going into the fourth tied up, they made some good shots [in Game 3]. Rondo made some good shots, Kuzma made some good shots. It\u2019s because they got some stops. It\u2019s just how the game goes. It\u2019s been tough all series. \u201cBut for us, we\u2019ve just got to do what we do faster, harder, for a longer amount of time. That\u2019s all that matters. Obviously with the doubles on James, Russ [Westbrook] in the post, we\u2019ve got to be able to get to our spots, be able to make plays, the right plays. Like I said: we do it throughout the game. We\u2019ve just got to do it for longer.\u201d The question is whether that\u2019s possible, given the way D\u2019Antoni splits up Houston\u2019s minutes. Six Rockets \u2014 Harden, Westbrook, Tucker, Robert Covington, Eric Gordon and Jeff Green \u2014 played 35-plus minutes in Game 3. Just two Lakers \u2014 James and Anthony Davis \u2014 logged as many minutes in Game 3. Los Angeles utilized 10 players for Game 3, while Houston played with an eight-man rotation without Danuel House Jr. available due to personal reasons. When House played in Game 2, D\u2019Antoni utilized a nine-man rotation with each of his starters playing at least 33 minutes, compared to just two Lakers logging as many minutes. So, it begs the question of whether Houston possesses the stamina to finish games while leaning so heavily on the starters. D\u2019Antoni was asked before Wednesday\u2019s practice whether fatigue has played a role in Houston\u2019s fourth quarter woes. \u201cWe\u2019re just not getting it done,\u201d D\u2019Antoni said. \u201cThat\u2019s the simple answer. Last night, it was a question of we had five turnovers in the fourth. When it comes to a time to win the game, to be more assertive and more careful with the ball and just will ourselves to a win, we haven\u2019t done that.\u201d Down 2-1 going into Thursday\u2019s Game 4, the Rockets find themselves in familiar territory. In each of the last two postseasons, Houston fought off series deficits against Golden State to tie things up before eventually suffering elimination. Covington returns for Game 4 after going through the concussion protocol Wednesday, the result of suffering a nasty blow to the nose from Anthony Davis in Game 3 that led to him hitting his head on the floor. D\u2019Antoni said, \u201cwe haven\u2019t heard yet,\u201d when asked about House\u2019s availability for Game 4. \u201cWe need to be more aggressive definitely defensively [late in games],\u201d D\u2019Antoni said. \u201cWe\u2019re in the right spots, but we\u2019re not being active in those spots. We need to turn up the heat. That\u2019s what they did after Game 1, where we willed ourselves to good stuff. In Games 2 and 3, they willed their way to better games. We\u2019ve got to match that. Structurally, we\u2019ll tweak some things here and there, how we guard guys. We\u2019ll change that. But overall, it\u2019s a dogfight. Usually, the dog with the most fight is gonna win. We\u2019ve got to be that dog.\u201d Even when the other team is consistently unleashing more dogs. Michael C. Wright is a senior writer for NBA.com. The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25739,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/nba-consider-nov-18-draft-date","date":"2020-09-09","title":"NBA officials to meet and consider Nov. 18 date for Draft","content":" LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. (AP) \u2014 The NBA\u2019s board of governors and general managers will discuss a plan later this week to push the NBA Draft back to Nov. 18, according to a memo sent to teams Wednesday. In the memo, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press , the league told teams that the Nov. 18 date is based on \u201cinitial conversations with the Players Association.\u201d The board of governors and general managers have meetings scheduled for Thursday and Friday. If it is moved this would be the second time that the Draft \u2014 originally set for June 25, then pushed back to Oct. 16 \u2014 gets delayed. An additional delay would also allow the league more time to conduct the pre-draft process, including a combine in some form, teams were told in the memo. The league also said delaying the draft would allow it more time to continue the process of deciding when best to start next season. Moving the draft would have a domino effect on other offseason league business, such as free agency and the process by which the league and Players Association will determine salary cap numbers for 2020-21 \u2014 something that teams obviously need to know before they can go shopping. The most recent plan had been for free agency to start with negotiations able to begin at 6 p.m. on Oct. 18 and the end of the annual offseason moratorium at noon on Oct. 23. And the NBA had been hoping for a Dec. 1 start to the 2020-21 season, though Commissioner Adam Silver said on the ESPN telecast of the draft lottery last month that date was unlikely. Silver said Dec. 1 \u201cis feeling a little bit early to me.\u201d The league has yet to publicly reveal when next season could start \u2014 or if it could start in a bubble or multiple bubbles. \u201cOur No. 1 goal is to get fans back in our arenas,\u201d Silver said on the draft lottery telecast Aug. 20. \u201cMy sense is, in working with the players association, if we could push back even a little longer and increase the likelihood of having fans in arenas, that\u2019s what we would be targeting.\u201d"},{"id":25734,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/rockets-robert-covington-injured-collision-lakers-anthony-davis","date":"2020-09-09","title":"Report: Robert Covington expected to be available for Game 4","content":" Houston Rockets forward Robert Covington was taken to the locker room after colliding with Los Angeles Lakers center Anthony Davis in the fourth quarter of Game 3 of the teams\u2019 Western Conference playoff series Tuesday night. Less than five minutes remained in the game when the collision took place. On Wednesday morning, ESPN\u2019s Tim MacMahon reported that Covington\u2019s nose is not broken and he passed a concussion protocol test. Covington is expected to be available to play for Game 4 (7 ET, TNT) . The Lakers lead the series 2-1 after winning Game 3 on Tuesday night. Covington and Los Angeles\u2019 Kyle Kuzma were trying to get into rebounding position. A push from Kuzma caused Covington to run into Davis, who was stationed under the basket. The left side of Covington\u2019s face hit Davis\u2019 right arm, while Covington\u2019s left elbow hit Davis\u2019 right side. Covington had a towel on his face as he headed to the locker room. Information from The Associated Press was used in this report."},{"id":25773,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/lakers-rockets-game-3-analysis","date":"2020-09-09","title":"Return of 'Playoff Rondo' helps LeBron James to milestone playoff victory","content":" LeBron James placed Game 4 preparation ahead of perspective Tuesday night after moving to No. 1 in all-time NBA playoff victories (162) . James scored a game-high 36 points, including 29 in the first half, before dominating from the defensive end in the second half to lead the Lakers to a 2-1 series lead over the Houston Rockets by way of a 112-102 win . \u201cI haven\u2019t had an opportunity to let it sink in,\u201d James said of his latest milestone. \u201cI\u2019m already kind of preparing for Game 4. But when I hear it, to just know the history of the game, from growing up as a kid watching the NBA playoffs, seeing so many dominant players, so many dominant franchises, seeing who was victorious out there and to know I sit at the top of most wins for any individual is very humbling and something I never dreamed of. > Game 4: Lakers vs. Rockets, Thursday at 7 ET on TNT \u201cBut it doesn\u2019t happen without my teammates over the years, my coaching staffs, everyone from top to bottom \u2014 GMs, owners, training staff, ball boys, everything \u2014 everyone has a hand in it because we\u2019re all a part of the process and success.\u201d Game 3 served as testament to James\u2019 thoughts with Los Angeles leaning on timely contributions from Anthony Davis (26 points) and veteran point guard Rajon Rondo (21 points and nine assists), who carried the Lakers on a personal 8-0 run in the fourth quarter to break open a close game. Rondo\u2019s 21 points registered as his most in the playoffs since May of 2018. With the Lakers up 86-85, Rondo knocked down a 22-footer, and followed up 34 seconds later with another 3-pointer. Rondo stole an errant James Harden pass on the ensuing possession and converted on the other end with a finger roll to put Los Angeles ahead 94-85 shortly before serving up his 1,000th career playoff assist on an Alex Caruso 3-pointer. Rondo said after Game 3 that he doesn\u2019t buy into the \u201cPlayoff Rondo\u201d moniker, but he\u2019s certainly embodied it over the last two games. Lakers coach Frank Vogel expected this all along, despite Rondo missing the team\u2019s seeding games and the first round after undergoing surgery in July on his fractured right thumb. So did James, having faced Rondo in the playoffs on 25 occasions, as well as Davis, who played with the point guard in New Orleans in 2017-18, when the Pelicans swept Portland in the first round. \u201c\u2019Playoff Rondo\u2019 is real,\u201d Davis said. \u201cHis intensity picks up. He wants to guard the best perimeter guy. He wants to facilitate on the floor. He\u2019s shooting the ball very well, making the right passes. We\u2019ve got the two best I.Q. guys in the game with him and LeBron on the floor at the same time, which is tough for defenses. So, \u2018Playoff Rondo\u2019 is real, and he showed up tonight.\u201d Rondo scored 15 points and dished five assists over the final two quarters as the Lakers limited Houston to just 38 second-half points. Davis credits James and Rondo with helping the Lakers make defensive adjustments on the fly, as they did in Game 3. \u201cThey see a lot of things on the floor, then we make adjustments,\u201d Davis said. \u201cWe come in with a game plan, but things happen in the course of a game. \u2026 With at least one [of them] on the floor at all times, it\u2019s easier to make those adjustments. It\u2019s been helpful for me. Those two guys, with that basketball I.Q. on both ends of the floor have been wonderful for us.\u201d Rondo\u2019s experience and knowledge makes him a rarity in today\u2019s NBA, according to James. \u201c[It\u2019s beneficial] when you have enough people you can trust and be in the foxhole with you, not from a basketball aspect, but from a cerebral aspect,\u201d he said. \u201cThe postseason is about making adjustments from game to game, and also being able to make adjustments on the fly because things happen in real time. Being able to see how defenses are playing, seeing how the game is being played, seeing how the flow of the game is being played, there\u2019s just not many guys that can do that in our league. In the postseason, it\u2019s gigantic. Having Do\u2019 on your side definitely helps.\u201d James did most of the heavy lifting in the first half with 29 points that may have prevented a Houston blowout. Harden and Russell Westbrook combined for 38 first-half points as the Rockets shot 56.8% from the field and 42.9% on 3-pointers. Harden finished with 33 points, while Westbrook bounced back from a dismal Game 2 to contribute 30 points on 13-of-24 shooting and 2-of-4 from deep. \u201cWe didn\u2019t play any defense in the first half,\u201d Vogel said. \u201cSo, this easily could\u2019ve been a blowout if [James] wasn\u2019t hitting big shot after big shot.\u201d Big blocks for James came soon after \u2014 four of them, in fact, in the third quarter \u2014 as the 35 year old set a personal playoff milestone for blocks in a quarter. James has eight blocks in this series, but only one of his four blocks in the third quarter led to points. James ran down Austin Rivers (whose father, Doc, was in attendance) for a block that prevented Houston from breaking an 82-82 tie at the third-quarter buzzer. \u201cIt\u2019s unbelievable,\u201d Vogel said. \u201cWhen he\u2019s protecting the rim on that end of the floor, and then scoring [29] in a half, that\u2019s just remarkable. The lift he gives us with the superhero plays, you can\u2019t really put it in words.\u201d Davis certainly tried to. \u201cIt gives us a spark, his ability to chase guys down on fast breaks, something he\u2019s been doing his whole career,\u201d Davis said. \u201cYou\u2019ve got the best guy on your team giving his body up trying to take charges and making big plays on the defensive end. Usually, if he blocks it, he\u2019s running down the floor and he gets upset if we don\u2019t give him the ball for dunks and lobs. So, we try to find him. Then, another spectacular play is coming on the other end.\u201d The last two games appear to be finally wearing on the Rockets. They expressed confidence Monday in the aftermath of Game 2. But Houston coach Mike D\u2019Antoni said after Game 3 that, \u201cI think our legs got a little tired\u201d in the second half, and in the fourth, \u201cI think it\u2019s pretty obvious we just ran out of a little steam.\u201d Houston shot 6-for-20 in the third quarter, 7-for-18 in the fourth and put up 30 3-point attempts \u2014 their fewest since Jan. 22. \u201cWe can\u2019t play into their strengths and the things they love to do,\u201d Harden said. \u201cThat\u2019s halfcourt, slow the pace up, let them get set, let them meet us at the rim, which I think we did, especially in the second half.\u201d Houston\u2019s bench, which has been outscored 83-19 over the last two games, is another growing concern. In the second half of Game 3, Los Angeles\u2019 bench outscored the Rockets\u2019 30-7 as Jeff Green was the only Houston reserve to score in Game 3. Sixth man Danuel House Jr. missed the game for what D\u2019Antoni called \u201cpersonal reasons.\u201d Houston\u2019s reserves could be even thinner for Game 4 if Green is forced to start. Robert Covington left the game with 4:37 left after catching an inadvertent Davis elbow to his nose under the basket. D\u2019Antoni wasn\u2019t certain about Covington\u2019s status and had \u201cno idea\u201d about whether House would play in Game 4. As for James, it\u2019s clear he\u2019s still got plenty of support for a fifth Kia MVP award, even though it appears that hardware this season could go to Giannis Antetokounmpo. \u201cNobody impacts winning more than LeBron James,\u201d Vogel said. \u201cHonestly, it\u2019s probably true in the history of the game that no one has impacted winning more than LeBron James.\u201d Davis, meanwhile, has grown so accustomed to seeing James\u2019 heroics that another career milestone in Game 4 wouldn\u2019t surprise him. \u201cIt seems like he\u2019s drinking from the fountain of youth,\u201d Davis said. \u201cThe things he\u2019s able to do on the floor still: head still touching the rim, still taking big shots, still playing physical is all a testament to his hard work and dedication to taking care of his body. So, I\u2019m pretty sure we\u2019ll see another record being broken on Thursday.\u201d * * * Michael C. Wright is a senior writer for NBA.com. The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25765,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/heat-bucks-analysis-game-5","date":"2020-09-09","title":"What's next for Bucks after again coming up short?","content":" Before we get started here, let\u2019s make sure no one gets the Milwaukee Bucks\u2019 timeline twisted as they made their way out of the NBA restart bubble down at Disney:  * The Bucks dug themselves a fatal 3-0 hole in their E astern Conference semifinals series against Miami with Giannis Antetokounmpo. Yes, the likely (and reigning) Kia Most Valuable Player and the certified KIa Defensive Player of the Year twisted his right ankle in Game 3. But he played through it, only exiting with 16 seconds left in that staggering 40-13 fourth quarter Friday. * Milwaukee at that point essentially was eliminated from the 2020 postseason. While folks around the NBA like to say that Father Time is undefeated, they also know that dropping the first three games of a playoff series is insurmountable. It\u2019s postseason quicksand, claiming all 140 teams that have stepped in it through the years.  * Then Antetokounmpo sprained the ankle again early in the second quarter of Game 4. He spotted his teammates 19 points in his 11 minutes, but they proved plucky enough to take advantage of some Heat complacence and avoid the sweep by winning in overtime. * Then the Bucks\u2019 star got ruled out shortly before Game 5 Tuesday , effectively ending their 2019-20 season against a Miami crew that wasn\u2019t going to make the same mistake twice. Milwaukee ran out of defense in stretches, ran out of buckets in one miserable third-quarter drought and ran out of time. It\u2019s important to keep the sequence of events straight because in the coming months or years, some people may get it mixed up. They might attribute Milwaukee\u2019s unacceptable ouster in five games, by a No. 5 seed, from the semifinals, to Antetokounmpo\u2019s injury and absence from the series finale. They might think that failing in five games somehow is better than four, when in truth it was over in three. They might shift their gaze back to the Bucks\u2019 admirable regular-season record, not just this time (56-17) but from 2018-19 (60-22) too. They might spin all those things forward in an attempt to rationalize the Bucks\u2019 second consecutive playoff failure. And then maybe alibi some more by citing the weird, artificial atmosphere of the Orlando restart campus or the Bucks\u2019 focus on social protest that might not have been a distraction, per se, but clearly added a lot to their playoff plate. To their credit, the players who were asked on their Zoom post-series interviews and coach Mike Budenholzer generally refused to blame the odd setting in which the NBA playoffs are unspooling or the off-court social justice agendas all 22 bubble-invited teams embraced from Day 1. Everybody, winners and losers, have dealt with the same isolated, hunkered-down circumstances. And they all have felt capable of tackling two tasks, playing on the court and speaking out on their media platforms over the past eight weeks. The Bucks could have felt a little extra glare from the spotlight they shined on themselves when they decided not to play Game 5 of their first-round series vs. Orlando on Aug. 26, the day it was scheduled. But the other teams still alive in the playoffs had their backs. The schedule got shifted by three days and basketball returned. It wasn\u2019t as if Milwaukee got inordinately hounded by media attention, either \u2014 the reporters in the bubble remained the same, quarantine rules fending off a sudden rush from TMZ or the networks. So now that we\u2019ve accounted for the timeline and the purging of excuses, the questions remain. * * * Do not underestimate the severity of the Bucks\u2019 swoon. They got to March 1 with a 52-8 record. Then they went 1-4 before the virus lockdown, losing at Miami, at the Lakers, at Phoenix and at Denver. After an interruption of more than 4 1\/2 months \u2014 again, same for everybody \u2014 Milwaukee went 3-5 in the seeding games, got spanked in its playoff opener by the Magic, and wound up at 5-5 in the two rounds as its bubble burst. In all, that\u2019s a 9-14 mark that began well before the restart. None of them had an answer for that lost vim, vigor, mojo or bottom-line results. Homecourt advantage? Yeah, it sure looks as if they needed what was nowhere to be found. The dazzling Fiserv Forum sat vacant back in the Cream City. What is inescapable is that the Bucks need change, and a fair amount of it. An overhaul, not tweaks around the edges like they got last summer. There would be zero satisfaction, and potentially a lethal dose of impatience, if general manager Jon Horst, Budenholzer, his staff and the players tried to run back the same group, same strategies, same results whenever 2020-21 gets here. Posting the best record over the long schedule to again snag the No. 1 seed , then hoping for a different playoff result is a form of hoops insanity. Besides, that\u2019s what this season was all about. The Bucks were two victories away from the 2019 Finals when they lost Game 3 to Toronto in overtime and never got back on track. So that means they\u2019re 5-9 in their last 14 postseason games. Even if the Bucks (like the other 29 teams) won\u2019t have to worry about selling tickets anytime soon, how will they attract eyeballs when fans already have seen this movie \u2026 twice? It isn\u2019t change for its own sake that\u2019s needed. There are weak spots to address, holes to plug, work to be done and mistakes to be erased, if they can be. The decision last offseason to keep Eric Bledsoe over Malcolm Brogdon goes all the way to the top, a financial flinch by co-owners Marc Lasry and Wes Edens that saw the Bucks keeping the wrong guy. Or at least parting with the better player for them. It\u2019s been bad enough to see Bledsoe play poorly in the biggest moments \u2014 after the way he shrank against Boston in 2018 and Toronto last year, his work against Miami should be strike three. If, that is, there is a way to offload the guaranteed $40 million or so left on his contract. What hurts too is that Bledsoe isn\u2019t a shooter (Brogdon is), which is what Milwaukee needs from the point guard it teams with Antetokounmpo. He can be a fireplug defensively (he was named to the league\u2019s All-Defensive second team Tuesday) but that doesn\u2019t outweigh his inefficient and oft-forced offense. Wesley Matthews at the other starting backcourt spot will turn 34 next month and played this season on borrowed time. George Hill, Bledsoe\u2019s backup, already is 34. There\u2019s more center Brook Lopez can give if asked, and Khris Middleton needs to use his play in Antetokounmpo\u2019s absences against the Heat to boost his game to that next proverbial level. Budenholzer\u2019s twice-tried, twice-thwarted system \u2014 based on making 3-point shots over the top of his freakishly versatile penetrator, while counting on opponents to miss theirs \u2014 needs a makeover. His team\u2019s focus on defending the paint coupled with the game-by-game randomness of perimeter shooting earned the Bucks\u2019 their No. 1 defensive ranking again this season. But Miami beat them at their own game, shooting 37.3% from the arc for 75 3-pointers to the Bucks\u2019 32% and 54. The Raptors had turned them inside out that way as well. Relying so heavily on Antetokounmpo \u2014 yet seeing how other players moved and played more aggressively in his absence near the end against the Heat \u2014 suggests there are skills and styles to blend toward better ends, too. No more waiting for Giannis to do it. Look, revamping a system isn\u2019t always an easy thing for a coaching staff, so Budenholzer\u2019s happiness and future in Milwaukee may get bandied about outside and even inside the organization. When four playoff coaches already have gotten dumped \u2014 Indiana\u2019s Nate McMillan, Philadelphia\u2019s Brett Brown, Brooklyn\u2019s Jacque Vaughn (interim) and now Oklahoma City\u2019s Billy Donovan \u2014 it\u2019s important to remember that contracts are guaranteed but jobs are not. As for Antetokounmpo, even he has miles to go, er, lots to improve upon for 2020-21, from his foul shooting and need for a reliable mid-range jump shot to new brakes, new shoes or new moves to cut down on his offensive fouls. That \u201cmiles to go\u201d phrasing might have confused some folks, focused as they might be on Antetokounmpo and the quarter-billion-dollar, five-year \u201csupermax\u201d contract extension he will or will not sign before next season. Even though the Greek Freak has room for growth and definitely can help his teammates more right where he is, that\u2019s not necessarily how this league works. To head off that disaster \u2014 Antetokounmpo deciding he wants out to seek his championship elsewhere \u2014 the Bucks frankly must change around him. However and whatever he wants. * * * Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25764,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/heat-bucks-game-5-sidebar-sekou","date":"2020-09-09","title":"Jimmy Butler's bet on Miami Heat pays off","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 Two months ago his words sounded crazy to anyone outside of the Miami Heat ecosystem. Jimmy Butler was just being, well \u2026 Jimmy Butler, when he talked about the Miami Heat\u2019s mission in the NBA bubble. He told anyone willing to listen that they were coming north to win it all, not just to deliver a good showing and exit this unprecedented situation with any moral victories. That\u2019s not the Heat way. Who cares that the roster didn\u2019t scream championship, with its mix of seasoned veterans and promising youngsters. Butler saw something in the Heat organization, and the building blocks of this team in particular, when he spurned other recruiting pitches last summer and zeroed in on the hard-hat culture of the championship organization that team president Pat Riley built and coach Erik Spoelstra commands. So they\u2019re halfway to a fourth title now, and halfway to Butler\u2019s stated goal, with Tuesday\u2019s 103-94 win over the No. 1 overall seed Milwaukee Bucks in Game 5 at HP FieldHouse. Butler\u2019s not surprised things have come together so quickly. \u201cNot at all,\u201d said Butler, who led a balanced effort with 17 points, 10 rebounds and six assists. \u201cWe\u2019re a close group, we like being around one another. We\u2019re constantly talking about how we can make each other better. What we see out there on the floor, we\u2019re legit in it to win it. We don\u2019t care about stats, we don\u2019t care about fame. We don\u2019t care about none of that. All that we all care about is winning a championship. And I\u2019m telling you, that\u2019s why we\u2019re playing the style of basketball we\u2019re playing right now.\u201d The Bucks were missing their MVP, Giannis Antetokounmpo, whose sprained right ankle kept him out of what turned out to be the final game for the team with the best regular season record in the league in each of the past two seasons. But the Heat had theirs in Butler, who has led the franchise to its first conference finals since 2014. Back then, LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh were finishing up a wild run of four straight trips to The Finals, including championships in 2012 and 2013. And he doesn\u2019t think this team has come close to playing its best yet. \u201cI don\u2019t think so,\u201d Butler said. \u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019ve played a full 48-minute game yet. And that\u2019s what\u2019s promising, is that if we do lock in and play from start to finish the way that we\u2019re capable of, the way we\u2019re supposed to, I think the game will be a lot easier. It\u2019s yet to happen, but we got to have it happen in the next round.\u201d Those \u201cHeatles\u201d title teams rode the wave of theirsuperstar trio to the top of the NBA mountain. This Butler-led Heat team is in this position, a league-best 8-1 in the postseason, because their superstar trusted the Heat\u2019s culture and the process. Butler also trusted his teammates. That includes veterans like Goran Dragic and Kelly Olynyk, who were already in Miami and played big minutes in the close out of the Bucks, and trade-deadline additions Jae Crowder and three-time champion Andre Iguodala, both of whom delivered handsomely on all that experience Tuesday. They also got important contributions from youngsters Bam Adebayo and Tyler Herro.  Spoelstra knows how tough it is to get here and how special it is. That was particularly true with a team that\u2019s endured its first season together amidst the coronavirus pandemic, the four-month season layoff and restart and the rigors of an unprecedented playoffs in this bubble. \u201cIt\u2019s not easy to get to the conference finals and our organization knows that,\u201d Spoelstra said. \u201cWe\u2019ve been trying desperately to get back to the conference finals. That\u2019s not our ultimate goal, we get it. But you could still acknowledge the journey, how hard it is to get to this point. That is why we brought Jimmy Butler here, that is why we put this team together with the veterans, adding Andre and Jae, building around Goran and Bam and adding to the young core. \u201cSo it\u2019s not easy to get to the conference finals, otherwise every team would be doing it. And we\u2019ve been at this for 25 years under the Riley-[Heat owner Mickey] Arison leadership. We\u2019ve tried every single year just to get to this level and it just shows you how competitive this league is. It doesn\u2019t happen every year and we don\u2019t take it for granted. We\u2019re grateful for the opportunity we\u2019ve had.\u201d What looked like a motley crew to the outside world when training camp began was the perfect situation to Butler after stops in Minnesota and Philadelphia the past two season did not agree with his sensibilities about the game. Butler was searching for a like-minded group of players, ones who compete with a chip on their shoulder, ones who were maybe overlooked, counted out or disregarded. He was looking for players like, well \u2026 Jimmy Butler. He was searching for guys like Crowder (16 points in Game 5) and Adebayo (13), Dragic (17) and Herro (14 off the bench, with several huge baskets down the stretch). Guys young and old(er) who would chase greatness the way he would. And they did, running down the Bucks after falling behind by 13 points in the first quarter with a furious 30-9 rally of their own to regain control. \u201cI just came in with a killer mindset,\u201d Herro said. \u201cI wanted to leave everything on the floor for my coaches and teammates. This was one game we needed, we needed one game to move to the next round and I just tried to bring everything I could and leave it out there on the floor. It was ugly but we got the win and that\u2019s all that mattered.\u201d So no, Butler\u2019s not surprised that his team is still playing. The Heat will celebrate this accomplishment \u2014 at least for a night or two per Spoelstra \u2014 before locking in on the conference finals. \u201cIt felt good at the end to obviously win it,\u201d Herro said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to enjoy this tonight and maybe tomorrow a little bit. But then we\u2019ll get back to work, because we\u2019ve still got some unfinished business.\u201d They\u2019re off to the best start for a team seeded fifth or lower since the playoffs were expanded in 1984. That\u2019s news that might even surprise Butler, who is finally getting his first taste of the conference finals. In fact, he probably won\u2019t care. Because in his eyes, the Heat are still only halfway to the ultimate goal. \u201cThis means a lot,\u201d Butler said. \u201cBut that\u2019s not my goal, that\u2019s not my guys\u2019 goal, that\u2019s not the organization\u2019s goal. We want to win it. We want a championship. And that\u2019s what we\u2019re focused on. These next eight [wins] are going to be much harder than the previous eight. We know that. But we\u2019re ready for it.\u201d * * * Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25752,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/celtics-raptors-notebook-3-things-ahead-game-6","date":"2020-09-09","title":"3 things to know ahead of Celtics-Raptors Game 6","content":" The defending champion Toronto Raptors are on the brink of elimination, down 3-2 in their Eastern Conference semifinals series against the Boston Celtics after Boston\u2019s most complete performance of the series . With Game 6 on Wednesday ( 6:30 p.m. ET, ESPN ), here are three things to know: Serge Ibaka was in a walking boot on Tuesday after suffering a left ankle injury in Game 5. As of late Tuesday night, his status for Game 6 was unknown. \u201cI will see how I wake up [Wednesday], because it\u2019s different,\u201d Ibaka said. \u201cWhen it happened last night, I felt like I could still play. Then today, this morning, it changed a little bit. So let\u2019s see tomorrow when I wake up.\u201d Both Nick Nurse (\u201cI think there\u2019s a good chance\u201d) and Fred VanVleet (\u201cI would be surprised if he wasn\u2019t out there\u201d) expressed confidence that Ibaka will be able to play in Game 6, but only time will tell. And the backup center\u2019s presence is critical, given how the Celtics are defending and given Marc Gasol\u2019s shooting issues. When the Raptors have run high pick-and-roll with their centers, whether the guard has used the screen or rejected it , Ibaka and Gasol have generally been open when they\u2019ve popped to the top of the 3-point arc. \u201cThey\u2019re gonna chase the ball with the big a lot,\u201d Nurse said. \u201c[Daniel] Theis is chasing the ball down the lane a lot, which obviously means your big can either roll or pop and get some kick-backs to him.\u201d Ibaka has been much more willing to take those shots, and he\u2019s 11-for-22 on above-the-break 3s in the series. Gasol, far less willing and far less accurate, is 0-for-10 in about the same number of minutes. He\u2019s been better inside the arc, but had a couple of rough-looking shots at the rim on Monday. Among 81 players with at least 50 field goal attempts in the playoffs, Ibaka (67.9%) ranks third in effective field goal percentage , while Gasol (43.0%) ranks 78th. Nurse acknowledged that, whether Ibaka plays or not, his team needs more from its starting center. \u201cWe don\u2019t need a ton,\u201d the coach said. \u201cIt\u2019s not like we need 25 from him. But we need him to chip in with some, just because there\u2019s opportunities there for him. As you well know, we need both him and Pascal [Siakam] to provide some offensive punch for us. That\u2019s when we\u2019re at our best, and we need to be at our best to win a game here.\u201d Siakam, 75th in effective field-goal percentage (44.4%) among those 81 players with at least 50 postseason field-goal attempts, is another story. The Raptors\u2019 leading scorer in the regular season has averaged just 15.8 points on 41% shooting in this series. It was noted after Game 1 how much Siakam\u2019s shooting suffers after the first six seconds of the shot clock. In the regular season, he had an effective field goal percentage of 65.7% in the first six seconds of the clock and just 47.4% in the last 18 seconds of the clock, according to Second Spectrum tracking. That differential (18.3%) was the fifth largest among 86 players with at least 100 field-goal attempts in the first six seconds. Siakam\u2019s 220 shots in the first six seconds were the ninth most in the league and accounted for a little more than 20% of his total field goal attempts. That ratio was about the same (14\/71, 19.7%) in the Raptors\u2019 first-round series against Brooklyn. In this series? Only two of Siakam\u2019s 79 field-goal attempts have come in the first six seconds of the shot clock. And the first of those wasn\u2019t in transition. It was a last-minute, after-timeout iso in Game 2 against Marcus Smart, who stripped him on the way up . (The Raptors were probably looking to iso against Kemba Walker there, but Smart seemingly figured out what they were doing and told Walker to guard OG Anunoby.) The one real transition bucket for Siakam came in the third quarter of Game 4. So the first answer to \u201cWhat\u2019s wrong with Pascal Siakam?\u201d is \u201cThe Celtics aren\u2019t letting him run.\u201d Two more issues, which are connected to the lack of transition opportunities, are Siakam\u2019s lack of layups and free throws. In the regular season, 34% of Siakam\u2019s shots came in the restricted area. In the first round, that number was 28% ( 20\/72 ). And in this series, it\u2019s just 19% ( 15\/79 ). He\u2019s made 11 (73%) of those 15 shots, but field goal percentage drops dramatically once you get outside of the restricted area, and Siakam has taken almost twice as many shots elsewhere in the paint (11-for-28) as he has in the restricted area. Tied to that is the lack of trips to the line. In the regular season, Siakam had a free throw rate of 27.4 attempts per 100 shots from the field. In the first round, he upped that to 33.3 per 100. But in this series, Siakam has just 14 free throw attempts with those 79 shots from the field, a rate of 17.7 per 100. Siakam has shot a reasonable 15-for-33 (45%) with Jaylen Brown defending him , but has just two free-throw attempts to go with those 33 shots from the field. He\u2019s shot 17-for-46 (37%) otherwise. Siakam saw a big drop in efficiency with his increase in usage this season. And without transition opportunities or free throws, it\u2019s been an even greater struggle for him to provide what the Raptors need offensively. This has been the ugliest series in these playoffs, with the Celtics and Raptors combining to score just 103.1 points per 100 possessions through five games. But it hasn\u2019t been so ugly on the Celtics end of the floor when Kemba Walker has been in the game. In 186 minutes with Walker on the floor in this series, the Celtics have scored 112.5 points per 100 possessions. In 54 minutes with him off the floor, they\u2019ve scored just 80.2 . Some of that latter number includes garbage time, but even in 45 minutes with Tatum on the floor without Walker, the Celtics have scored just 80 points on 99 possessions . One big difference has been their shooting. From outside the restricted area, the Celtics have shot 40.1% with Walker on the floor and 30.4% with him off the floor . Walker himself has shot 13-for-19 in between the restricted area and the 3-point line. The other big difference has been turnovers. With Walker on the floor, the Celtics have committed 13.5 turnovers per 100 possessions, a tick fewer than they averaged in the regular season (13.7). With Walker off the floor, they\u2019ve committed 25.6 turnovers per 100 possessions . Taking care of the ball has always been one of Walker\u2019s best qualities. The Hornets ranked first or second in turnover percentage in each of his last six seasons in Charlotte. This season, his 8.5 turnovers per 100 possessions used was the sixth lowest rate among 41 players with a usage rate of 25% or higher. In this series, against the team that ranked second in opponent turnover rate and needs to get out and run, Walker\u2019s ability to take care of the ball is even more critical than usual. * * * John Schuhmann is a senior stats analyst for NBA.com. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . It was the latest milestone for James, who holds additional records for most points, field goals, free throws, steals and minutes in postseason history. He is also third in assists and games played, and sixth in rebounds."},{"id":25786,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/report-bucks-marvin-williams-retires-nba","date":"2020-09-09","title":"Report: Marvin Williams retiring after 15 NBA seasons","content":" Milwaukee Bucks forward Marvin Williams, 33, is retiring from the NBA after 15 seasons, according to ESPN\u2019s The Undefeated . Per Marc J. Spears, Williams made his decision after the Bucks\u2019 Game 5 ouster at the hands of the Miami Heat in the Eastern Conference semifinals. \u201cI\u2019ve been very blessed. God has been very, very good to me,\u201d Williams said, per The Undefeated. The Atlanta Hawks in 2005 drafted Williams, who didn\u2019t even start in his lone season at North Carolina, based on his upside. He had the size, athleticism and diverse skill set to intrigue. Williams was bought out by the Charlotte Hornets in early February and signed with the Bucks days later. Prior to joining Milwaukee, Williams was averaging 6.7 points on 44.8% shooting, including 37.6% from 3-point range. A former No. 2 overall pick, Williams has also played for the Utah Jazz (2012-13). The veteran had been with the Hornets for five seasons before heading to Milwaukee. In 17 games with the Bucks, Williams averaged 4.0 ppg, 4.4 rpg and 1.1 apg while shooting 43.9% overall and 30.8% on 3-pointers. For his career, Williams averaged 10.2 points and 5.2 rebounds in 1072 NBA games."},{"id":25780,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/okc-thunder-billy-donovan-not-returning","date":"2020-09-09","title":"Thunder, Donovan agree to mutually part ways","content":" Billy Donovan won\u2019t return as coach of the Oklahoma City Thunder after five seasons, the team announced Tuesday night, ending a largely successful run that ought to make him an attractive candidate for jobs around the league. Donovan, who was at the end of his contract, took the Thunder to the playoffs every year and was a finalist for NBA Coach of the Year this season after his squad outperformed expectations and pushed the Houston Rockets to seven games in the first round of the playoffs. Donovan went 243-157 with Oklahoma City. \u201cI have a great respect and admiration for the players I coached in Oklahoma, and I also want to thank the coaches I worked with, who gave unbelievable time and expertise to our common goal,\u201d Donovan said in a statement. The Thunder and Donovan described his departure as a mutual decision. Oklahoma City general manager Sam Presti said he couldn\u2019t give Donovan the assurances he wanted about the future. \u201cIn knowing where he is and the caliber of coach he is, I wouldn\u2019t want to mislead him and tell him it was going to be a certain way and then have it not be that way,\u201d Presti said. \u201cBut ultimately, it was also five years and I think in his mind, it may have been time to move on. I totally respect that and I have a great deal of respect for him. I wish him nothing but the best.\u201d Before his run in Oklahoma City, Donovan led the University of Florida to two national championships and four Final Four appearances in 19 seasons. Donovan inherited All-Stars Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook when he was hired before the 2015-16 season. The Thunder reached the Western Conference finals, where they squandered a 3-1 lead against the Golden State Warriors. Durant left for the Warriors that offseason, shaking the franchise and its fans. But the Thunder bounced back \u2013 Westbrook was the league MVP and set a league record for triple-doubles in a season. It was the first of three straight seasons that Westbrook averaged a triple-double. The Thunder lost to the Rockets in the first round of the playoffs. The Thunder tried to assemble enough stars to compete with Golden State, trading for Paul George and Carmelo Anthony before the 2017-18 season. It didn\u2019t go as planned \u2013 the team went 48-34 and lost to the Utah Jazz in the first round of the playoffs. In 2018-19, the Thunder went 49-33 and George finished third in the MVP balloting. Oklahoma City lost in the first round again when Portland\u2019s Damian Lillard hit a deep game-winning 3-pointer over George in Game 5. Expectations for Oklahoma City were low after the Thunder traded Westbrook to the Houston Rockets for Chris Paul and sent George to the Los Angeles Clippers for Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Danilo Gallinari. Many weren\u2019t sure if Oklahoma City\u2019s new players would function well together \u2013 or if the group would stay together. Instead, Paul was an All-Star, Gilgeous-Alexander emerged as the team\u2019s top scorer and Gallinari had one of the best seasons of his career. The Thunder went 44-28 and nearly knocked off the Rockets in the first round of the playoffs. Presti said he wanted Donovan to return and even lobbied for him to be Coach of the Year. Donovan finished behind Toronto\u2019s Nick Nurse and Milwaukee\u2019s Mike Budenholzer. \u201cWe appreciate him greatly, and I think we were pretty clear about that before the playoffs started,\u201d Presti said. But with the Thunder stockpiling draft picks and Paul\u2019s future with the franchise uncertain, among other things, Presti understood Donovan\u2019s hesitation. \u201cI think he\u2019ll have other opportunities that may be more \u2014 just a little more certainty in terms of what that\u2019s going to look like beyond the next season,\u201d Presti said. \u201cAnd I respect that completely.\u201d"},{"id":25802,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/la-clippers-final-city-approval-build-inglewood-arena","date":"2020-09-09","title":"Clippers get city approval to build Inglewood arena","content":" INGLEWOOD, Calif. (AP) \u2014 The Los Angeles Clippers have received final approval from Inglewood\u2019s city government to begin construction on their new arena next summer. The Clippers announced the approval from the city council Tuesday, along with a joint deal to buy the publicly owned property on the arena site for $66.25 million. Clippers owner Steve Ballmer is building a privately financed 18,000-seat arena along with a practice facility and corporate offices for his NBA franchise, which has shared Staples Center downtown with the Los Angeles Lakers and the NHL\u2019s Los Angeles Kings since it opened in 1999. Ballmer intends to open his new arena in 2024, immediately following the expiration of his team\u2019s lease at Staples Center. The Clippers plan to break ground on the estimated $1.2 billion project in 2021. The Clippers immediately opened a wait list for season tickets at their new arena. The naming rights to the project currently called the Inglewood Basketball and Entertainment Center are already being shopped worldwide in a partnership with CAA Sports. \u201cToday is a new chapter for the Inglewood Basketball and Entertainment Center, as we move from the land use entitlement process and look toward construction,\u201d Clippers President of Business Operations Gillian Zucker said in a statement. \u201cEvery part of IBEC is being designed with purpose \u2013 with an unapologetic intensity that will define the experience together for players, musical talent and fans alike. This arena will prove, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that there is no replacement for live basketball and entertainment.\u201d Inglewood\u2019s approval was expected for a project that claims it will create 1,500 full-time jobs and $100 million in tax revenue over its first 15 years in business. The only major obstacle to Ballmer\u2019s plans to date has been the Madison Square Garden Company, which owned the venerable Forum just north of the Clippers\u2019 proposed site. MSG sued Inglewood, California Gov. Gavin Newsom and the state Legislature to slow Ballmer\u2019s progress, apparently fearing competition for concerts and other events. Ballmer, the former Microsoft CEO with an estimated net worth of about $75 billion, solved that problem in March by buying the Forum outright for $400 million in cash. He says he will continue to operate the famed home of the 1980s Showtime Lakers as a live music venue. The Clippers\u2019 arena site and the Forum are separated only by SoFi Stadium, the new $5 billion football arena and surrounding development built by Los Angeles Rams owner Stan Kroenke. SoFi Stadium opens Sunday with the Rams\u2019 season opener against the Dallas Cowboys. When the Clippers\u2019 new home is built, four significant arenas \u2013 SoFi Stadium contains a 6,000-seat performance venue in addition to the main football stadium \u2013 will sit one mile apart."},{"id":25772,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/reports-rockets-danuel-house-out-game-3","date":"2020-09-08","title":"Rockets' House out for Game 3 for personal reasons","content":" Rockets forward Danuel House will not be available for Tuesday\u2019s Game 3 against the Lakers, according to The Houston Chronicle\u2019s Jonathan Feigen House played 27 minutes in Game 2, scoring 13 points while adding five rebounds."},{"id":25794,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/giannis-antetokounmpo-game-5-status","date":"2020-09-08","title":"Giannis Antetokounmpo (ankle) out for Game 5 vs. Heat","content":" LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. (AP) \u2014 Reigning NBA MVP Giannis Antetokounmpo was ruled out of Game 5 of Milwaukee\u2019s Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Miami Heat because of a sprained right ankle. The Bucks listed Antetokounmpo as inactive, doing so about 45 minutes before Tuesday\u2019s matchup started. They entered the game trailing the best-of-seven series 3-1. Antetokounmpo clearly tried to get himself ready for Game 5. He was on the court about two hours before game time, getting some shots up, then did more strength and flexibility work with a member of the Bucks\u2019 staff. Bucks coach Mike Budenholzer watched the on-court session closely, before the team made the final decision. \u201cIt\u2019s just always good to see it with your eyes,\u201d Budenholzer said. Antetokounmpo sprained the ankle in the first quarter of Game 3, then played his usual minutes the rest of the way. He turned the same ankle the same way \u2014 inward \u2014 early in the second quarter of Game 4 and could not return. The Bucks lost Game 3 with Antetokounmpo, then found a way to win Game 4 in overtime even after playing the final 40 of the game\u2019s 53 minutes without their leading scorer and rebounder. Antetokounmpo had started all 43 of Milwaukee\u2019s postseason games since he joined the franchise as the 15th pick in the 2013 NBA draft. The last time the Bucks played a playoff contest without Antetokounmpo was April 28, 2013 \u2014 when they were swept out of the first round by the Heat. Antetokounmpo got plenty of treatment between games, but Bucks coach Mike Budenholzer indicated Monday \u2014 while acknowledging that there was still hope that the MVP would play in Game 5 \u2014 that the team would weigh the short-term benefit of him playing Tuesday against the long-term risk. \u201cWe have such a great sports and performance staff and just a high, high level of trust that they understand the big picture,\u201d Budenholzer said. \u201cThey\u2019ve been a part of all the decisions in the past and obviously going forward, and the trust level with them, the communication between them and Giannis \u2026 sometimes you have to protect him.\u201d Antetokounmpo is widely expected to win the MVP award for a second consecutive season after averaging 29.5 points, 13.6 rebounds and 5.6 assists. In the opening round of the playoffs against Orlando, he averaged 30.6 points, 16 rebounds and six assists on 59% shooting from the floor and 39% from 3-point range. But in the first three games of the series against the Heat, his offensive numbers cooled off considerably. He averaged 22.7 points, 13.3 rebounds and seven assists \u2014 shooting only 45% from the field and 15% from beyond the 3-point arc. He had 19 points in 11 minutes in Game 4, helping Milwaukee stay in the game early. Antetokounmpo is obviously a huge part of Milwaukee\u2019s plans going forward. It was almost exactly a year ago \u2014 Sept. 12, 2019 \u2014 when the Bucks held a preseason Town Hall meeting for fans, and one of them asked the panel that included Milwaukee general manager Jon Horst what the situation was with Antetokounmpo\u2019s long-term contract. \u201cOf course, he\u2019ll be offered a supermax extension,\u201d Horst said. The Bucks can make that move when free agency begins, possibly as early as mid-October. Such a deal would kick in for the 2021-22 season, and the mathematics before the pandemic hit said it would have been worth around $247 million. If the salary cap going forward takes a hit because of the amount of revenue the league and its teams lost this season, so would the total value of Antetokounmpo\u2019s next deal \u2014 though, by any measure, he\u2019ll be set for life. He\u2019s under contract for $27.5 million next season."},{"id":25813,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/bucks-hope-giannis-antetokounmpo-available-game-5","date":"2020-09-08","title":"Bucks hope Giannis Antetokounmpo can play in Game 5, but won't know until hours before tip","content":" UPDATE:  Giannis ruled out for Game 5  (Sep. 8, 5:45 p.m.) Both are nightmare scenarios, capable of scaring awake even the most seasoned, gnarled basketball coach in the middle of the night, screaming, shaking and calling out for \u201cMama!\u201d So which is worse: Losing your superstar player unexpectedly in the heat of a playoff game and having to adapt and improvise on the fly? Or knowing and dreading for 48 hours that you might not have him at all, well aware that your opponents are preparing accordingly? While Milwaukee\u2019s Giannis Antetokounmpo continued round-the-clock treatment Monday on his sprained right ankle, coach Mike Budenholzer could hedge on his answer only because he and the team thought Antetokounmpo might not even play in Game 4 against Miami Sunday. From that perspective, Antetokounmpo\u2019s 19 points in 11 minutes before he had to leave in the second quarter was all bonus. > Game 5: Tuesday, 6:30 ET on TNT Budenholzer explained that \u201clittle bit of an asterisk\u201d that carried the Bucks through the first nightmare. Antetokounmpo\u2019s availability for Game 5 Tuesday isn\u2019t expected to be known until the hours or minutes before tip. Antetokounmpo arrived at the arena on Tuesday wearing a walking boot. \u201cI would say generally speaking a player going down in a game [is worse],\u201d the coach said. \u201cThe thing that made this one a little bit unique, there was some chance he wasn\u2019t going to play. So there was some thought and preparation put into \u2018What if Giannis didn\u2019t play\u2019 from the tip. \u201cBut if you\u2019re going into a game with a totally healthy player and he is unexpectedly injured, there are things you\u2019ve got to adjust and do on the fly.\u201d To the Bucks\u2019 credit, they did all those things, strategically and emotionally, winning in overtime 118-115 to stave off elimination by sweep. Multiple players, notably Khris Middleton, picked up the slack left by Antetokounmpo\u2019s departure. They got outscored from the foul line and the 3-point arc, yet managed to dominate in the paint without their potent primary trespasser there. The Bucks swiped or pounced on the basketball when it got loose, got many of their preferred shots, took advantage when the Heat relaxed a bit and survived. \u201cDid we put ourselves in a hole? Absolutely,\u201d guard Wesley Matthews told reporters Monday. \u201cAre we gonna be punks about it? Absolutely not.\u201d Now it\u2019s on to Nightmare No. 2: Anticipating an elimination game minus the NBA\u2019s likely repeat Kia Most Valuable Player and its certified Kia Defensive Player of the Year on your side. Against a Miami bunch that has been feistier most of the series, now chapped from letting Game 4 slip away, and no doubt rooting for the Bucks\u2019 possible short-handedness. \u201cWe anticipate him playing, being ready to go, being the player that he is,\u201d Heat veteran Andre Iguodala said. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to be able to adjust with him \u2026 and adjust better without him. \u201cThey\u2019re not going to come in with a flat game,\u201d Iguodala also said. \u201cThey\u2019re desperate and they\u2019re going to play like it.\u201d For the record, Antetokounmpo participated in the Bucks\u2019 workout session Monday morning on the Disney campus. Also for the record, the team did nothing strenuous that a guy in a walking boot couldn\u2019t handle. \u201cOn the court, we literally just walked through a couple of defensive things, a couple offensive things, just kind of stationary in the half court,\u201d Budenholzer said. \u201cHe was able to participate in that, but I think it wasn\u2019t much, so don\u2019t read too much into that.\u201d Sliding over into that top player spot again for Milwaukee, if Antetokounmpo is out or plays at less than full health, will be Middleton. Besides his vital numbers \u2014 36 points, eight rebounds, eight assists \u2014 he kept shooting regardless of his percentage (12-of-28) and made many of the Bucks\u2019 offensive decisions to orchestrate the victory. Said Iguodala: \u201cHe has a really strong skill set scoring the ball. Not a particularly quick player but he has a great fast-slow, slow-fast change of speed, which is the hardest to guard. He\u2019s got a really good handle and \u2026 he\u2019s very fluid. More than capable 3-point shooter. And then gets to the mid-range, which is kind of a lost art in the playoffs. But it\u2019s very needed, as we saw.\u201d Middleton\u2019s teammates know he\u2019s not the Greek Freak as far as elite status in the league. Not as overtly competitive, either. (Not in the way Antetokounmpo spit out to a few of them as he lay on the court, cursing and grabbing his ankle, \u201cI should have dunked it!\u201d) But he\u2019s no distant second in their eyes. \u201cHe\u2019s really flourishing,\u201d Matthews said of the Middleton. \u201cHe\u2019s stepping up in a big moment. And not only on the offensive end. \u2026 This is the most vocal I\u2019ve ever seen Khris.\u201d Budenholzer went to a four-guard attack for a while Sunday. Eric Bledsoe had the ball in his hands more without Antetokounmpo around as primary ball handler. And Brook Lopez got more work in the low post, with less need to open lanes for Giannis\u2019 romps through the paint. Those tweaks give Miami new things to think about for Game 5. But most of the heavy-duty thought process will stay with Milwaukee, because playing Antetokounmpo even if he says he\u2019s ready isn\u2019t an easy decision. As Budenholzer said: \u201cSometimes you have to listen to the player, sometimes you have to protect him.\u201d The Bucks coach said the medical staff will have the most input, tasked with weighing the condition of Antetokounmpo\u2019s sprained ankle now against further injury that might come if he risks playing on it. \u201cOrganizationally we have such a great sports performance staff,\u201d Budenholzer said. \u201cJust a high level of trust that they understand the big picture. They\u2019ve been a part of all the decisions in the past, and obviously going forward. The trust level with them, the communication between them and Giannis.\u201d Having Antetokounmpo for Game 5 in a series that might end in five or six games anyway is a bad bargain if it adversely affects the guy Milwaukee hopes to have for the next one or six or 10 seasons. \u201cLooking at everything, assessing everything together, we\u2019ll continue to make decisions that protect and keep Giannis in a position where he\u2019s healthy and has a long, long, healthy career and is still available to us and giving us what he can.\u201d * * * Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980.
