The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25843,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/bucks-save-season-game-4-overtime-heat","date":"2020-09-07","title":"Without Giannis Antetokounmpo, Bucks' supporting cast unites to save season","content":"It\u2019s time for Giannis Antetokounmpo to start thinking about what he needs to do to win a championship. Based on the Sunday performance of so many Milwaukee Bucks not named Antetokoumpo, perhaps the ensemble of Larry O\u2019Brien lifting help is right where he needs it. There in the Bucks locker room, picking him up figuratively \u2026 after picking him up literally, when he fell to the court early in the second quarter of Game 4 of their East semifinal series against Miami. > Game 5: Heat vs. Bucks, Tuesday at 6:30 ET on TNT Antetokounmpo aggravated the sprained right ankle first rolled in Game 3 on Friday, part of the meltdown that dropped them into this 3-0 hole. It was severe enough that the reigning Kia MVP left the game at 10:18 of the second quarter and never returned. History, according to the NBA, already had the Bucks as dead deer walking, facing the same inevitable elimination that came for the first 139 teams to open a best-of-seven series by losing the first three. But to lose Antetokounmpo, the league\u2019s likely repeat MVP and certified top defender of 2019-20? Against this Heat squad that had been more resourceful, more tenacious and playing to its own high standards from the series\u2019 start? Why of course. The remaining Bucks, down 31-30 when Antetokounmpo exited, outscored Miami 88-84 for a 118-115 overtime victory on the Walt Disney World campus. Made no sense. Wouldn\u2019t have bet on it. Yet bubblicious, in an admirable way. This sort of stuff happens occasionally in sports, and in this case there were a few contributing factors: * The remaining Bucks were desperate. With Antetokounmpo gone, they really knew their season was about to end, banishing them from the bubble into an offseason of undetermined length and indefinite futures. You don\u2019t earn the No. 1 seed in the conference two years running only to be so rudely dispatched. Most have heard the chatter through two playoff quests that Antetokounmpo\u2019s teammates might not be up to the task of properly chasing a championship with, and for, him. Yet just when it seemed some of them \u2014 along with coach Mike Budenholzer \u2014 might have been working their last games with the Bucks, they spoke up against that. Loudly, for a night. \u201c[Giannis] was laying it on the line out there for us. His ankle already was in bad shape,\u201d Bucks wing Khris Middleton said, after the postseason performance of his life (36 points, eight rebounds, eight assists). Antetokounmpo had, in fact, scored 19 points in 11 minutes, leading Milwaukee back from an early 12-point deficit to one once he got hurt. \u201cHowever long he was out there, he was giving it his all,\u201d Middleton said. \u201cWe had to have his back.\u201d * Miami relaxed. Jimmy Butler even said so afterward, admitting that the focus and drive that had carried his team to the 3-0 start and seven victories without defeat in the postseason flickered Sunday. \u201cWe did what all of us said we can\u2019t do, and that\u2019s get comfortable,\u201d Butler said. \u201cWe thought this game was going to be easy and it was not. \u2026 We knew what we had to do coming into this game.\u201d Human nature? Sure. Costly against a wounded foe? Sure. \u201cI feel like we played like we were up 3-0,\u201d said center Bam Adebayo. \u201cI feel like we got complacent a little bit. \u2026 And they just kept playing.\u201d Heat coach Erik Spoelstra said it unfolding in defensive lapses that hurt \u2014 baseline cuts, offensive rebounds, Bucks shooters getting to their preferred spots. Uncharacteristic for them. \u201cWe didn\u2019t defend with the level of detail and effort and concentration,\u201d Spoelstra said. \u201cThe reality is, they deserved to win this game. They were playing harder, they were doing things with more force, more consistency, getting us off our spots in our offense.\u201d More force, consistency and motion looked good on the Bucks, who can often look deferential and passive while Antetokounmpo attacks and buckles under swarms of defenders. * Milwaukee\u2019s options were limited. This is the more complicated factor, with the implication that a few of the Bucks\u2019 best players after Antetokounmpo might play more free-and-easy when they can\u2019t defer to his game. It happens all the time for reserves who step in for an injured teammate \u2014 they know they\u2019re getting their minutes that night, no quick hook, so they\u2019re able to get into a rhythm. With the Bucks, Middleton, Brook Lopez and Eric Bledsoe knew the ball was going to be in their hands at levels rarely experienced \u2014 Antetokounmpo topped the NBA this season with a 37.5 usage rate. Someone had to pick up the slack, or Miami might have started playing make-it-take-it. So in addition to Middleton\u2019s firepower stretched across 48 of the 53 minutes, the Bucks got 14 from Lopez, Bledsoe\u2019s most active game (14 points, 10 rebounds, 6 assists) and even 10 points and five boards from Donte DiVincenzo. The second-year guard from Villanova had looked overmatched in the previous games but wound up a game-high plus-22 in his 27 minutes. The biggest one came when he salvaged a possession in the final seconds of regulation by drawing a foul on Goran Dragic. With 1.9 left, his team down 107-106, DiVincenzo missed the first foul shot but hit the second to trigger the overtime. Middleton went over to rub the kid\u2019s shoulders, assuring him that he had made the free throw they\u2019d needed. That\u2019s sort of what Middleton and the rest of them did with Antetokounmpo, assuring him they\u2019d cover for him for a night. \u201cThe Greek Freak\u201d hobbled out of AdventHealth Arena in a walking boot, with nothing but guesses for 24-to-48 hours whether he would be able to play Game 5 on that ankle. Regardless, the energy and passion, the aggression and movement and urgency the other Bucks showed need to be there. Not just Tuesday but whenever they start their next playoff series together. * * * Steve Aschburner has written about the NBA since 1980. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25821,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/usa-basketball-hof-statement-tom-jernstedt","date":"2020-09-07","title":"Hall of Fame, USA Basketball mourn death of Tom Jernstedt","content":" SPRINGFIELD, MASS. \u2013 The Basketball Hall of Fame Family celebrates the life and mourns the passing of legendary basketball administrator Tom Jernstedt. Jernstedt, enshrined as a member of the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2017, has passed away at the age of 75. \u201cTom Jernstedt was a humble and unsung steward of the game,\u201d said John L. Doleva, President and CEO of the Basketball Hall of Fame. \u201cUnder his direction, the NCAA Men\u2019s Basketball Tournament grew into a phenomenon that brings college basketball fans together on a global scale. He will forever be remembered as the Father of the Final Four and one of the most respected leaders in basketball.\u201d Tom Jernstedt\u2019s introduction to the NCAA came as a reserve on the University of Oregon football team. Despite a lack of playing time, he proved himself to be a leader in athletics. While football was his primary interest early in life, he would leave a lasting mark on basketball starting in 1972 when he was hired as the director of events at the NCAA and worked his first Final Four. Nearly 50 years later, the madness and the magic of March still reflects the vision and the leadership Jernstedt brought to the NCAA throughout his career. He helped steer the NCAA Tournament through television contracts, tournament expansion, the shift to domed stadiums, and the selection process. He also served as the President of USA Basketball from 2001 to 2004 and was the 2001 recipient of the John Bunn Lifetime Achievement Award. USA Basketball CEO Jim Tooley issued the following statement regarding the passing of  Jernstedt: USA Basketball is greatly saddened to learn of the passing of Tom Jernstedt. A USA Basketball Board of Directors member for many years and the USA Basketball president from 2001-04, Tom was a steadfast supporter and a tireless contributor to USA Basketball, international basketball and the NCAA. He cared greatly about the sport of basketball and even more about the athletes and coaches who represented USA Basketball. Tom was a good friend and mentor to me and to many others at USA Basketball. He will be missed. Our thoughts and prayers go to the Jernstedt family."},{"id":25831,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/disney-world-diary-lessons-learned-nba-campus","date":"2020-09-06","title":"Disney World Diary: Advice after life on NBA campus","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 My colleague Sekou Smith is about to be released from NBA quarantine soon and since he won\u2019t know what\u2019ll hit him besides sunshine and humidity at first, I should fill him in on what\u2019s up around here. First: Don\u2019t miss coronavirus testing. Second: Don\u2019t miss coronavirus testing. Once he follows those orders, he\u2019ll be exposed to another world here in this basketball ecosystem. It\u2019s not perfect; nothing ever is. The NBA worked without a parachute and a blueprint while devising a way to continue the season on this campus, collect that all-important TV revenue, and keep everyone safe. But by and large, this operation is a success so far, because of the high level of basketball performances and non-existent number of positive tests. So here\u2019s what Sekou will discover once he gets his equilibrium and his wits following a week locked inside a small hotel room, and my advice for him: \u2022 This is a basketball paradise, an NCAA tournament in one place, only with superior players and better refereeing. The chance to see multiple NBA teams on a single day, either playing a game or practicing it, is once-in-a-lifetime stuff. Luxuriate in it. \u2022 Being inside the arena will seem surreal at first, with no fans or halftime acts and an atmosphere that\u2019s largely artificially created. But the noise created by emotional players and coaches and shifting sneakers is very real and pure. Bring your ears as well as your eyes and they will be treated to the sounds of basketball. \u2022 Don\u2019t worry about stepping on a gecko even if dozens will scatter in your path every day once you open your door. Those reptilian critters are quicker than a juicy rumor. \u2022 Always bring a jacket to Florida in summertime because they overdo it on the air conditioning. You go from sauna to Siberia in a hurry. \u2022 Don\u2019t waste your time requesting a one-on-one interview with LeBron James. King don\u2019t do those. Not yesterday, today, tomorrow, next week or next year. Not here, either. \u2022 But do spend time with Jaylen Brown of the Celtics. It\u2019ll be more meaningful. He\u2019s thoughtful, smart, well-versed and beyond his years. You might even talk basketball with him.  \u2022 Kyle Speller, who\u2019s employed by the Nuggets, is one of four NBA public address announcers invited to voice these games. His enthusiasm and signature style \u2014 yeeahhhbaby! \u2014 is Rucker Park-like and will turn you into a huge fan. \u2022 The teams normally practice on courts installed at the Coronado hotel ballroom and the hallways to those courts make for some, um, interesting if not uncomfortable path-crossing scenes. The morning after the Raptors beat the Celtics on a buzzer-beater, both teams held practice just a few dozen yards away from each other, roughly at the same time. There wasn\u2019t much acknowledging by players en route. \u2022 You will have chicken as a meal choice on Sunday, Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and probably Saturday. \u2022 Do not, under any circumstances, wear a suit or button-down shirt to work. You will get clowned. Dress down like the coaches and your fellow media folk and blend in. \u2022 Rent a bike, even you haven\u2019t ridden one in years. Pedaling will be therapeutic and a good way to clear your head and prepare for the busy day. Make sure to say hello to the power-walking Heat coach on the road that laps the hotel. Erik Spoelstra starts his rounds at roughly 9 am daily. \u2022 There\u2019s a big lake at the hotel so go ahead and grab a rod , although there\u2019s a rumor going around that everyone catches the same one fish. \u2022 Pace yourself, plan accordingly, use time management and make every day count. Understand that this bold experiment by the NBA isn\u2019t sustainable. The price is too steep \u2014 around $175 million? \u2014 and the sacrifices made by everyone involved is too great. And this is just for 22 invited teams over four months, not 30 teams and 82 games plus post-season. \u2022 Finally: Make full use of this chance to reconnect socially with your NBA family, meaning players, coaches, media, league employees, etc. Been a long time since you last saw them. With this pandemic, who knows when you\u2019ll see them again? My time here is done. This assignment from the basketball gods was an honor and pleasure. After two-plus months, I\u2019m headed home. But first, I\u2019m checking my luggage for any gecko castaways. * * * Shaun Powell has covered the NBA for more than 25 years. You can e-mail him  here , find his archive here   and follow him on  Twitter  . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting."},{"id":25849,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/game-2-nuggets-clippers-analysis","date":"2020-09-06","title":"Mike Malone challenges Nuggets, who find their physicality","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 Mike Malone demanded a response from his team. He knew their Game 1 effort against the Los Angeles Clippers in the Western Conference semifinals was a sinister mix of fatigue from an emotional Game 7 grind against the Utah Jazz in their first-round series and the Clippers sensing doubt in the opposition and pouncing. So with another day between games to stew on what went wrong, to digest all the chatter about his team being out of its league, the Nuggets\u2019 coach had all the motivation tools needed to stoke the competitive fire of his team. Don\u2019t take the first punch. Deliver it. And keep swinging. It worked spectacularly early as the Nuggets built an early 23-point lead behind the 1-2 punch of Nikola Jokic and Jamal Murray in a wire-to-wire 110-101 Game 2 victory Saturday. That Nuggets team that ran out of gas after the first quarter Thursday night, morphed back into the energized bunch that battled from 3-1 down against the Jazz to win that series. The change in demeanor, the increase in physicality, is what Malone expected from his crew. \u201cI don\u2019t think it\u2019s hard at all,\u201d Malone said. \u201cI mean, this is playoff basketball. If you don\u2019t have a physical mindset you\u2019re going to be going home early. I thought we had a physical mindset in that Utah series coming back from a 3-1 deficit and tonight we were a noticeably different team than we were in Game 1. \u201c Those same guts and mettle they displayed in that comeback against the Jazz was require to survive the second half Saturday night. The Clippers closed within single digits multiple times in the fourth quarter, but each time the Nuggets got an answer from defensive ace Gary Harris, who nailed three huge 3-pointers to help secure the win. Harris was playing in just his fourth game since the season restarted here in the Orlando bubble. He was rehabbing a hip injury that and isn\u2019t yet in his normal game shape. But he\u2019s still sharp enough to have made the clutch steal on Donovan Mitchell in the closing seconds of that Game 7 win over Utah. Harris and Murray nailed 3-pointers on back-to-back possessions in the final minutes to help hold the Clippers off down the stretch. \u201cHe gave us a big boost on offense and since Game 6 [of the Utah series] he\u2019s been giving us a big boost on defense,\u201d Murray said. \u201cThat\u2019s what he does and that\u2019s what we expect of him. And he\u2019s had a great transition from not playing to coming back and starting and being a big part of what we do.\u201d Jerami Grant led a swarming and relentless defensive effort on Kawhi Leonard as the Nuggets held the reigning Finals MVP to his worst game of this postseason (13 points on 4-for-17 shooting) and his lowest-scoring playoff game since 2016. Leonard\u2019s streak of playoff games scoring at least 15 points was halted at 47. Harris did a similar job on Paul George, who led the Clippers with 22 points (7-19 FGs, 4-10 3Ps). Harris\u2019s 13 points (including a 4-for-7 shooting effort from beyond the 3-point line) proved just as critical. \u201cOur defensive, our activity and the fact that we were willing to help each other [improved],\u201d Malone said. \u201cI thought Jerami Grant\u2019s defense on Kawhi was spectacular. But the four guys behind him were giving the necessary help. I thought Gary Harris\u2019 defense on Paul George was terrific. But the help behind that was what we needed, what we didn\u2019t have in Game 1.\u201d That initial punch from Jokic and Murray was also missing from Game 1. After exhausting themselves in that wild Game 7 against Utah, they were spent by the end of the first quarter in Game 1 against the Clippers. They made up for it in the opening minutes of Game 2, taking turns attacking and setting the tone. They owned the floor before halftime \u2014 when the Nuggets led led 72-56 \u2014 combining for 44 points (24 from Jokic; 20 from Murray). They combined for a total of 27 in that Game 1 wipeout. \u201cWe were tired,\u201d Murray said. \u201cWe came out sloppy, we came out exhausted, we didn\u2019t make shots and it showed.\u201d Clippers coach Doc Rivers noticed the difference from the start in Game 2. Jokic knocked down three wide-open 3-pointers early, Murray was attacking and getting to his spots and his team was trying to climb out of that hole all night. \u201cJokic had like 30 seconds to shoot those first three 3s,\u201d Rivers said. \u201cHe\u2019s a good player to begin with. But when we gift him nine points, he\u2019s just going to get more confident. I thought Murray was dominant and I thought Jokic was just as dominant in the first quarter. Honestly, I thought they just played more aggressive. They got into us the entire game.\u201d They did exactly what Malone asked them to do. They responded the way he expected a team that\u2019s playing in the conference semifinals for a second straight season to respond when smacked in the mouth the way the Nuggets were in Game 1. And now things really get interesting. Because the Clippers get a day to digest what went wrong, what they can do better and figure out an appropriate response. Their path to the conference finals and beyond won\u2019t come easy. It won\u2019t come without a fight from a Nuggets team that is convinced it belongs. \u201cOur group believes in themselves,\u201d Malone said. \u201cWe\u2019ve shown that we\u2019re a very resilient group that can execute and find ways to win in close games down the stretch. It\u2019s great to be able to tie this series up and have that life and belief going into the next game.\u201d Sekou Smith is a veteran NBA reporter and NBA TV analyst. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting"},{"id":25857,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/celtics-raptors-game-4-analysis-0","date":"2020-09-06","title":"Raptors scramble Celtics offense, create massive 3-point margin","content":" The team that has shot better from 3-point range has won each of the four games of the Eastern Conference semifinal series between the Toronto Raptors and Boston Celtics. In fact, OG Anunoby\u2019s buzzer-beating game winner in Game 3 was the difference between the Raptors shooting better or worse than the Celtics from beyond the arc on Thursday. The Raptors had a much bigger edge in Game 4 on Saturday, shooting 17-for-44 (39%) from 3-point range on their way to a much more comfortable, 100-93 victory that tied the series at two games apiece. The pivotal Game 5 is Monday (6:30 ET, TNT). \u201cIt\u2019s a huge part of the game,\u201d Raptors coach Nick Nurse said of the 3-point shooting \u201cWe\u2019re trying to defend \u2019em at a super high level and challenge \u2019em, and we\u2019re certainly trying to create good ones for our guys to step into and shoot \u2019em.\u201d > Game 5: Celtics vs. Raptors, Monday at 6:30 ET on TNT To that first part, it should be acknowledged that Jaylen Brown, who shot 42% on catch-and-shoot 3s in the regular season ( 39% in the playoffs through Game 3 ), missed some open and in-rhythm looks on Saturday. The Celtics were 7-for-35 (20%) from 3-point range and Brown (2-for-11) attempted five more 3s than any of his teammates. But, upon review of the film, less than half of the Celtics\u2019 28 misses from beyond the arc were open and in-rhythm. The Raptors did challenge a lot of those 3s, even though their priorities on that end of the floor start with defending the dribble. \u201cIt\u2019s always most important that we get \u2019em in the half-court,\u201d Nurse said. \u201cOnce you get \u2019em in the half-court it\u2019s probably containing the ball, and trying as best we can to keep the ball in front of us.\u201d These days, with hand-checking disallowed, keeping the ball in front of you often requires multiple defenders. And the Raptors are probably the most aggressive team in the league in regard to putting extra bodies (and arms) in front of the ball-handler. They pinch off shooters one pass away in an effort to both keep the offense from getting all the way to the basket and force turnovers. In the regular season, the Raptors were the only team that ranked in the top five in both the (lowest) percentage of their opponents\u2019 shots that came in the restricted area (30%, 5th) and opponent turnovers per 100 possessions (16.5, 2nd ). The other side of that coin is that the Raptors will allow a lot of 3s. But that doesn\u2019t mean that they will happily concede those 3s. Yes, there will be some open ones, like the two from either corner that Brown missed in the first four minutes on Saturday. But no team can contest every shot. And the champs are the best in the league at scrambling out of two-to-the-ball situations, rotating, and contesting as much as they possibly can. Yes, it\u2019s a make-or-miss league. But not all misses are the same. Here is some of the champs\u2019 best work in forcing tough 3s from the Celtics in Game 4: Play 1 Pascal Siakam is on the bottom row of the Raptors\u2019 2-3 zone and has both feet well inside the paint when Jayson Tatum throws a dart to Marcus Smart in the left corner. But Siakam sells out and jumps like he would if he was trying to dunk the ball from the free-throw line, running Smart off the catch-and-shoot 3. He even manages to contest the side-step 3 with a quick second jump. Play 2 Matt Thomas matches up with Semi Ojeleye in the right corner in transition, but quickly rotates up to stop Tatum with the ball. Tatum swings it to Ojeleye, who elicits another all-out close-out from Siakam. Thomas rotates back to Ojeleye and Lowry rotates to Tatum, whose fall allows the Raptors to reset. Thomas then switches a Kemba Walker-Ojeleye pick-and-roll and is able to avoid the foul on Walker\u2019s step-back 3 (though Walker would probably disagree on the avoiding-the-foul part). Play 3 Kyle Lowry sinks into the paint to help Fred VanVleet on Brown\u2019s drive, but is still able to run Smart off the catch-and-shoot 3 from the left wing. And like Siakam in the first play, he recovers to contest the side-step 3. Play 4 The Celtics\u2019 after-timeout play has Walker curling to the ball off a Grant Williams screen. VanVleet\u2019s pressure pushes Walker\u2019s catch far beyond the 3-point line. Serge Ibaka meets Walker on the other side of a Brad Wanamaker screen, Lowry rotates to Wanamaker\u2019s pop, and Siakam guards two guys until Ibaka recovers. VanVleet then defends Walker\u2019s late-clock iso about as well as one can, though the Raptors do give up an offensive rebound. Play 5 The Raptors push a double-drag screen for Walker far beyond the 3-point line. Marc Gasol retreats to stay with Daniel Theis\u2019 roll to the rim, but VanVleet is able to contest a potential pull-up 3 from behind. Siakam stays in front of Brown, and when Siakam falls, Gasol steps up and OG Anunoby rotates down to guard Theis. Tatum is open on the right wing, but Anunoby runs him off the catch-and-shoot 3 and the side-step attempt is off the mark. The Celtics do get another offensive board. That is a lot of ridiculous effort on the defensive end of the floor. \u201cWe weren\u2019t really switched on to Game 1,\u201d Nurse said. \u201cBut other than that game I think we\u2019ve tried hard. I think there\u2019s been some effort and some desire and some toughness, and trying to carry it through for most possessions. \u201cEach possession seems to be pretty critical in a playoff game, and we\u2019re getting to the point where we\u2019re playing most of the possessions as, we\u2019re trying hard. We\u2019re making some mistakes and they\u2019ve got good players and they make shots and some things like that, but we\u2019re down and we\u2019re trying to compete is the biggest thing.\u201d As seen on those last two plays above, the Raptors\u2019 rotations do leave them susceptible on the glass. But their defensive rebounding percentage has higher in the playoffs (76.4%, 7th ) than it was in the regular season (72.1%, 22nd ). And it\u2019s been higher in this series (80.1%) than it was in the first round ( 73.6% ). Rebounding is important, but the most critical thing you can do defensively is force your opponent to miss shots. The Raptors do that both near and far from the basket. Not only did they rank second in opponent field goal percentage in the restricted area (59.3%) in the regular season, but they ranked first in opponent 3-point percentage (33.7%). The Celtics probably won\u2019t shoot 20% from beyond the arc like they did in Game 4 again, but they might not shoot 44% like they did in Game 1 again either. And even when the Celtics made 10 corner 3s in Game 1, they scored a well-below-average 106 points per 100 possessions (112 on 106). This series is the first time the Celtics have been held under 110 points per 100 possessions in four straight games since a 2-3 road trip in mid-November. \u201cThat\u2019s our foundation,\u201d VanVleet said, \u201cbeing able to get stops. As long as we continue to do that at a high level, we give ourselves a chance to win, and we got to keep meeting the challenge. It\u2019s a really, really hard team to guard but I think we are doing a great job trying to meet the challenge.\u201d The Raptors\u2019 own offense has had its issues. Toronto ranks seventh offensively out of eight teams in this round. But they\u2019re certainly able to win ugly, so consistently good defensively that they\u2019re now 45-3 ( 5-0 in the playoffs ) when they\u2019ve scored at least 105 points per 100 possessions. \u201cI think we know who we are,\u201d VanVleet said Saturday. \u201cI think we\u2019re just being OK being uncomfortable and not being pretty. I think we can win in many different ways and I think that we\u2019re very versatile and just trying to keep continuing to find ways to win. \u201cIt\u2019s not always going to be pretty but I think we\u2019re comfortable with how ugly and mucky the game is now. Now we would like it not to be that way but you\u2019ve got to take what you get and that\u2019s a great team that we\u2019re going up against, and we\u2019ll take any wins that we can get, take any success that we can get. So we put up 100 and we were able to hold them to 93 and that\u2019s the name of the game at this point in the year.\u201d John Schuhmann is a senior stats analyst for NBA.com. You can e-mail him here , find his archive here and follow him on Twitter . The views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Turner Broadcasting"},{"id":25837,"link":"https:\/\/www.nba.com\/news\/questions-facing-bucks-giannis","date":"2020-09-05","title":"With Bucks down 3-0, scrutiny falls on Giannis Antetokounmpo","content":" ORLANDO, Fla. \u2014 He will sign the richest contract in the history of American professional sports by next summer \u2014 if he chooses to do so. He will also, in all likelihood, win his second straight Kia MVP award in a few weeks. And if you fell from another planet and started watching this second-round playoff series between the Bucks and Heat, you\u2019d assume this is a tale about Jimmy Butler. >> Game 2: Heat go for the sweep Sunday (3:30 ET, ABC)  But no, no. This is Giannis Antetokounmpo, who has everything a superstar wants, and suddenly a few things he doesn\u2019t: Questions about his ability to lead a team to the promised land. Those conversations are being amplified here on the eve of a potential sweep, with Butler and the Heat bringing the brooms instead of Giannis and the team with the NBA\u2019s best record. Giannis is down alarmingly in the second round to a lower seed, and in this type of situation, all eyes are seared in the direction of the player who earns all the goodies. Should the Heat finish him off \u2014 and no team in NBA history has rallied from 3-0 in a best-of-seven \u2014 Giannis will deal with a level of scrutiny like none before in his otherwise stunning NBA career. His flaws are being magnified and exploited right now and his trend of going silent in the fourth-quarter stretch in this series will solidify if it hasn\u2019t already. He might find that shaking a reputation can be a lot harder than shaking a few defenders on his way to the hoop. Mainly, he\u2019ll need to go back to the lab this offseason and fine-tune his skills, starting with his outside shooting. That part of his game still lags, and although Giannis has gained more confidence in that shot over the last year, it has failed spectacularly against Miami, where he\u2019s 2-for-13. The Heat, therefore, are giving Giannis all the room he wants on the perimeter, leaving him open, daring him to aim from 20 feet, watching him misfire. He\u2019s most dangerous when he runs downhill to the basket, a 6-foot-10 forward who covers the space between midcourt and the rim in roughly four gallops, collecting fouls and breaking spirits along the way. But again: When your jumper isn\u2019t being respected, you start seeing layers of defenders standing in the paint and waiting and often drawing offensive fouls. Or, in the case of ace defenders Butler and Bam Adebayo, you get stripped of the ball en route. Problem is, Giannis tweaked his ankle midway through Game 3 and had to endure the remainder of the game operating at less than 100%. With only one day\u2019s rest between games here at Disney, there\u2019s not ample recovery time; the Bucks called off Saturday\u2019s practice. There\u2019s also another issue at stake: Giannis\u2019 level of bloodthirstiness. This can only be tested in the postseason, when the stakes are high and demands on superstars are heavy. This cold-hearted approach is very apparent in the eyes, demeanor and take-charge-ness of Butler, who like the majority of NBA players has far less physical ability than Giannis . Milwaukee searched for leadership in the fourth quarter of Game 3 and found none, being outscored by 27 points in the period. Giannis is still waiting to deliver a signature moment in this series. He missed 14-of-21 shots in Game 3 with three turnovers, far from the level he enjoyed in a season that saw him average almost 30 and 14 and win Kia Defensive Player of the Year. \u201cI am in a good place,\u201d Giannis insisted. \u201c Obviously, if there is a team that can come back against a team from 3-0, and beat them, it can be us. \u201d The plight that the Bucks find themselves in can also be taken another way, that perhaps Giannis doesn\u2019t have the right mix of players around him. This song and verse has been heard before. Is Khris Middleton a true and solid deputy to Giannis? Does Eric Bledsoe have the chops to match up with the league\u2019s other floor leaders at point guard? What happens if the Bucks fail to hit open 3-pointers and do they have the personnel for that or an emergency plan other than throw the ball to Giannis. \u201cI believe in my teammates, I trust my teammates, I love my teammates and I want my teammates to be confident,\u201d Giannis said. \u201cWe can do it.\u201d Also: Why isn\u2019t Giannis playing more than 33-34 minutes a night, especially here in the postseason where it\u2019s all-hands-on-deck? These are nervous times in Milwaukee because the fate of the franchise rests with Giannis. No other team is more dependent on a superstar, both on and off the court, than the Bucks are with Giannis. He helped build a downtown arena with all the bells and whistles, made the Bucks a title contender, put a small-market town on the basketball map and influenced many personnel decisions. Didn\u2019t the Bucks give Middleton an astonishing contract extension \u2014 he\u2019ll make $40 million in 2023-24 alone, rich for a No. 2 option guy \u2014 partly to show Giannis how committed they are? Same for Bledsoe, who\u2019ll make $19 million in his final year? And what about when Giannis\u2019 deal comes up next summer, when almost every team in the NBA will clear salary cap room in what will be the next great free-agent chase? How damaging would that be for the Bucks if Giannis fails to win a ring between then and now and decides he\u2019d have a better chance elsewhere? That\u2019s the elephant in the room, because the franchise is hypersensitive about Giannis and his options next summer. The Bucks do have the ace card, of course. They can, and will, offer him a supermax extension that\u2019ll be more than any other team can offer. And if Giannis puts that level of generational wealth above everything else, then it\u2019ll be an easy decision. Still, others have rejected that money, namely Kawhi Leonard and Anthony Davis, so there\u2019s precedent. And anyway, this isn\u2019t Giannis\u2019 first big contract; it\u2019s his second. He\u2019s already wealthy. All of that, and more, creeps into the picture for Giannis and the Bucks in the event of a second-round ouster and they can\u2019t return to the conference finals, much less the NBA Finals. The atmosphere at this NBA campus does favor a team trying to rally. There\u2019s no home-court advantage of disadvantage, and besides, Milwaukee hasn\u2019t dropped four straight all season. \u201cFirst time in the history playing in a bubble, first time in history a team can come back from down 3-0,\u201d said guard George Hill. This is supposed to be his year and Milwaukee\u2019s year, the second time they entered the playoffs with the league\u2019s best record and the MVP. They were the dominant player and team during the regular season. They were the force that held up the playoffs for a few days to better reflect on social injustice. They came into the playoffs as the top seed and strong favorite against Butler and the upstart Heat. If Giannis and the Bucks exit meekly and quietly, what did it all mean? And: Where is this all headed? * * * Shaun Powell has covered the NBA for more than 25 years. You can e-mail him  here , find his archive here  and follow him on  Twitter  .
